Quite a bourbon overdose, but still extremely tasty, complex and very enjoyable. Excellent stuff.
Draft @ GABF. On a day where I had so many great beers, this one jsut didnt shine as bright. Big oaky vanilla, boozy bourbon, cocoa, some marshmellow, dark fruits, quite sweet. Boozy bitter finish.
Tap. Dark brown, near black with a tan head. Smells like bourbon, oak, raisins, and roasted malt. Flavor is similar with some chocolate. Medium to full bodied.

Several servings at GABF. Pours ink black with half finger of foam. Smell of vanilla, prunes, cotton candy. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, raisin, cloves, with a sweet finish and mild EtOH. Mouthfeel is thick and wonderful. Overall, amazing beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 vintage thanks to nate321. Cork opens up without much fanfare... bummer. Pours a really,really dark brown with no head and still looking. Aroma is nice with wood, bourbon, vanilla. Taste is sweet but not too much with nice caramel and alcohol flavors. Some charred malt notes. I thought the absence of carbonation would disturb me but it is not really the case... It is actually really fun to drink and slick. Nice one! Not sure what was up with the carbonation, though.

11 Vintage (6/1/2012)

Appearance: Pitch black, no head, no lacing.

Smell: Bourbon sweetness, vanilla, molasses.

Taste: Thick, sticky. Bourbon but not nearly as sweet as BCBS and not even close to KBS. Lots of bourbon, maybe too much. If its this boozy with a year on it, I can only imagine how boozy it is fresh.

Finish: Some dark chocolate. Malt. Woodiness. A bit of burn. More sweetness as it warms, but more burn as well.

Overall: Not as complex as other barrel-aged brews. I feel like I should have drank an Old Viscosity first to see how the barrel aging adds or covers elements of the base beer. Ive come to feel that barrel aging needs to enhance or add to the complexities of a beer otherwise it just ends up being overly boozy, like someone splashed bourbon in a stout for no good reason.

Pours a deep rich burnt sienna almost black color with a finger of eggshell gaseous foam. The nose is full of big bourbon notes, boozy raisin, sweet caramel and a touch of vanilla. The palate follows with big burnt caramel sweetness that mingles nicely with the heavy oak bourbon notes. Lots of rustic earthy notes in the background and a long sugary boozy finish.

Bottle @ BeerTemple, Amsterdam.
Pours a flat thick ebony brown.
Toffee nose, some hazelnut, boozy!
Rich taste, roasted caramel, Sacher Torte with grappa it seems. Lingers nicely.
Mi gusta!

Powerful brew and not for the weak. Strong aroma of bourbon and molasses. It smelled thick. Very dark with no head. Poured like syrup. Bourbon was the first and most powerful flavor and a little overwhelming. Man, this was heavy. It almost felt like I was drinking liquid malt extract. Other flavors were molasses, wood, caramelized sugar and some chocolate. This was rich and a little one sided but still a good sipper.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Bottle: Black, inky pour. Not much head at first, but a quick swirl brings forth a nice, tan, creamy froth. Aroma is sweet chocolates, smooth bourbon, and heavy oak. I love the battle between the sweet chocolate fudge notes and the warm bourbon oak... Very well balanced. Mild vanilla and coconut inclusion from the barrel, too. The beer is incredibly smooth, thick body; chewy. Fudge cake flavor with bourbon, molasses drizzle all over. Oak and dark cocoa beans with a twinge of roast and very mild smoke in the finish. Full of bourbon but still very smooth. Super tasty stuff.

Poured from 12oz bottle from Blackwells. Black with very little head. Thick rich oil aroma. Toffee and coffee nose also. Very rich beer. Bourbon Carmel chocolate and slight nutty taste. Huge beer n delicious

2011 bottle drank Sep 2013. One of the bottles that started my cellar. Pours nearly black with just a little coming through brown. No head and but some legs. The aroma so big, rich, and many dimensioned. It lingers in your nose with bourbon, soy, some nuts and chocolate. The flavor is intense, deep, and evolves from rich sweet boozy chocolate with lots of soy and syrupy middle and bitter cocoa and roasty end. The feel is sticky syrup thinned by booze. Its very warming, almost hot. Just wow. This is one my favorite beers in a while. Hits on everything I want from a big old bourbon barrel aged stout. Its a stout right Im gonna call it one cuz it basically is. Drank next to an Old Viscosity of the same age is interesting. I drank most of the Old first and found it not to have aged much in comparison. The Older is more still, more hot, much more soy and umami, and has even more dimension. Love it.
Well Ill be honest, I expected more. More bourbon. More heaven. More balance. Not bad by any means, but this caliber of beer was left too low.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with rapidly settling brown head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is strong bourbon, slightly sharp, vanilla, boozy, bourbon sweet with a mild roast, chocolate finish. Quite sweet, fruity undertones, slight char aftertaste. Moderate carbonation, medium to full body, and smooth texture. Seems a little thin and watery. A sweet bourbon beer. Again a solid offering, though it isnt a rich or full as Uncle Jacobs. Solid but not really worth the price.
Inköpt på Citybeer i San Fran. PANG! Kraftfull aroma och smak. Välbalanserad, underbar hint av cocos ;)
Pours black with no head. Smells of coffee, alcohol, slight sweetness and roasted malts. Tastes of alcohol, coffee, little licorice, and a little oak. Smooth and warm going down. Delicious.

Pours black with a minimal mocha head. Swirling it leaves small lacerations in the glass. Aroma is raisins, plum, caramel, dates, figs, vanilla, slight notes of tobacco, leather and smoke. Could sniff this all day long. Taste is caramel, honey, raisins, dates, figs with hints of vanilla, tar, tobacco, bourbon. Aftertaste is dried fruits, smoke and hints of black peppercorn along with some slight warming alcohol. Just magnificent!!

Det här var gott, riktigt gott. Smaken var oerhört kraftfull med mycket smak av choklad, sherry och sherry. Kroppen var stabilare än stonhenge och balansen var jämnare än Richard Geres slätrakade kind.
Dark brown/black pour with a tan head. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla and oak. Flavor is chocolate molasses, vanilla and some bourbon. One hell of a good brew.

Tap at churchkey august 2013
Pours almost pitch black danm this is insane lots of barrel age oxidization damn huge beer lots of roast char and vanilla. Damn huge flavors here almost stout in flavors. Over the top but complex

Pours thick black with a mocha head. Smells of big booze, vanilla, chocolate and sweet chocolate and dark fruit. Taste is boozy, chocolate, rich sweet malts, vanilla and oak. Thick full flavor and thick like motor oil. Very good bourbon barrel aged beer!

Å herre jävlar. Det här var jag inte riktigt beredd på. 
-Ska vi ta en sån här? , den är ju ganska bra.. Säger Johan.
Vafan det är ju absolut värdsklass!! betalade vi en hundring var delat på tre pers vill jag minnas. Ååå så ljuvligt. Får flashbacks till den gamla goda tiden då goose Island fortfarande var ett oberoende bryggeri. Underbart! Tack grabbar!!!

So good! Like Bourbon County crossed with KBS. Bourbon forward with coffee and some chocolate. Nearly if not perfection. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with a touch of tan head. Crazy good aromas off this. Massive bourbon aromas. Nice vanilla and coconut too. Smells like sweet sex candy. Flavours are quite boozy... bourbon, vanilla, coconut, notes of coffee and dark chocolate. This big boy is a sipper. And a damn good one.

Natifest 10
8/07/2010: Port Brewing Older Viscosity ... Aroma: Fantastic vanilla with a slight bit of boubon, rich malts, port. Appearance: Near black pour; beige-colored crown. Flavor: Oak, just a hint of cork; tons of malt; vanilla. Palate: Full-bodied; creamy and milky; coats the mouth nicely. Overall: Very good.
12.7 Fl. Oz. corked and caged bottle (ALC. 12.0% BY VOL.). Rating #890 for this beer.

Aged this bottle for 6 months. Fantastic aroma of vanilla, coconut, aged oak and wood; some tropical rum notes on the tail end. Pure black appearance with a half inch brown foam. Ive been told by friend that this was an intense and alcohol filled beer but, I think it may have mellowed out as it aged. Very smooth flavors of chocolate, molasses, oak, raisins, plums and red wine upfront. Thick maple, brown sugar and pineapple notes on the finish. Overall, very complex and delicious. Alcohol is not noticeable in the slightest. Still not sure if it had mellowed out during the aging process. Id give this an A+ rating. 

EDIT: As I continue to drink, I sense some hot chilli or pepper notes on the back of the palate.

2010 bottle that ive had cellared at 50-54 degrees since purchasing it, opened tonight. Served in a snifter. The cork was very tight in the bottle. Some sediment was visible inside the neck of the bottle where the cork once was. Black pour that creates a beige head when swirled. Aroma of whiskey charred oak. Very pleasing. The taste is similar with lots of coffee, vanilla, and a touch of anise. The whiskey and coffee flavors are very prominent. The coffee essence is outstanding. Not a trace of soy sauce as I had expected. Instead this is a very robust stout that drinks like well aged bourbon with the delightfulness of a premium coffee liqueur. Slick in the mouth but not too thick. So good.

Pours jet black with carmel colored head that doesnt last long. Smells malty, chocolate, dried fruit with a lot of carmel smell to it. Nice boozy notes on the back end of the scent. Super thick mouth feel, tastes chocolate and carmel and booze. Wood and smoke on the back end medium, adds so much complexity. A pleasure to drink!! Amazing brew
Bottle..pour is dark black with a thin tan head. .Nose is fudge,sweet bourbon,vanilla,spice...Taste is dark chocolate, caramel, toffee, cream, oak, dry, nice bourbon..very well done

Bottle 375ml @ Sommerhus
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma has notes of malt, oak, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, alcohol and licorice. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long oak, vanilla, chocolate and warm finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.

Pours jet black with a thin tan head. Smells like a barrel of whiskey, with thick notes of sticky malt, hints of espresso, dark chocolate, leather, and tobacco.
Taste is complex. Theres an undergirding of sweetness, but this is a burly bitter brew with hefty boozy overtones.
Medium to full body, lively carbonation, bitter chocolate aftertaste.
Impressive beast. I loved it!

Dark and brooding with a creamy brown foam. Strong bourbon aroma has hints of vanilla and oak. Alcohol is strong and spoils some of the other malt flavors. Otherwise, good mouthfeel and pleasing finish.

On tap at old Chicago. Pours midnight black with brown lacy head. This beer seems to devour light. Aroma is strong bourbon with hints of coffee. Taste is fantastic. Smooth and sweet up front with a chocolate bourbon finish. This beer is amazing.

Bottle from Binnys in Lincoln Park, dark brown pour with minimal tan head. Aroma of bourbon, little burn, nutty, caramel, chocolate and light vanilla. Taste is dark fruit, chocolate, and some nice barrel, smooth finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I have been a fan of Old Viscosity for some time but had not had the chance to try the older variety. All I can say is that it was worth the wait in more ways than one. This is a very dark and strong beer that has sweet, malty flavor that is supported by the oak aging. The hops serve to mellow out the sweetness and the aroma is great. A must have!
Bourbon, lots of bourbon, but no burn. Just tasty smooth thick velvet. Smooth bourbon. Chocolate, carmel, smoky burnt malt.

Deep black in color... Aroma of oak, bourbon, roasted malts... Flavor is roasted malts, bourbon, chocolate... Alcohol notes are prevalent, not terribly sweet, but better that way... Solid if not really good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The normal Old Viscosity is already ambrosia but this one is a step beyond. Have had it several times in past years (only ever on draft) but this is my first time rating it. Draft at Monks Cafe. Pitch black pour with a dark brown head. Rich chocolate bourbon notes off the top. Swoon-worthy. Perfect silky body. Deep chocolate mousse. Creme brule. Charcoal grill. Burnt marshmallows. Red leather. Fig. Molasses. Heady alcohol, but so creamy a finish that it merely provides a glorious haze to the experience.  Probably my favorite stout of all time (next to maybe only the Bourbon Barrel Angel Share, which is a close cousin.) Nearly a perfect mix of pitch black dark with a rich chocolate cream. The Bourbon only heightens the experience. SEEK THIS OUT!!!

This has been one of my white whales for a long time, really glad it finally made it out to chicago. Has a strange astringent red vinegar smell, but looks great. Wow, amazingly pleasant smooth complex taste. Butterscotch, plum, nutmeg, sherry, and fig. So smooth...almost too smooth, the mouthfeel could be creamier and slightly more bourbon bite. Overall, its still amazing and worth the price if you see it.

Bottles.  Dark black color, very small if any tan head on it.  I believe my bottles were from the no carbonation days.  Huge bourbon and malt / chocolate smell.  Taste was very light carbonation, almost flat, with a lot of bourbon, but enough roasted malts to balance it out.  Pretty good stuff, I would like to try it again, but since I do not really do much with beer anymore, I somehow doubt I will.
Tulip glass at Harrys Hofbrau. Complex boozy, bourbon and deep fruit nose. Raisin. Dark brown with brown highlights. Rich malt. Bourbon. Well balanced.
Deep deep brown almost black with an average sized tan head. Aroma is of oak, vanilla, bourbon, cola, molasses. Taste is heavy in oak, vanilla, booze, caramel, brown sugar, roasted malts.

Bottle. The look is dark, thin tan head, oily, and black in color. The smell is so good, its bourbon, woody, heavy, alcohol, malt, and complex. The taste is woody, alcohol, strong, bourbon, malt, and great. Thick and oily.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 2013 bottle: poured into goblet.  If you love barrel aged whiskey beers, this one is top notch. Clean and smooth all over the place. I want some older viscosity cologne right now!
Draught.  This is like engine oil with hops. Its awesome.  Perfect balance and bitter roasted malts, hops, and bourbon.

2012 Vintage Bottle. 5/17/13. Pours black with a thin brown head. Aroma is bourbon, oak, fruit, licorice, molasses, chocolate, spicy. Taste is bourbon, alcohol, fruit, vanilla, caramel, coffee, butty, dark chocolate; bitter coffee finish. No lacing. Rich, full mouth feel. Medium-low carbonation. Alcohol very well-hidden. This was fantastic. One of the smoothest rides Ive had, especially considering the ABV. This is incredible.

2013 vintage bottle.  12% ABV, really? No way, its boozy but I would not guess it.  Big vanilla and oak nose.  Maybe some brown sugar, chocolate,  and a hint of coffee.  Reminds me of an imperial stout.  I was expecting a thicker velvety finish, a bit thin.  Still an awesome beer.

On tap at Hops and Pie so 12/13 vintage.  Boozy hot bourbon nose with vanilla and some dark malts.  Slightly translucent at edges and not as thick as I was expecting.  I honestly think I prefer Old Viscosity to this....will need to revisit that one cause its been a while.  Flavors of vanilla, bourbon, coconut, and dark malt.  Good but not complex and a bit thin.

Trade from burg at the Swamp Head release. Thanks! Pours black with no head, not as thick as a stout but not thin either. Big bourbon vanilla aroma with some black licorice and chocolate. Thick velvety mouthfeel with nearly no carbonation at all. Thicker than it looked on the pour wow. Big sweet vanilla oak. Lots of bourbon. Definite bit of licorice and hints of cocoa. Lingering and long ladting vanilla on the palate. Lots going on here and a surefire sipper. Old Viscosity was decent, but this really takes it to a new level. Awesome beer.

12.7oz Bottle. Pours a thick (5W30)  opaque blackish brown (more black than brown), thin espresso colored head (more like a film) . Nose is bourbon barrel, vanilla, dried fruit (figs and dates dominant). Mouth is thick and oily (whatd ya expect?), bittersweet and full of boozy goodness, toffee, cocoa, vanilla, coffee. The ABV in this is well hidden. Delicious.
Pours black with tan head and some lacing.  Aroma of cinnamin, cough syrup, and soy sauce.  Taste is complex with dark fruit, bourbon, booze, and more cough syrup.  Outstanding beer.
Pours black with off white head.  Aromas of oak and mild bourbon  with flavors to follow.  Not a bad ba strong ale.

Opaque very dark brown with a mocha colored head.  Nice chocolate liqueur and a bit of coconut nose. Viscous, chewy moutfheel with a bi of carbonation sting on the back if the tongue that is exacerbated by some hop hotness and then, alcohol warmth. A ton of chocolate and smooth vanilla yield to extraordinary booziness.  All except for that alcohol that appears so obtrusively at the finish, this is a remarkably good beer.

Completely black pour 2 finger brown head. Pretty sticky. Cinnamon and brown sugar. Loads of vanilla on the nose. Hint of oak. Taste is very sweet. Boozy burn at the finish. Tasted like a blend of stout and barley wine. Pretty exceptional.

Pitch black pour with an almost non-existent light brown head. Nose is dominated by the vanilla, caramel and oak from the barrel, boozy notes, theres some milk chocolate, and dark fruit. Amazing tasting beer, surprising amount of mocha, lots of vanilla and oak notes from the barrel, theres some bitter chocolate and a bit of caramel. Well balanced, almost no carbonation from the aging though. Great desert beer.

01/05/2013 Ma che siete venuti a fà (375ml bottle, 2009 vintage). Bruna, abbastanza densa, quasi impenetrabile, schiuma virtualmente assente. Al naso sentori di caramello, toffee e tostato, ossidazione, vaniglia e altri sentori di botte (bourbon), forte etilico. In bocca ha un attacco dolciastro, etilico, tostato, finale amaro lungo e persistente. Corpo medio-pieno, notevole nonostante i 5 anni di invecchiamento, praticamente piatta. Mi aspettavo di più.
Draft at DLD - pours dark brown with light brown head. Nose is bourbon. Flavor adds chocolate, alcohol and dark chocolate. Dry. Roasted malts contribute to bitterness. A sipper.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2013 Ill be doing a direct comparison of this and the non-BBA Old Viscosity at a later date. For now, I will say this is quite the sipper. Strong bourbon, vanilla, and perhaps caramel notes in smell. Bourbon hits first in taste, giving way to more vanilla notes. Strong alcohol burn, a bit surprising given its "relatively" low 12% ABV. Good, but would benefit from aging. Old Viscosity from memory is one of my favorite beers, so Im looking forward to the direct comparison. This one though is a a Big Beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour is black with no head at all. Aroma of dark molasses, bourbon, chocolate, maple syrup, and spice. Flavor is more mellow on the bourbon/booze than I would have thought from the aroma. Notes of caramel, dark fruit, and molasses. Flavor is a bit watery and cloying.

2013 bottle, into a tulip.  Pours thick brown with very little head.  Nose is vanilla, bourbon, caramel.  Flavor is complex and balanced with roast, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, tobacco.  Full bodied, delicious.

Bottle. Pours very, very dark brown with no head. Nose shows a heap of vanilla, cookie dough, touches of spice, light bourbon and white chocolate. Very sweet stuff. Bourbon is never too much which is nice. Sweet vanilla and chocolate combine to make up the majority of the tastes coming through. Very light spice under it all. A little thin in the mouth. Well made beer

On tap @ Chucks 85th. A rare enough beer but a real treat to find on tap.  Pours inky super thick black with thin creamy mocha head. Aroma is soy sauce, charred malt, dark chocolate, and bourbon. Taste is similar with even richer flavors and heavy mouthfeel. Big oaky flavor.  Not quite as strong on the bourbon as I expected as this is pretty much cask strength. Comes in 375 bottles for a reason - a little of this goes a long way. Much bigger beer than Old Viscosity, bigger flavor in every regard, but much less drinkable too. Perhaps the perfect dessert beer?

Bottle. Jet black, medium tan head but not much. Aroma reminds me of madeira: raisin, alcohol, chocolate. Flavor has similar qualities, more emphasis on the alcohol, assertive cocoa bitterness. A good beer for sure, perhaps a little disappointing when held against other beers in its class.

Black, thin head, light but complex aroma of barrel, dark chocolate, vanilla, alcohol; nice. Flavor is somewhat lighter than expected, but complex with dark chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, wood, and alcohol. Alcohol is just a bit harsh here, and makes it a little bit unrefined. Overall the flavor is complex and very balanced. This is an interesting and easy to sip beer. Moderate carbonation, finish stays interesting. Nice but very pricey.

Black with little to no head. Aroma is big bourbon with just a touch of vanilla. Flavor is strong bourbon. It almost tastes exactly like a good bourbon with a strong malt backbone. Makes for a great after dinner drink, but pairing it would be difficult. Could have a bigger body to balance, but if you drink it as a bourbon its not as noticeable.

Wife: 4.3

Bottle aged for ?? Years. Great aroma of wood, dark fruits, vanilla  color appears to be the darkest brown ever vs. Black. 4 on palate. Not chewy but very slick and smooth. Taste is Chocolate dark fruit licorice followed by bourbon at end

Poured into a tulip glass with no head at all. Nearly completely flat. I am not sure of the vintage since the bottle date is illegible. It appears to have been on the older side since the lack of carbonation and the cork was a biotch to remove. I had to use a cork screw and even then the corkscrew almost pulled out. Pours a near black in the glass. Aroma is of bourbon and maple. The taste is delicious. Like the 09 Nemesis I had last night, age has treated this beer very well. While flat, it is still enjoyable. There is a sweetness to this beer that isnt too overpowering. The bourbon warms the mouth but isnt too hot as it may have been when first bottled. The lingering taste is that of coffee in the back of your throat. The feel is as the name implies, quite oily. A nice treat.

Bottle at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. The colour is deep brown to black and looks like oil. Has no head. Has a very complex and sweet aroma where oak, leather, licorice and liquor being the most dominant. The flavour is also complex and has a more roasted touch along with chocolate truffles, coffee, port and black currant. The mouth feel is rich and as oily as it can get. Light bitterness. A fantastic and incredibly complex ale. Best Ive tried for a long time.

Pours thick and dark mahogany color with very little head. The aroma is complex with vanilla, tobacco, barrel, and caramel. The flavor is really well balanced with sweetness almost dominating a grainy roasty flavor. Really tasty.

Bottle at home. Pours black with no head. Smells of bourbon and chocolate. Very sweet with aromas of bourbon, coconut, chocolate and alcohol. Also hints of vanilla, oak and tobacco. Full bodied. Very soft carbonation. Long very dry finish with more alcohol.

2012 bottle. Pours dark with a tan head that fades to a ring. Aroma is rich chocolate and bourbon with notes of wood and earth. Taste is rich velvety chocolate and bourbony goodness. Chocolate, wood, soy sauce, and bourbon frame the taste with a medium body and a nice smooth finish.

Bottle 375ml.
Small "pop" at opening. Pours black with no head. Aroma is of malt, alcohol, fruits, caramel. Taste is of malt, caramel (x2), sweet, warming alcohol. Palate: Full bodied, round. Overall: A bit heavy. Lots of alcohol. A real sipper.

From a bottle shared at home.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of dark ripe cherries with a hint of chocolate.  Rich and thick mouthfeel.  Flavors of raisins, toffee, ripe cherry and molasses.  Boozy finish.  Exceptional.

12.7 ounce bottle.  Thanks Tom! Pours black with a small reddish brown head.  Aroma of malt, fruit, chocolate, and bourbon.  Taste is sweet malt, dark fruits, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and coffee.  Great sipper!

Bottle (375 ml). Traded by pushkinwow, thanks Stephen! Opaque brown/black with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of dark fruits, bourbon, vanilla, caramel and chocolate. Taste is about the same with raisins in the finish. Thick, viscous and full bodied. Warming alcohol. Low carbonation (but not flat). This is a luscious beer, really complex and relatively good balance for the style. Impressive sipper!

Bottle 2011. Courtesy of Slackermads,  I failed to empty his fridge, but at least I went for the good stuff. Pours near black with no head. Aroma is heavy with chocolate, caramel, chocolate-syrup, alcohol, vanilla, sweet quality licorice, oak,bourbon, dark roasted malt, soy and spice. Taste is heavy sweet, medium bitter and has a light acidic note. Body is near full, texture is thick and smooth, nearly flat carbonation. Finishes sweet,  bitter malty and alcoholic. In the far finish there is solid oak . Rating no. 200. Chocolate and caramel bonanza!  Lets see if I can hustle another from his fridge.

Bottle (vintage 2011) shared with pentaz, who stopped by to empty the fridge. Dark brown with a small light brown head that quickly leaves without a trace. Aroma is chocolate and caramel syrup, oak, bourbon. A bit rough with alcohol, roasted malt and salty liqourice towards the finish. Taste is heavy sweet, light salty, full body, oily texture, near flat carbonation. Long developing aroma that most of all ends up in bourbon, oak, vanilla. Bourbon brew.

2011 Release
Appearance: The body appears black through the center, but its actually a very deep mahogany thats rather clear, only a very thin short lived tan head.
Aroma: Oak is very heavy right away, but bourbon and chocolate and coffee come through, nice balance.
Taste: The flavor is very mellow on the intro only hinting at cocoa and coffee, the flavor quickly picks up and tastes of diluted bourbon and heavy oak with an underlying cocoa and coffee that are very subdued and noticed most in the lingering flavor and slight coating on the tongue.
Palate: A bit thin and watery, no carbonation at all.
Overall: Decent beer, but a bit thin and watery, the diluted bourbon winds up being the main flavor and its a bit boring.
Vanilliger Antrunk, weich, harmlos. Deutlich Bourbon, mild erdig, weiter Vanille. Ebenfalls nur gering röstig, zum Ende alkoholisch. Ein merkwürdig mildes Bier. 8/11/10/9/9/10

Drinking a two year old version. Lots of intense flavor. Very good but very potent. A sipper for sure.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a dark black color with aromas of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, wood, ligt roast, and some sweetness.  Flavors follow the aroma a light creaminess on the palate.  I could drink this beer everyday and not get tired if it.

This is a beautiful beer!!  Sample pour of deep dark, murky blackness with no head.  Nose is intense bourbon with oak, heavy vanilla and chocolate all over.  Absolutely amazing! Flavor is boozy as can be, due to the bourbon.  Vanilla and smooth roasted malts throughout.  Bourbon... and more bourbon... Im in love.  Smooth caramel throughout... Killer... Smooth medium body with no lacing... Wow.

Mmm, by far the best of the two versions. Minimal head disappears quickly. Tobacco, leather, bourbon in the nose. Much of this carries over to the taste as burnt malts jump on board. Tasty and complex; a nice brew to grab once in awhile.

12.7 oz bottle, thanks to Jay. Black color. Minimal off-white head. Bits of lace. Awesome big bourbon oak nose. Vanilla, chocolate syrup. Bigger body. Light carbonation. Dry finish. Taste is sweet with an alcoholic bite. Hard to drink unless you do it in very small sips, definitely a noticeable 12%. Very aromatic ale, great bourbon character, but lacks a balance, hurts drinkability. Makes me curious to try the standard Old Viscosity -- I bet that has what Im looking for

Serving: 375 ml. bottle of the 2011 vintage from Habersham Liquors.  It pours a muddy dark brown with a very slight head.  The nose is heavy raisin, lighter bourbon, vanilla, and roasted malt.  The flavor leans towards the sweet side with dark dried fruit, slight soy, bourbon, vanilla, and light chocolate.  Rich and very full bodied with a lasting, warming boozy finish.  Rather tasty.

2011 vintage. Pours a clear dark orange-brown color with a thin head that fades quickly. Aroma of whisky, roasted malts, raisin booze. The taste is booze, roasted malts, chocolate, raisin. Medium bodied. Solid beer.

Pours black. Little head. Aroma is strong figs with molasses and bourbon. Taste... Outstanding. Complex, yet simple. Interesting yet balanced. Everything plays so well together. Theres bourbon, sweetness, roasted malt, and just enough hops to control the sweetness. This is an eye roller. Every sip gets better as it gets warmer. Its almost as though this brew has established its own style, or better yet, marries the styles of stout, barley wine, and strong ale. The best of each world. Truely a world class brew worth savoring. I really like it, can you tell?

Draft at Bigwood, 12/6/2012 [7 of 11].  From notes.
Aroma:  Bourbon, oak, sticky sweetness, dark fruit and toffee there as well.
Appearance:  Deep dark, think.  Ring of off-white head.
Taste:  Smoke. Barrel. Chocolate. Toffee.  Finishes with s roasted coffee.  Mississippi Mud Blizzard.
Mouthfeel:  Full-bodied. Viscous.  Moderate carbonation.
Overall:  Im a sucker for beers like this.  So dar, rich, sweet and oaky -- this is the stuff I love.

Bottle from trade with Crajun.  Pours a very dark black color with very little head.  Ok lacing.  Big sweet bourbon aroma mixed with hints of vanilla, tobacco, wood and coconut.  Taste has a big bourbon flavor up front, a bit overpowering.  Finish has lingering bourbon taste with hints of coconut, vanilla and wood.  Moderate alcohol burn.  Medium body and pretty silky mouthfeel.  I much prefer the Old Viscosity.  The bourbon is too much here and covers up the great flavors of the base beer.

Aroma is full of dark chocolate, oak, bourbon.  Taste follows.  Great mouth feel, silky and viscous like it should be.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Hops and Pie, 10oz for $8 is not bad considering that a 375ml bottle costs $17. Dark black, no surprises there. Smells fantastic like chocolates and a very subtle barrel and bourbon character. the taste is equally fantastic, chocolate, slightly boozy but the barrel and bourbon never take over. This is a very well done beer, other breweries should take notes because most barrel-aged beers are all barrel and booze. Oh, it wasnt flat either.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 07-10-2011 01:04:27

Bottle, 12.7 fl oz, at Cardinal. Its a rather flat one, without head, just some dark beige bubbles around the rim, black in color. Licorice, booze, roasted malts, dried fruits like prunes and figs, soy sauce and some umami in the aroma. The flavor is quite sweetish, with some soy sauce, licorice, booze and dried fruits. Its full-bodied, warming and soft on the palate, with nice carbonation. Lasting finish with sweetness and lots of flavor. Some warmth. Wonderfully heavy bottle, sort of sexy...  Anyway, its a wonderful beer. 121022

37.5cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. I cant decipher the date info. Pitch black colour with a very small head. Aroma is very sweet and laden with malts, coffee, sugar, syrup, alcohol and caramel. Flavour is also very sweet. Sugar, alcohol, coffee, syrup and a bit more alcohol. Despite all the alcohol it is surprisingly easy to drink. Long lingering aftertaste.

Duft af bounty bar (kokos, chokolade og vanilla). Den er sort med en smule skum. Smager af chokolade og er meget alkohol tung. Der er ikke meget kulsyre og den er tynd i fylden og har en lang sødme. Lækker øl

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Exellent beer. Good flavor of chocolate, caramel and vanilla. The consitence is creamy and it leaves a coating feel,
Great beer! With coconut, choco, vanille and other great flavours. Expensive but very good!

Dark brown, no head. Vanilla, coconut, milk chocolate, molasses, cream. Coffee, chocolate, dark dried fruits, strong sweet alcohol. Aftertaste of burnt malts and coffee.
I recommend it big time.
One of the best beers i ever had. Coconut, cream, chocolate, cocio, vanilla, bourbon. Soft, smooth and light mouth feel. Extremely well made beer.
Fantastic aroma. Very complex. Vanilla, malibu, coco, coffee. Not all black but dark brown. Taste is just as the aroma prenounces. Wonderful.
Fra flaske på Cardinaltreff mai-11: stillheten senket seg rundt bordet før jubelen brøt løs. Dette ølet MÅ jeg prøve igjen, og da lage skikkelige notater!

Sorprendente, punto. Aroma magnifico di cioccolato fondente con una punta di caffè e note alcoliche. Staresti per ore ad annusarla poi improvvisamente ti viene voglia di metterla nel bicchiere. Nerissima con una schiuma marrone blanda e poco persistente. Al palato si rinnovano le stesse impressioni notate a naso: Cioccolato fondente, caffè (in piccola parte) e poi una nota alcolica tipo rhum. Corposa riempie la bocca in maniera elitaria. Ottima. Costa un pò ma se la vedete compratela.

Bottle. The color is NOT pitch black, but almost black. Nonexistent head. Aroma is that of coconut, vanilla, malt; sweet. Very nice. Flavors are malt, coffee and alcohol. Mouthfeel is oily, no carbonation really, but not smooth like e.g. an oat stout. Finish is sweet and malty, a little bit bitter, and alcohol. Overall, this is was a very nice beer, but the alcohol shines through more than I am used to, taking some points off it. Also, quite expensive.
Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Almost black colour, not much head. Strong sour whiskey malt aroma. Sweet chocolate, treacle whiskey flavour. Very stron sweet sickley aftertaste. Not my sort of beer.

Aged bottle - pours a jet black with the thinnest of tan lacing (but there is some, which is more than others in the style).  Aroma is soft, but pleasant - chocolate, malt, light alcohol (bourbon) and some caramel notes in the background.  Flavor is very nice - bourbon in the background, but heavy on the sweet malts coming to the forefront - a great sipper.  Palate is nicely done as well - not light, but not heavy, and little to no alcohol burn (drinks light for the ABV).  Lost Abbey did this one right - great drinking Impy!

Pours pretty much black with a next to non-existant head. Aroma is incredibly rich, vanilla, dark fruit, coffee, roasted malt, molasses. Taste is equally impressive. Almost like an imperial stout but with a hint of bitterness more akin to a strong ale. Opens very boozy sweet before that bitterness balances it up. Body is rich, creamy and full, carbonation is low and finish is magnificient. Had The Angels Share yesterday, and this one today. So impressed by this brewery!

Bottle to oversized tulip (from notes). 2011 vintage.  Looks good; black and thick with no head whatsoever (bourbon effect?).  Smells excellent; caramel, bourbon, and malt are all present.  Tastes great too; all of the above items are well-represented, especially the bourbon and the malt. Mouthfeel is good; warm, but thats to be expected, especially because its this years version and hasnt aged long.  Overall, a great beer that Id love to have again.

Bottle care of Mr Paul Unwin. Colour is opaque black, dark brown at the edges, no head. Nose is pungent sweet whiskey barrel, malty, vanilla, wood, creosote, marmite, alcohol. Taste is sweet bourbon whiskey, vanilla, oak wood, marmite (yeast extract) dark chocolate. On the finish theres a burn at the back of the throat, warming. At first the whiskey barrel is too  overwhelming on the other flavours but it grows on the palate.

Big black pour w/ a small dense dark brown head and limited lacing.  The thing looks black, thick, and beautiful.  Big barreled aroma rich bourbon hints of vanilla, alcohol, syrups, dry oak, over some roast malts, hints of chocolate and a touch of coffee.  My only real complaint in the aroma is that its a bit light for a big beer, likely due to the minimal amount of carbonation.  Palate is big thick and creamy.  Taste is big rich mellow and well blended.  Loads of rich malts, chocolates, vanillas, other rich bourbon notes, a dry oak finish on the tongue.  Some light milk chocolate in their as well.  Delicious!

Straight up pour and only a thin brown head that vanishes leaving no lace. Black color, no highlights. Very light carbonation and heavy bodied.  Nose is alcohol, almost like cognac and flavor is sweet oak and alcohol. Some alcohol burn at finish. Expensive at $17.99 for a caged & corked 375ml bottle from Julios Liquors Westborough, Ma.

Jet black, nice khaki head. Bourbon overwhelming on the nose. Flavor is very complex. Bourbon is huge but nice  coffee like notes. Palate is full and silky. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle - pored deep vrown with no head, no carbonation. Drain pour! The smell is soaked with Bourbon (too muc in fact). A bit of charcoal roast but thats it. Taste is bourbon while viscosity is not that thick. Probably there are some fans for this, but not me.
August 30, 2012 bottle at BVerys tasting. Black pour with almost no head.  Bourbon, malt and wood in aroma and taste.  Thanks Brian!

Pours black with just touches of ruby. No head, just a thin collar.
Huge amounts of bourbon with touches of caramel, vanilla, oak, and coconut
Taste is pretty much the nose. Same stuff really but more coconut. 
Slick and oily feel.
Delicious stuff. May be a bourbon bomb but a really good BA treatment

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Un-friggin-believable. Jet black oily pour. Huge aroma of bourbon and wood. Taste is wood, bourbon, sweetness from the booze - absolutely beautiful.

Bottle, 2010 vintage. Pours pitch black with a huge creamy brown head - not sure why others report no head. Good staying power, creamy texture and nice lacing. Room filling aroma of chocolate, raisin, bourbon, more bourbon, and perhaps a bit of vanilla. Wow. Flavor is very reminiscent of the best imperial stouts, medium sweet chocolate, bourbon, dark roasted malt, raisin. Finish is quite alcoholic, warming and lightly coffee bitter. Despite the name, I find this a bit light bodied as compared to what the aroma and flavor profiles would suggest. Very nice, and MUCH better than Old Viscosity.

I was very impressed with this beer.  Pours black, no carbonation or head, I really had to pry the cork out.  Smells rich and chocolaty, booze well hidden.  Palate is rich and full, sweet, with lots of chocolate and vanilla, a hint of roast, and a lingering finish.  Awesome stuff thats a great sipper, should be served warm, and hides alcohol well.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on August 23rd, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a viscous black. 
Aroma: Smells like the malt of an imperial stout, oaky, strong malt.
Taste: Taste is not as strong as the nose.  Roasty maly, faint oak some caramel, bourbon.
Palate:Medium light body, lingering faint aftertaste.
Summary: Really interesting beer. Nose is way strong, but taste is not nearly as aggressive.

Bottle at home.
Black with a very small brown head. Aroma heavy malty (roasted, coffee, licorice, barrel, bourbon, vineous). Flavor heavy sweet, light burning of alcohol, light bitter. Body almost full, quite flat.

Bottle at Amundsen
Pours dark dark brown, almost no head except for some big bubbles that falls off quite fast. Smells of chocolate sauce and hints of soy sauce. Heavy heavy without something that breaks through. Heavy sweet, still chocolate sauce. This can easily replace chocolate sauce on your ice cream dessert... I also find some port notes and oak in the back. For me this beer seems quite overrated, its all too sweet and chocolate laden. Still i managed to drink it up, guess it was just because of the price of the bottle

Tabac, mélasse, café dans un noyau chocolaté qui rappel vivement les outils, vieux classique de party de noël. Les notes de whiskey prennent leur place au fur et à mesure. Une belle addition dans un six services de gibier.

Black colored pour. Slim layer of tan bubbles that dont last long. No lacing. Big bourbon aroma. Malt, pepper, wood, vanilla, and slight alcohol. Taste is the same with some raisin and figs mixed in. Tons of vanilla-y bourbon. Nice sweet mouthfeel. Very good.

375ml bottle @ Gradi Plato BeerShop Rome. Aroma: dark chocolate, wood/oak, liquorice, bourbon. Appearance: without head, flat and dark beer. Taste: vanilla, liquorice, coffee and bourbon oak. Palate: full body, almost creamy and good bitter finish. Overall: fantastic bourbon oak aged beer!!!

Bottle: Vintage 2009: again no completely black pour:
No head, a completely flat and black colored beer.
The smell is marvelous mix of vanilla, wood/oak, liquorice, bourbon, smooth spices, earth.
The taste is subliminally soft and smooth: wood, vanilla, dust, mocha, toffee, oak, light creamy liquorice notes, roasted barleys malts, spices, coffee with milk notes (in the far distance), some caramel, smooth bitterness, some dark (sticky) fruits and some earthy notes.
The aftertaste is a mix of vanilla, creamy soft liquorice, sticky bitter barley malts and some dark fruity liquor spices. Very nice and all by all well balanced.
No carbo, soft light spicy watery oily soft mouthfeel, full body and an oily sticky texture.
Wow, what a beer! This is worth a hype, where is the hype?
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle.... 2011 vintage... trade with javit.... shared with Karin....It pours pitch black with a nice thick creamy tan head..... The aroma is very nice... raisins, liquor, port, brown sugar and sweet licorice......The flavor is dark fruits, rom, chocolate, sweet roasted malt and some alcohol.....very nice fantastic brew.....

From notes: Poured deep, opaque black with a small, thin dark tan head that was gone quickly.  Aromas of vanilla, alcohol/bourbon and a mild woody note.  Full-bodied and thick, as the name would imply.  Coffee flavor mixed with vanilla that gives way to woody notes.  The coffee reappears in the finish.  Alcohol was well-controlled.  Excellent.
No head. Lots of flavor. Great strong/old ale. Really expensive though. If i could go back Id swap this out for more of another beer.

Pours a pitch black with a quickly fading tan head that is super viscous and leaves limited lacing but coats the glass with a thickness... Vanilla oak bourbon dominate the aroma, some dark fruits, alcohol, very nice... Boozy, kinda sweet, bourbon oak vanilla come in late, some chocolate some smoke, very complex a little charcoal, loads of flavors, most arrive late in the sip... Moderately lively, full bodied... Just an awesome beer...
No head at all, pitch black. Big on vanilla, crème brulee and licorice. Alcoholic but very refined. Sweet and delicious. (At Deans Tasting)

37.5cl bottle.
No head.  Clear dark pour.  Yummy.  Raisin aroma.  Alcohol aftertaste but smooth.  Yummy!

Bottle via secret santa.  Thanks man!  Why the hell do I always have to use a pair of pliers to get the corks out of these lost abbey beers?  Its not like they have carbonation or anything.  Maybe thats the problem.  This beer pours a motor oil black with almost no head.  Aromas of anise, some chocolate, bourbon and oak.  Taste is very heavy on the oak and bourbon.  No hop presence detected.  Vinous, anise, rum.  Dry finish.  Meh.  Not a huge fan of this beer overall, but glad I tried it.

Bottle. Aromas of sugar plums, bourbon, licorice, molasses, and coffee. Prune juice color; thick muddy brown with good lacing. Smooth and very sweet flavors, lots of bourbon, somewhat cake-like, and overall just a bit too cloying. Thick, heavy body. Really a bit over-the-top, delicious in small doses, but too sweet to drink much of it.
Thick dark beer with a small head. Good nose with aromas of sweet caramel, chocolate and bourbon and a hint of vanilla. A complex and powerful beer which is perfect for sharing

Thanks to masterchiefMD for sharing this at my most recent tasting.

2008 vintage. Consumed March 19, 2010.

A: Black with a decent head and great lacing.

S: Bourbon, rich creamy stout, buttery and sweet.

T: This is a creamy, buttery stout with a very prominent bourbon component. It is done quite well. The 12% ABV is present, but the beer is not overly boozy. The bourbon does slightly overrun other aspects of the beer, i.e. rich roasted malt, toffee, chocolate, etc.

M: Silky smooth and creamy with little carbonation.

D: A small sample was plenty. Sweet bourbon stouts can be a chore to drink by yourself. Great for splitting with a friend or two.
Pours headless black. Thick caramel flavor with bourbon, oak, vanilla and booze. Partner describes it as a memory foam mattress on the tongue.

Appearance- Pours a thick black with a small tan head.
Aroma- Sweet caramel, vanilla, bourbon.
Flavor- Big sweet kick, caramel and chocolate comes through, Nice roasted malt and alcohol finish. Nice blend of vanilla dn bourbon mixed in. Very thick and smooth. Like a fine port wine or sherry. I will definately be getting this beer again.

Bottle 376ml, a dark beer without head and carbonation. Nose is already powerful on prune, oak, soy sauce and caramel. Aroma is on caramel, vanilla, oak, soy sauce, round chocolate, intense red grape and prune, extremely complex and very drinkable ! The aroma bouquet is so powerful that we dont feel the 12° alcohol. Long vinous and light sour aftertaste with oak and vanilla notes, some bitterness with light ashes touch, salt water and dry red wine notes. A really well done beer, complex, powerful and drinkable, the dream.

bottle shared by John, because it was on my wants list, what a sweet treat.. a woody boozy beer with lots caramel and sweetness imparted by the barrel, most notably brown sugar and vanilla.. really tasty.

375 mL bottle, vintage 2011.  Pours black with a small light tan head.  Rich chocolate and bourbon aroma, dark fruit, molasses, and soy hints.  Great flavor, again cocoa and bourbon, brown sugar, coffee and slight smoke, dark fruit.  Rich and smooth.

Pours a deep cola brown, almost no head. Nose is chocolate and dark fruit. Low carbonation, really nice balance of booze, roasted chocolate malt with some raisin mixed in there somewhere. Really nice sipping beer.

Bottle at Sorbon, June 2012.

Black with no head. Nice heavy aroma of licorice, some alcohol, bourbon, roasted malt, tobacco and raisin. The taste was heavy but pleasant to sip. Nice beer.

Trevlig sötaktig lakrits och tjära. Mycket god smak. Lagom tjockt. Mycket tjära och tobak. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This came from THE LOCAL BEER BAR in Eureka, CA.  I paid $17.99 but it was one I had to try.   The 375 ml bottle poured very dark brown color with ruby hightlights on the edges. A good sized tan head accompanied it but that didnt last long, and left light lacing. The nose is dark roasted malt, bourbon, ripe plums, and  anise. Very rich in body, the mouthfeel is like vintage port wine. The flavor is complex, with bourbon, oak wood, raisins,  coffee, ripe plums,  and more.  There is some bitterness in the finish. This is a sipper and I took a long time to finish it. A remarkable beer.  Loved every drop.

Finally get to rate one of my favorite beers. Viscosity is right. Pours thick as hell. Like oil into an oil pan. No head just light carbonation in the form of little bubbles fighting to get through the thickness. Nose is a booze bomb. But not in a bad way. In a way I love. Rich vanilla and wood ethers dominate the pallet. Rich dark fruits mix in as well with very small hints of chocolate and coffee. Taste is sweet. Extremely sweet. You can tell they hopped it though because the bitterness comes through on finish. Mostly sweet though. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy. Soft on the pallet yet extremely heavy body with an aftertaste that doesn't quit. Amazing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with no head. Smell is strong tobacco, licorice, bourbon. Taste is hot alcohol, smokey, thick. Very good.

Pretty poor version of the style. Pours a very thin, opaque brown/black with opaque, red edges. No head at all, and little to no lacing. There is a bit of a slick coating to the glass, but not much. The bubbles are more reminiscent of fizzy beer than something like you would expect from this. The aroma is that of a sorry attempt at Goose Islands BCBS. It is too hot, and the wood is just overpowering. It is boozy, but boozy for booziness sake. Nothing really nice about the boozy aroma, either. The flavor saves this one, as it is pretty nice, but even for the style, an 8 from me is pretty weak. It was, again, a poor, out-of-balance version of what BCBS offers you. Not a fan, certainly not for $16.

Poured into my bruery tulip. No head and no lacing blacker than old viscosity. Aroma is bourbon, a very woody bourbon. Too much wood for my liking. Taste follows the nose, I like the bourbon but the oak Is too much. I love bourbon barrel beers but this one isnt my favorite. Mouthfeel isnt bad, neither is the carbonation. Its a good beer just not great, Ill stick with old viscosity.
Black full-bodied beer with a medium size foam. Fine dark roasted flavor. Extremely full-bodied with lots of alcohol, licorice, vanilla, whiskey.

Pours pitch black, no head, light tan ring around the glass. Aroma is boozy, sweet, with notes of molasses, butterscotch, coconut, and definitely some oak. Flavor is the same; boozy and sweet. Mouthfeel is viscous and thick, but theres no carbonation at all. Overall, very tasty brew. The barrel aging is present, but not overpowering. Definitely a slow sipper! Drinks more like an aged port wine. What it lacks in mouthfeel, it makes up for in flavor. Great tasting brew; probably wont seek it out again, but Id never turn it down!

Bottle grey import via Platinum cellars NSW
Heavy and slighly oaky and bourbony nose, with palate of tasty birght oak surrounded by sweet yet drips chocolatly and dark malt flavours.
the best Bourbon BA beer I have had yet

375 ml bottle.
Rated on 20110624.
Pours pitch black color with absolutely no head at all. No noticeable viscosity on the pour. Aroma of light oak, lots and lots of liquorice, roasted malts and ash dry dark chocolate. Flavor of bitter dry dark chocolate, smooth toasted malts, liquorice, sugary sweet syrup and some soy notes. Very slick and oily palate with a strong body. Very complex yet balanced brew. Excellent.
4426

5th July 2009Opaque black stout. Light palate, dry and a little soft. The barrelling dominates. Dry wood and the barest hint of vanilla. Sourish tangy dark malt. Warming dry finish. Nice enough but a little too wood dominated.

Bottle. Pours pitch black, with an airy head, a genuinely oily body and no carbonation. The aroma is everything youd expect it to be from such a dark monster, with a lightly smoked malty notes, oak barrels, tobacco, liquorice, vanilla, sweet dark fruits and syrup. Flavour almost follows suit, with licuorice and sweet coffee. This is a splendid brew, but a tad on the sweet side to be among the very best.

37,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 24.06.2011
Aroma is rather nice with vanilla, bourbon and some roasted malt. Flavour has bourbon, vanilla, roastiness and hints of coffee. Palate is rather low on CO2 and surprisingly thin for this style. The barrell has been good for this beer; The Old Viscosity was just another strong ale but this one is a masterpiece.

Nothing to say in particular.. I mean... it costs a lot but when you feel the smell into your blood and sloly drink this aged nectar you will be so excited and enticed to drink another one. This is something special. If you find a brasserie or a beer shop with this particular product: First spend your money to buy this and second, congratulate the seller because its a signal of competence, knowledge and passion if he knows this beer.... what Im saying? beer? I should say a MILESTONE

This is the only beer in my experience that comes close to the fullness and intensely luscious aroma of G.I. Bourbon County Stout.  Aroma is rounded out green oak with rum and bourbon depth and sweetness, along with a backdrop of soy sauce and yeasty sweet chili sauce.  The flavor is more subdued most of the way with the malts dominating in a melange of balanced earthy, sweet, smokey goodness.  The finish is purely of the barrel with a singed distilled spirit, alcoholic note drying out the experience but leaving a beautiful lip smacking residue.  The body is the lightest thing about the beer and may make it more approachable for some.  There is a slickness to the mouthfeel that reinforces the richness of the experience.  Excellent.  Thank you Port Brewing.  2012 small bottle.

Bottle shared by madtowndmb1...thanks Kyle! - Pours black with a thin foamy brown head. Nose is chocolate and molasses, with big dark breadiness and a touch of booze. Its sweet, with brown sugar notes. Taste is big roasty/sweet, with a bit of charcoal, milkiness, bourbon. Its smooth and sweet, with lots of molasses and brown sugar. Excellent warming heat on the finish. Its a sipper for sure, and the sweetness is a bit much, but overall its still pleasant, and the 12% is hidden well. A bit thin overall, though the carbonation is soft. Not my style per se, but it was an enjoyable sample.

2009 vintage 
Head: absolutly nothing ! , lacing tough 
Colour: very dark brown to black 
Smell: bourbon, vanilla, bit of banana, oats,sweet, candy sirup/burnt caramel, bit of salty roasted peanuts, lots of oak, super nice ! 
Taste: start is bitter sweet chocolat, notes of chocolat chip cookies, bit of roastyness, touch of candy sirup with a bit of boozey mouthdrying spiceyness, then some vanilla ,the end is dry because of the slight boozeyness with a tiny bit of grassy flavours , but those are so subtle they are easly seen over.
This is without a doubt a beautifful beer , is it only this vintage ? or the aging on it i dont know theres just nothing to overdone or underdone everything is perfectly balanced nothing too alcoholic or too sweet or sour or .... just utterly awesome ! and i cant do anything about my judgement on this beer .... and really why should i ? i love it !!
UPDATED: APR 24, 2012 Bottle and draught @ Port Brewing. Motor oil pour, deep dark brown no head. Oak, bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts. Oily, thick, smooth mouthfeel.

From Christmas Time 11, at an undisclosed location. 

Sometimes we have to make choices in life. Temptations. Decisions. Or just plain going with gut feelings. And I figure I am alive, well, and for the most part happy, so I guess my batting average is okay, but Ive oft made the wrong decisions. The ability to drink this beer was a product of some decision that in hindsight, I am not be proud of. I am not talking anything illegal here. Just, err, unethical. Or perhaps bad karma. Not guilt, maybe regret.The funny thing about regret...it is better to regret something you have done, than something you havent done....

Which leads me to Older Viscosity. The pour was most memorable for me. Thick. Real thick, motor oil blackness with the thinnest brown head. The smell was all booze. But a real nice bourbony booze. However, it was impressively smooth, almost smokey to the taste. A little bit of chocolate/vanilla perhaps, a lot a bit of malt. No major carbonation of note, just that pure dark oily goodness. 

So, I regret nothing. However, I owe the beer gods and karma some due.

Pour opaque black, with no head at all. 
Aroma of vanilla, bitter choco, bourbon, oak, toffee, Dark fruits, soy sauce, ocean, seaweed. Simply the lots. 
Taste is quite sweet. 
Oily and thick body, with a semi-flat carb. I dig it.

Bottle. Pours a clear copper with small off white head. The aroma is oak and roasted malt. Thin mouthfeel with vanilla and oak flavor. Alcohol present but not overpowering making it easy to drink. A very good American strong ale from Port Brewing.

Pours a thick black with a touch of tan head. Nose and taste are very clean & balance. The BA is a nice subtle addition and not over powering at all. STUPID expensive at $20 for a 350, but Im glad I got to try it.

Shared bottle poured into a snifter at Jackie-Os. Appearance is a nice translucent, dark amber with a medium beige head of foam. Nice retention for what this is. Aroma is huge caramels and toffee with notes of barrel thrown in there. Taste is pushing too sweet and malty, but doesnt quite make it there. Very enjoyable beer. One to sip on for awhile. Thank you for sharing.

2011 bottle. Pours opaque black with thin tan head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, roasted malt, brown sugar, molasses, and faint smoke. Flavor is heavy malt with supporting dark fruit esters; dry, sweet finish. Full body, low carbonation, and medium warmth.
Dark brown pour with a light tan head.   Fruity roasty aroma with notes of berries and vanilla.   Flavor of Bourbon, vanilla, and oak.   Roasty and dry.   Pretty smooth and easy to drink.

Bottle.  Courtesy of Pat.  Poured dark and viscus.  Virtually no head.  Nose of raisin and mild bourbon and butter. The taste of chocolate and bourbon sticks with you.  Very thick mouthfeel.  Delicious

Dark, dark, dark.   Dark fruit, dark chocolate, dark caramel and quite yummy.   12.5 ABV and not a hint of the alcohol.     Nice thick mouthfeel and not much bitterness.   One of the best beers Ive had.

Dark brown body, small off white head. Amazing strong aroma with sour cherries, licorice, whiskey, wood, honey. Smooth, ideally carbonated palate with an alcoholic burn. Amazing complex flavour with burned malts, wood, whiskey, vanilla, some dark chocolate. Every bit as great as the original.

A - Pours a dark black with just a touch of brown with a thin layer of chocolate head. The head fades down very quickly leaving behind very little lace.

S - Aroma is full of bourbon with oak and vanilla with roasted chocolate and some booze coming through and a bit of coffee.

T - Starts off with some Bourbon with lots of oak and vanilla with some roasted chocolate malts. Through the middle some coffee flavor comes through with some more Bourbon and milk chocolate. The finish is a mix of roasted chocolate malts, Bourbon, light coffee, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with very mild carbonation. Smooth with a warming and slightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. The bourbon really adds a great element to the beer and compliments the chocolate malts nicely.

Traded 2011 bottle. I was a little worried when the cork limped out of the bottle but everything turned out okay. This beer was solid all around and fun to drink...slowly. Well made and not too overdone.

The nose is a touch of boozey bourbon with some red fruits and caramel/chocolate malts. Poured black with little head. Flavors are similar with some vanilla and caramel and a helping of fruity esters. Nice and drinkable.

On tap @ Hunahpus day. The aroma was fantastic, like cherry coke next to a vanilla scented pencil. The taste was rich bourbon and sweet malts before a spicy and rich caramel finish. At 12% abv I could drink this stuff all day and die happily. I didnt though.

2 march 2012, bottle. Lightly toasted vanilla syrup. Lovely. Heavy body, syrupy, and mostly flat. Syrupy vanilla and milk chocolate and some oval tune. Lovely! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of prune, molasses and chocolate.  Pours black with very little lacing and no head.  Taste is toffee, slight mocha and dark fruits.  Very intense but a great heath bar aftertaste.  Love it.

Pours black with a tan head that sticks around for the duration. Pretty nice for a 12% abv beer. Nice melange of bourbon and barrel aromas with enough malt in the background to hold its own. This isnt a hit you over the head beer- the aromas and flavors are remarkably well integrated, and it is remarkably well mannered for the high abv. Lovely balance of barrel notes of vanilla, whiskey, tannic oak; stout notes of some roasty bitterness, a touch of espresso, and nice stiff malt.

The pour lives up to the name, jet black with a tiny tan ring left behind. Nose is bourbon from the second it is uncorked, with a few other malty flavors on the backside like chocolate, but mainly bourbon. Taste is much more round, the bourbon is almost not present. There are a good number of other contributors  to flavor, mainly a strong vanilla like note, more likely from the oak barrel.

2010 bottle with a mild pop on the cork , beige head present but recedes quickly, black ass stout so black its shiny. I can smell this all night sweet chocolate coconut  desert, taste follows the nose but a dry sweetness with hints of vanilla and bourbon added to the mix very smooth and delicious, mild alcohol burn on the back end but very well hidden for 12%.  This is one of my favorite beers.

Black pour with small dark tan head. Aroma of chocolate milk, caramel, boubon, ripe fruit. Taste of chocolate, cocoa, caramel, molasses and bourbon. What a complex beer. Nice carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. Hints of coconut on the aroma as well. Awesome beer!!

Good times when you have your pick of 2010 or 2011 older on tap...Beer Revolution in Oakland.  Went with the 2010.  This was fantastic.  As thick as expected with great fully burnt to a crisp malt taste.  The barrel stays in the back and adds to the wonderful flavors...maybe there is just so much flavor in the malt that it can compete.  The malt has a very unique flavor, who knows what step/ingredient it came from, but it is awesome.  This sticks and coats to your mouth but the malt flavor is so good, that gets it a perfect score for palate.  Impressive stuff.
0.375l - 2011 Bottling, pours viscous black, nose is coconut, yeast, plum & booze.  Palate is similarly layered, no burn or dominant note.  Unbelievably good.

Older pours black.  You arent seeing through this baby.  Like I said, its flat.  Small and I mean small amount of bubbles are formed and quickly disappear.  You looking for a head on this beer?  Well there is none.  There is a small amount of very dark tan lacing.  Hey but you know what?  I said there was a silver lining.  A light at the end of the tunnel.  This beer was frigging fantastic.  Could of it been better with carbonation?  Hell yes.  This beer could of been amazing.  But you see the smell and taste this beer gives off still knocked my socks off.  As soon as you pour this beer you are blasted by the aroma. Bourbon, oak, chocolate, roasted malt, and vanilla just attack the nose.  Its huge and I just wanted to sit there and take it all in.  As you drink this beer you feel a warm sensation throughout.  The taste is big just like the smell.  It took me a good 1 1/2 hours to finish my glass.  Its a sipper.  Straight up boozy,  Bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, molasses, and dark fruits.  Amazing.  Mouthfeel as you would of guessed it is a little bit lacking.  No carbonation.  Dead.  But its not all bad.  Its smooth and a little bit on the heavy side.

Bottle, 2010 vintage, 02/09/2012.  Pours coffee black, thinnest of mocha heads that quickly dissipates.  Incredible aroma, powdered dark chocolate with intense vanilla, dates, brown sugar, coffee roast and bourbon finish.  Taste follows suit, with big vanilla, dried fruits, caramel,  sweet bourbon finish, alcohol not noticeable.  Rich palate, soft and smooth, but full despite the lower carbonation level here.  Overall, undeniably excellent brew, can match up with the best.
jet black with minimal head low carbonation great aroma notes of bourbon raisin caramel chocolate to name a few smooth on the palate very nice!

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2012 Bottle (375ml) vintage 09 (the amazing one) @ Brasserie 4:20. Motor oil (not a big "viscosity" i dare say) black color with brown reflexes, no head at all. strong aroma of Bourbon, booze, oak, dark fruits, figs, A LOT of vanilla. Taste of bourbon, booze, wood, wet oak, bitter chocolate, and again, MUCH MUCH vanilla. Boozy, vanilla, bitter chocolate finish. The body is not thick as you could expect, the mouth feel is medium and the texture is quite liquid and flat. Not a complex beer, but very very strong, straight and intense. Honestly i had hard times trying to finish it, it warms a lot. The bourbon side prevails above all and the too much vanilla results cloying. maybe the too intense barrel aging (and the years) took too much beer away. Its funny that it absolutely taste similar to a barrique red wine like the taurasi. To summarize: Is it worth the cost? no,it isnt. Should i suggest you to drink it? Yes, absolutely, a great intense experience. share it with 2 or 3 other beer geek (this stuff is their territory) and all will be ok. 

EDIT 13-02-2012
I had another sip from a different bottle, same vintage: more bitter chocolate, cocoa beans/peels; less bourbon and vanilla.

Pours dark with no head
Aromas totally explides with figs dades brown sugar raisin chocolate and coffee
Palate is creamy mild and subtle but ends quite sparky and bitter. Taste almost to perfection. A very very good imperial stout

Bottle, courtesy of Alex from 4:20 yet again, thanks for sharing another excellent beer mate. Black as crude oil, very thin tan head. Aroma is sexy chocolate, big buttery bourbon rise up. Flavour has vanilla and caramel, chocolate, more bourbon and alcohol, barrel notes. Long and large finish with some nice alcohol burn. Yummy.

This was almost impossible to uncork! Pours black with almost no head. Smells like oaky bourbon and a bit of vanilla. Implied sweetness. Taste is sweet slightly doughy malt and heavy oakiness, with the boozy bite of bourbon. Im into it. Gotta sip because of that bourbon bite, but I have the patience. Tastes pretty much like Im drinking whiskey.

(bottle).   Aroma of vanilla and bourbon comes through.  No head whatsoever. The flavor is intense with vanilla, roasted malt, bourbon and alcohol. Warming  palate.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very black with virtually no head or lacing.  Smell is heavily roasty and burnt malts, coffee, chocolate, bourbon, and a little vanilla.  Taste is really nice, plenty of sweet vanilla, nice roasty and burnt malts, lovely bourbon notes, dark fruits like plums and figs, and a little brown sugar and molasses.  Body is full and despite the fact it didnt look like much, had ample carbonation. Finish is sweet at first, then bitter from the burnt malts, then finally coating the tongue with vanilla. Really nice.  Very complex and very delicious, a real nice double.

I like the dark color, but there was absolutely no head when I opoured it into my Trappist glass. Aroma is intense of oak and vanilla. Alcohol def shows in this one, but you dont focus on tht with all the Bourbon barrel heaviness that comes through. Not sure if Ive had a bourbon barrel American strong ale, usually imperial stouts, but they are similar and I really this style and need to reflect it in the rating.

Bottle. Pours black with no head, but with leaves impressive legs on the glass. Aroma of vanilla, oak, prunes, licorice, chocolate, light roast. Taste is lightly roasty, big vanilla/oak, espresso. Palate is flat, oily, slick, rich vanilla finish.

Bottle from a while back. This is the thickest and blackest beer Ive ever tasted. Pours like used motor oil and smells of coffee/chocolate, vanilla, and Bourbon. This beer was freakin amazing! Right up my alley.

12.7 ounce bottle (thanks Zak!). Pours like motor oil, as advertised; probably the blacest beer Ive ever seen, with a thin tan head. Aromas of choclate, vanilla, bourbon and caramel. Faloors of choclate, coffe and vanilla with a really nice bourbon flavor that doesnt overpower the other flavors in the beer; very nice.

12.7oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours near black with a thin, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of strong bourbon, roasted caramel and chocolate malts, some vanilla and oak, plus some floral malts.  Flavor very strong of bourbon, plus some sweet malts and alcohol.  Thick texture.  An incredible beer.

Bottle 2008. Very dark, with good sized long lasting beige head. Aroma is malty, chocolate, vanilla, liquorice, dark fruits.... Same impressive complex mix of flavours, plus some smokeyness, sweetness and a bitter finish. Nice rich mouthfeel. Excellent.
Bottle. Black with dissipating tan head. Dark chocolate and caramel nose. More of the same in the flavour with a smooth vanilla finish. Excellent.
Bottle. Diesel black with rapidly dissipating tan head. Nose is fantastic. Such a defined caramel. On the flavour caramel is doused with alcohol. Vanilla and mild bourbon. Such an impressive beer.

2008 bottle given by cquiroga 2 years and a half ago. Thanks. This is one pleasantly complex massive brew and that complexity is fortunate as its also extremely sweet. Screaming cocoa/vanilla fumes as soon as the bottle is opened, it would feel as much like pina colada than bourbon were it not for the generous alcohol splash and smokey earthiness. Chocolate dessert like rich palate sprayed by sparse carbonation. The alcohol grows tougher as it warms up, the strong bitterness from a younger and unaged Old Viscosity becoming something to long for more and more. Impressive how the 3 years of age and barrel-aging have not thinned out the huge body some more. Also impressive is the large tan head that remains a crowning achievement throughout the tasting. Not the type of beer I love these days, but a fun sipper nonetheless, albeit not subtle.

Pours pitch black with a medium mocha head that disappears quickly.  Awesome bourbon/vanilla aroma...also a bit of sweet nuttiness...like candied pecans.  Flavor follows suit and adds some dark fruit....fig...mildly winey and warming.  Mouthfeel is fairly heavy and the finish is roasty and boozy.

Bottle at Håndverkerstuene. 
Black color with low beige head. 
Strong malty aroma with coffee, herbs and bourbon. 
Complex dry taste with all of the above, a little more coffee, spices, this one has got it all.Feels thick and powerful. Finish is just super, with a lasting woody taste.

2009 bottle BIG thanks to grownfool. Aroma is pure bliss bourbon chocolate vanilla and some faint dark fruit. Pours dirty motor oil with a faint wispy head that disappears. Taste is more bourbon and vanilla with a dark fruit and chocolate that makes you all warm inside. Palate is full and slick with a dry warm finish. Awesome, this is one of the best Ive had!

Bottle thanks to grownfool!  Dark oily black pour, no carbonation and a rick chocolately boozy vanilla nose.  Flavor is more rich silky dark chocolate, sweet vanilla, noticeable wood and mellow bourbon throughout.  Just a stellar beer and very well hidden alcohol at 12%

Bottle. Pours black with a tan head.
Smells simply amazing. Red berries, and candy sugar with strong maltiness. Tastes of heavy sweet malt, dried fruit, and goodness. Full bodied. Medium carbonation. Oily texture. Finishes sweet but dry.

On tap at The Bavarian Lodge. Pours a deep brown, almost black colored body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is excellent with big bourbon, dark fruits, and sweet malts with caramel and chocolate. A nice mix of woody vanilla, roasts, and a touch of molasses and raisin bread. Flavor is similarly superb. Lots of smooth malts up front with a bigger chocolate and some caramel and molasses. Big bourbon and raisin with a really nice woody vanilla. More chocolate and a nice roast come out at the end with a very solid mix of sweet malts and bourbon. Smooth, rich, and somewhat dry from the wood and roasts before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Full, smooth, extremely soft body with a creamy, soft, light-medium carbonation. Overall, an excellent beer that immediately jumps to one of my all-time favorites. Wonderful integration with the sweet malts, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla oak, roasts, and dark fruits. Huge fan of this one.

On  tap at the Firkin.  Pours inky black with a small head. Aroma has vanilla and rum raisin. Later some woodiness ... and bourbon. Taste brings a lot of chocolate, super smooth, with a lot of sweetness, some vanilla some wood.  Finishes with a choco/peppermint tinge of some length. Alcohol not as pronounced as in the nose. Very nice one!

Brassin 2010. Bouteille de 12.7 oz, avec bouchon de liège, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de bourbon et de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Saveur: Goût de bourbon avec une pointe de chocolat et dalcool. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de chocolat en arrière goût. (Rating #4031)

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass dark, almost black, small head. Starts intense malty, modest alcoholic, warming. Fine notes of earth, woody, not too dry. Well balanced and warming finish, modest bitter. Wonderful!

375 ml caged and corked bottle.  Im not sure what vintage this is because the printing on the label is smudged, but I think it looks like its either a 2010 or 2011 bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with a small tan head that fizzled away quickly.  Theres a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is sweet and boozy, it smells like dark fruit, caramel, bourbon, vanilla, and some chocolate.  I think the taste is the same as the aroma, and all the flavors mesh well and none of them overpower the other ones.  This beer is definitely one of the sweeter ones Ive had lately.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its oily and coating with a moderate level of carbonation.  At $16.99 a bottle I wouldnt buy it very often, but I think its a very good brew.

Poured from bottle to snifter. Pours a dark, dark brown, almost black, with minimal head leaving no lacing. Noise is bourbon up front, with roasty caramel. Taste is sweet sweet bourbon with a lots of heat. On the palate its smooth and thick. Absolutely fantastic. Highly recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 15/11/2011 375ml bottle @ Klaas place - bottled: ? (smudged ink)  (2011-645) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Very dark brown to black beer, very small beige head, bit stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: whiskey, alcohol, vanilla sweetness, caramel. MF: low carbon, full body, creamy texture with alcohol warming the throat. Taste: chocolate fest! Also caramel, lots of vanilla, slightly sweet but not at all cloying. Aftertaste: more vanilla and caramel. Oh boy, this is great stuff. Food pairing wise Im thinking a creamy hazelnut and mocha cheese cake.

Pours black with barely more than absolutely no visible carbonation. Lots of malty, chocolatey, toffee-ey aromas along with wood, some soy, molasses, milk, leather, leaves, spiced raisin bread, almond, light char, light citrus. The bourbon is not insane and in your face like a lot of other bourbon beers where it seems like they are just pouring bourbon into the beer.  When I poured it, there was no head at all, but if I swirl it, I get a nice dense creamy brown head that fades back to a small ring and island in not much time. The taste is incredible. I cant believe the bourbon is so mellow and not overpowering, yet, along with the malty richness, it is the main focus. The texture is incredibly soft and smooth with just a little bite of alcohol. The carbonation is low but still enough to really drive some flavor into the tongue. Amidst all of the bourbon and silky sweet malt, there is just enough hop character to add the delicate balance that is needed. This is the best bourbon beer Ive ever had. I was really expecting something just over the top insane, but this is smooth, delicate and delicious. And this is this years vintage. I can only imagine how this develops 2-4 years down the road.

2010 bottle.  Amazing black coffee look with dark tan head.  Aromas are huge and potent, loads of sharp coffee, cocoa, vanilla, boozy bourbon.  Palate follows with decent carbonation, very big coffee hit, medium roast, bourbon is big on the finish.  Really well put together offering from port, honestly one of the better bourbon strong ales Ive had although Id akin it to an RIS.  Would age really do much to this?  Id say the rough edges the coffee output might get smoothed out, but already drinking great.

I was disappointed with the Old Viscosity so I had to take it to the next level; this time I was impressed. The color is dark brown. There was a thin tan head that disappeared quickly. On the nose I got bourbon, chocolate syrup, cherry, leather and dark fruits. Medium body, just perfect. On the palate: Bourbon, chocolate, vanilla notes, alcohol, a little bit of nice roasted malt, very complex. Awesome beer.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 Pours nearly pitch black. Quickly fading foam. Smells heavily of bourbon with some roasted malts in the back. Taste is dominated by the bourbon, but there is also some nice coffee and chocolate notes and a tinge of booze. A nice beer, especially if you like bourbon.

Absolutely amazing aroma and flavor.  Dark espresso (Italian roast), chocolate, whiskey, sherry, port, roasted caramel.  A hint of some fruitiness (banana) underneath.  Lightly carbonated.  Thick black color with no head.    This is an excellent beer!

Bottle from 2011.  Pretty awesome aroma of maple, pecan, oak, vanilla, brown sugar, toffee and slight whiskey.  Deep, dark brown color, with a fine, lasting, light tan head.  Flavor is comprised of huge, sweet malts, roast, oak, char, dark, nearly burnt sugars, golden raisin, faint chocolate, vanilla and a rush of alcohol at the finish, along with some lingering coffee tones.  Smooth, full, thick mouthfeel, body is immense.  I liked this quite a bit.  Cheers to Amy and John for sharing!

12.7 oz bottle. Pours a motor oil thick blackness with absolutely no head. The aroma is one of the most intense Ive ever smelled before. Tons of bourbon in the nose and a fair bit of alcohol too. Tastes of bourbon, chocolate, some coffee, roasted malt, woodiness, licorice, nuts, and alcohol. Powerful tastes that was much more complex than the smell. Very impressive beer, but not for the faint at heart (Ive had imp stouts weaker than this).

375ml brown corked and caged bottle. It has a suspect cage on it. No date, but it has been aging for a bit, maybe over a year, I dont remember.

It pours a dark black with a super fizzy tan head that quickly dissipates.

The smell has a lot of bourbon and alot of raisin. Alcohol prickles the nose. There is some vanilla and oak in there as well. Very much barrel-dominated, almost no stout notes.

The mouthfeel is thinner than I would have expected and I think it works. The flavor is again barrel dominated. Lots of dark fruit, caramel, and sweetness. Just a hint of cocoa. Reminds me of Darkness with a giant addition of bourbon. It is pretty smooth despite the abv, that could be because of aging.

If you want the barrel flavors to dominate and you like a rich dark fruit sweetness to go with the bourbon this is for you.
