(Bottle 25/10-2011) Very low dark brown head, almost black color, alcohol aroma, extremely well balanced, roasted chocolate vanilla taste mixed with bourbon. Very good!

Almost black with a small dark brown head. Aroma is very sweet malty, roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Flavor is very sweet and very bitter. Sweet and rather bitter finish with warming alcohol. 251011

Pours from the bottle a deep black color with a very thin, deep brown head. Aroma has a lot of bourbon in the nose. A woody note comes through in the middle with a lot of toasted malt. A very light dark fruit sweetness, prune and raisin,  comes in at the tail end to take some of the edge off of the bourbon alcoholic note.  Nose has an overall Merlot wine-like nose to it. Flavor starts off with a very smooth light roasted malt bitterness combined with a light chocolate presence. This transitions to a  mildly sweet prune middle with the start of the bourbon flavor. A strong bourbon and woody flavor comes in late in the tasting and fades away for a while after the sip. The body perfectly compliments the beers flavors, allowing for enough density to make the flavors pop. Carbonation is very fine and adds a slight sharpness to the finish of the beer. Overall one of the best beers I have had in a long while. The flavors are very distinguishable in the beer with great separation that provides the ability to enjoy each one as they arise. Fantastic brew well worth the price.
A completely black beer and a brown head. Mildly sweet aroma and taste of chocolate, but also liquorice. Finish becomes bitter. (Bottle)

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 375cl 2009 Vintage bottle @ Euston Tap, London, shared with MesandSim. Pitch black, opaque color, small beige head. Smell rum, roastyness, coffee, lightly burned, slightly smokey notes and some dark chocolate. Taste wood, alcohol, dark chocolate, roastyness and slightly coffee. Very round taste, perfect balance. Oily texture, alcohol soft but present. Medium carbonation, medium to full body; suits the beer perfectly. Absolutely love this!
Bottle bought from beermerchants.com. Dark black body and no head. Boozy aroma, really hit by the bourbon. Dark chocolate flavours with dark fruits. Very dark basically and rather nice.

Sample at SBWF 2011. Bottle. Clear, dark brown liquid with very small, lightly tan head. Aroma of booze, toffee, vanilla, caramel, chocolate, oak and coconut. Taste is medium sweet and lightly bitter with notes of chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Very smooth and balanced. Full bodied with low carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Nice brew, very balanced taste but a bit boozy aroma.

corked and caged bottle, Im pretty sure it has about 2 years on it.  Anyway, got excited for this one after seeing people complain about too much bourbon - I love bourbon barrel aged beers and dont mind a strong influence.  Black pour with tan head.  Aroma of rich, dark chocolate, plenty of oak, bourbon, almost a funky prune / date aroma, licorice.  Flavor is good, although more chocolate / oak and less bourbon than I expected.  Has a very long finish, with rich, soily notes, chocolate cake, prune.  Bourbon certainly contributes but doesnt wholly characterize the flavor profile here.  Very smooth, nice palate for 12%.  Overall very nice beer.

Corked and caged 375 from binnys downtown chicago. Pours a deep brown with a thin tan head, and rich aromas of brown sugar, molasses, caramel burnt sugars and bourbony booze with little to no hops character. Fully sweet and rich, oak and vanilla notes from its time in the barrel. Excellent beer, would go nicely with ice cream or on pancakes!
Nose is wood chip, toffee, mellow and broad alcohol, cane sugar, sweet licorice, feel is wine, carb is very low, taste is cough syrup, weak vanilla, decent sour notes, some meat later, licorice.

Bottle - Wow!!! This is just a great beer that is worth the money. Lots of bourbon in the nose. The taste is so smooth. It was hard taking my time drinking it, because I really didnt want to stop. My only issue was that it didnt coat my glass like I thought a beer called older viscosity would do. But you would be an idiot to pass this beer because of that.

Sampled at an StLHops Pinball event.  Had a sip of Old Viscosity just before this sample.  This was quite dark and smelled of dark complex fruit and the barrel aging effects.  The flavor was very nice with that fruit, wood, bourbon, chocolate and so much more.  I only had a few ounces and that was enough to know that it wasnt nearly enough.

I probably shouldnt rate this since I havent had the old viscosity yet, but funk dat. The aroma is very boozy, coconut rum and bourbon mostly, but there is also a bit of caramel. I guess there was a little something extra in those barrels (apologizes to Lagunitas) Black,  medium fizzy brown head with absolutely no retention, no adherence to the glass. Full body and boozy, but neither thick nor viscous as the name implies. Licorice and date flavor, some chocolate notes. Bourbon appears at midpalate and hangs around for a very long time. I bet the base beer was great before the barrel aging ruined it,, my opinion only.  Well crafted for the booze hounds.

Bottle from mixmasterrob.  Absolutely tremendous beer.  Pours a smooth/rich dark brown and the aroma is wonderful and not too over powering.  Couldnt ask for much more from a Bourbon Barrel Strong Ale
Caramel and chocolate aromas. Pours dark with a small white head. Flavors of toffee, chocolate and nuts.  Overall a great strong ale

Rich black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, rich vanilla, bourbon, & some dark fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, oak, molasses, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, and some licorice; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, bourbon, bourbon, and more bourbon - delicious.

Pours black as night with a thin brown head that has good retention. Aroma is bourbon, roast, chocolate truffle, vanilla, burnt sugar, a touch of leather tanning, old leaves and dusty dry straw. Flavor is big on sweet chocolate and brown sugar up front, nice vanilla-laden bourbon barrel, some over toasted coconut, licorice, oak, roast nuts, dark caramel and scotcheroo cookies. Palate is heavy bodied, lightly carbonated and creamy right up until the slightly drying, boozy finish. The palate suits the beer nicely, even the fairly strong alcohol burn fits. Delicious brew overall, complex and tasty, yet pretty easy going for 12%abv, despite the alcohol burn.

Draught at Beer Revolution. Black; flat. Aroma of oak, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, berries, cafe au lait. Flavor is cola, vanilla, whiskey, chocolate. Rich and flavorful, and very sweet. Rather clean, fruity, tangy finish. Old Visc. is better. Flavor is too dominated by the bourbon.

Black with disappearing tan head.  Nearly perfect bourbon nose, vanilla, light cocoa, some dark fruits.  All very much present, yet soft.  Velvety body with smooth cocoa, moderate bourbon, vanilla, marshmallow, light sweetness, and mild roast.  Smooth all the way.  A near masterpiece.
at the brewery with the bros for dallas bachelor party.  This was the icing on the cake.. In terms of me getting loaded.

Bottle at Lost Abbey w Andy, James and Dallas. Excellent beer with many similarities to Angels Share. Mily, smooth and chocolately, but a little stronger on the hops and more bitter which take away from the drinkability. Still absolutely awesome.

Aroma is full of bourbon and vanilla notes. It also has a hint of alcohol. The appearance is an inky black color with a hinty of brown around the edges of the glass. The beer pours with small brown bubbles of head that go away nearly instantly. The taste is very similar to the nose with a little more alcohol on the finish. The bourbon and vanilla are prominent flavors on the tongue. Great beer overall. It tastes like a more concentrated version of parabola

2010 bottle... Clear dark brown pour , non exisistent head or lace . Aroma of bourbon , oak and vanilla . The flavor is huge malt sweetness with the bourbon burn and some tannins from the oak . Mild acidic notes as well . Dry , roasted and bitter finish with a big alcohol burn . Also some salty licorice notes . Full bodied , thick and slick . Good but it needs to cool off . You had better like bourbon .

Strong whiff of warm alcohol as soon as the cork was popped. Pitch black - no light got through except along the bottom edge, where it was a dark reddish brown. No head. Taste was oak and bourbon with a vanilla finish. Very, very nice.

On tap @ Lost Abbey - 2010 vintage.
Near black pour with a small amount of tan head.  Tons of bourbon and oak aroma, vanilla, and alcohol.  Flavor of chocolate, more vanilla, and lots more bourbon.

Bottle at Brewdog Bar. Pours opaque black with no head. The nose has oaky tannins, liquorice and tar. The taste has more of the same, though the tannins are not so obvious. There is a big structure and a thick texture with a cloying finish, annoyingly. Overall, interesting beer but unbalanced!
Tap at brewdog. Black with small tan head. Whiff of alcohol on the aroma. Taste is delicious. Licorice, dark fruits, raisins, prunes. Sweet, alcohol well disguised

Move this one to Imperial Stout where it belongs.  This is a hugely bold and robust beer.  Thick and viscous body with aromas of bourbon, chocolate, ash, and vanilla.  Taste is boldly barrel aged with huge bourbon character and a backbone of roasted malt and chocolate.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 oak aged beer, great back beer behind the brew, a really big beer. The oaky vanilla notes are heavier than your typical bourbon aged stout. Not too much bourbon coming through, first stout that I have really enjoyed from these guys, well done LA
Bottle. Pours black with no head. Tons of oak in the aroma, vanilla, chocolate. Taste of oak, vanilla, licorice, dark malt, alcohol.

Pour thick oily black with minimal head. Aroma cola, oak, dark fruits, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, plums, raisins, cherries. Taste oak, wood, dark fruits, caramel, sweet, vanilla, cherries, raisins. MF slick cola like feel. Good beer not to my style preferences but well done. Thanks Mike!!!

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Pours pitch black with no head at all. Aroma of sweet bourbon and some light roasted malts.Taste is sleek and smooth, vanilla, oak, sweet roasted malts, light warm alcohol well incorporated. Full bodied. Good bourbon lingering all way to the end. Complex from start to finish, like a pandoras box, I want more of this elixir!

375 ml bottle @ Cardinal. Black body with a nice, thin, lasting beige head. Really strong and nice aroma of black malt, moderate roast, smooth, but distinct bourbon, oak, dark chocolate, roasted coffee and hint of peat. Flavor is pretty much what the aroma promises, balanced bitter, smooth oak and warming alcohol. Really fantastic flavor, its so strong and still delicious smooth and balanced. Fine full body with a long lasting aftertaste with hops, malt, wood and pleasant alcohol. Fantastic  a beer with a clear WOW factor.

Tap, Brick Store. Finger of dark tan head on a mahogany dark body. Lots of bourbon in the aroma with a slight sweetness and some slight earthiness. Very bourbon in the flavor with some sweet chocolate, dark cherry and vanilla...light roast.  Warming, slick and thick.

On tap at Local option. Very anticipated. Aroma: Intense bouron, anise, molasses, fresh coffee with a nice nutty twist. Appearance: Pitch black with a nice brownish ring. Flavor: Bourbon upfront along with some roasted malts and a semi-sweet chocolate finish and oak tannins. Light bodied for such a big brew but you can really feel the alcohol. Overpowering bourbon presence, especially in the taste. I prefer the regular Old Viscosity.

Rating #700, and beer #2 for my second anniversary on Ratebeer. 12.7 oz corked and caged bottle into snifter. Funny label depicting a guy under an old truck, emptying used motor oil into pint glasses. And thats what this looks like, completely impervious motor-oil black. Has no head but leaves a ring of dark tan foam. Smells like a bourbon barrel aged imperial stout. The oak and bourbon are quite pungent; also chocolate milk and some overripe fruit. This is without a doubt the most thick and syrupy beer Ive ever had. Holy freaking firkins, Batman. Taste is mostly sweet with a sour backbone. Tastes like a really rich, alcoholic and decadent liquid dessert. Its like drinking alcohol-laced Hersheys syrup straight from the can, only that sounds pretty nasty. This is delicious. Has a lingering aftertaste of licorice. Carbonation is very low, but thats okay. Im kind of hungover right now and didnt think this would go down too well today. I was wrong.

Pours dark brown and almost black. Nose is plums, raisins, grapes, cherries, and sweet malts, caramels, and woods. Flavor is similar. Thuggish and oily on the palate. Good. A little in the fruity vinous side for my likes but well made beer.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of multi-grain toast, marzipan, milk chocolate, over-ripe fruit, and booze barrel. A bit of charred oak barrel in the mouth along with notes of booze, chocolate, and dark caramel. In spite of its malty heft, theres some woody astringency on the palate. Tastes better than it smells. Average.
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Scura, intenso aroma di fruttato, alcol devastante e una bella dose di luppolo. Birra della madonna, complessa e unica nel suo genere.

2011 Vintage purchased at Hop City Craft Beer in Atlanta, June 2011. This is one HUGE beer, definitely a sipping beer. Bourbon really dominates the smell and taste, hints of vanilla, oak, coffee, chocolate. Alchohol is fairly well hidden, Id love to taste a bottle that had some age on it. Great brew, very unique, a real gem.

On tap at the brewery.  Dark pour similar to Angels Share.  Tons of bourbon, vanilla, oak on the nose.  Taste follows the nose with lots of vanilla, bourbon, and toasted malt.  It tastes similar to a stout without any much of the coffee notes.  I enjoyed this more than Deliverance and very close to regular Angels Share.  Carbonation not a problem.

Bottle shared thx to Dunbar72 2011-07-09 Sätila
AR: butter, vinos, barley wine
AP: dark brownish, wee beige head
F: dark coffee (home-brewed), cognac barrel,vinos, vanilla

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2015 Bottle 37,5 cl, courtesy of Dunbar72. Pours pitch black with á small bubbly brown head. Aroma is sweet, sour, fruity, dried fruits, barrel and vanilla; excellent. Flavor is oily, alcohol, malty, dried fruits, vanilla, barrel, spicy, bitter and pungeant. A bit thin body. Finishes acidy fruity bitter.

Bottle 2010 vintage. What a cascade of sweet dark fruity boozy vanilla coconut chocolate licorice, so fullbodied. Flavor as fantastic as aroma. Enjoying every sip...

Bottle, thanks to Dunbar72. Black beer with no head. Whisky aroma, creamy, toffee and vanilla, roasted with chocolate and cocoa. Whisky flavor, sweetish, toffee, cream, some alcohol, chocolate and cocoa. Great body and with a pleasant roasted aroma.

375ml bottle.2011 vintage.Wow.Pours a black/brown with a thin brown head that laces the glass.Nose is mind blowing with notes of chocolate,raisin,bourbon and anise.Mouthfeel is silky smooth and creamy with tastes of coffee,chocolate,milk,oaky bourbon and dark fruit with NO EVIDENCE OF ABV!!! One of the all time beers.Smoking!

Bottle on 4th of July.
Pitch black with a cappuccino to light brown head leaving some lacing. Aroma: chocolate, sweet licorice, vanilla, toffee, some bourbon.
Taste: licorice, chocolate, liqueur, toffee, some salmiak, maybe bourbon.
Full-bodied, soft carbonation.
Great, packed with flavours, but very well balanced.

0.375l bottle @ Baran, Bergen shared with RuneStumo. The elder pours a beautiful pitch black body with a nice little lasting chocolate head. The aroma almost blows me away with fantastic bourbon, wood, mild vanilla and lots of dark chocolate and licorice. My god this is nice. It has a oily sticky mouthfeeling, quite full-bodied and softly carbonated. Tastes much what it smells just better. Lots of fantastic bourbon flavors, wood, chocolate, espresso, dark fruit and licorice. End really nice wit a little alco kick and it has a beautiful dark bourbon aftertaste. Glad to say that I have one more bottle of this fantastic brew in my cellar. Cant wait to try it again. Top notch all the way!

29.06.2011. Bottle shared with Palme. Baran cafe, Bergen. Black colour with tan head. Aroma is really rich with strong malts and lots of flavour. There is some very good malt sweetness and you can feel the strength of the alcohol coming through. Notes of bourbon whisky and some kind of roasted smoke. This is one very good beer!!

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2011 Appearance is jet black (but you can see the edges are a dark cola brown if you look closely) with a cocoa-colored 1 finger head.  Aroma is mainly bourbon whiskey with bold accompanying notes of chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Flavor is mainly whiskey, but nestled among the more apparent chocolate, coffee, and vanilla notes are sour barrel, salt, raisins, sherry, and warming ethanol. Body is very full, creamy, and bitter with low carbonation.  Overall, this is a perfect bourbon beer. It was the perfect knock-out punch I needed to bring my night to an end and I will be searching for a bottle to add to my cellar!
Plums, vanilla, chocolate, no carbonation. This was aged for over 2 years. Absolutely the best beer I have had from Port.

My rating may be skewed as this bottle was flat - sadly a casualty of travel from the west coast most likely.  Pours dark brown almost black with a lighter brown halo and no head of course, just a bubble or two. Aroma is incredible a perfect blend of milk chocolate, bourbon, vanillla, and brown sugar.  Taste is  similar chocolate and bourbon dominating but soft due to the age.  Palate thinner than expected and of course flat.  Sad that I didnt get to have it in true form - I can tell would be excellent.

12.7oz bottle, 2011 release.  Served at cellar temperature.
Pours dark brown to blackwith a one finger brown head that recedes to a wispy cap and ring, leaving only a few spots of lacing behind.  Also not as thick as I had thought it would be.

Aroma is an absolutely wonderful wave of bourbon, one of the better bourbon noses Ive encountered.  Also tagging along are notes of oak, rich chocolate, premium coffee, vanilla, anise, figs, plums, black currants and other dark fruits.  Excellent strength.

Flavor is again more tasty bourbon, well pronounced but doesnt overpower the chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, oak, vanilla, and a strong dark fruit component.  There is noticeable alcohol on the finish but within tolerance for a big bourbon barrel aged beer.  Very complex.

Mouthfeel is medium to high, creamy with low/medium carbonation.

Freaking fantastic.  One of the more bourbon-heavy beers Ive had but still integrates very well and doesnt completely take over the base beer.  Incredible aroma, one of those beers where Ill keep the last ounce in the glass for as long as I can so I can keep taking it in.  Rich and complex, a treat all around and worth the price tag IMHO.

On draft at Local Option in Chicago. This has to be one of the best beers Ive ever had on draft. The aroma was intense. Full of maple, rolled oats,bourbon, brown sugar and malts. Flavor wasnt over boozy and pretty easy to drink. ABV masked very well on this one. A real treat of a beer.

Wonderful aroma of malts with a nice oak and bourbon blanket to it.  Flavor is mostly roasted malts in the form of dark chocolate with some hints of coffee.  Smooth and soft with an alcohol bite and bitterness at the end.

bottle.  black with almost no head.  nose is fudge, caramel, barrel and raisin.  flavor is dark chocolate, sweet caramel, bourbon.  sweet which compliments the abv nicely.  i had this at tasting a few months back and couldnt wait for it to hit shelves!  as good as i remember it.  palate is medium and just a bit hot.  would love to cellar one of these.

375ml from IPB.
Appearance : Pitch black with small brown head. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Lots of bourbon with notes of vanilla. nice hops and roasted malt. Very rich. Some alcohol, nice chocolate.

Taste : Hops and roasted malt. Lots of bourbon.Great finish with nice bourbon, hops and roasted malt. Soft carbonation.

Overall : Nice bourbon, not too intense. A bit too warm and alcoholic though. Finish is really nice with great bourbon and hops. Nice balance between hops, bourbon and malt all around. Nice sutff but a bit too boozy for me.

Poured from a bottle dated 2009 into a Singha glass. Beer is black and forms almost no head, there is apparently no carbonation and no head. There were a few bubbles that were most likely the result of a rather violent pour that form some lacing. I guess Im an unlucky victim of an uncarbonated Older Viscosity / Lost Abbey SNAFU. Thanks. It will affect my review since THEY are the ones that fucked up.

Aroma is like bourbon. Very sweet, very boozy, smells like a lot of bourbon barrel aged beers. Smells good.

Beer is medium bodied, feels good in the mouth. Very strong from an alcohol point of view. Very sweet, some chocolate based bitterness. Overall its pretty smooth for this sort of beer. A nice blend all together.

Serving type: bottle

perfect beer!  lots of bourbon barrel smell and taste.  maintains a strong chocolate smoothness and a strong bitter bite of bourbon.  pretty good lacing for a stout of this age.  absolutely delicious beer.  9.5 now and 10 with a couple more years of aging on top of this.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 [Bottle]  Opaque reddish blak appearance, weak head retention. Big sweet red wine verging on bourbon nose,very sugarry with a big chunk of molasses, intensely fruity (prunes and cherries). Sweet but not overwhelming on the palate, thick in body and plenty of alcohol and vinuous notes. Bourbon comparisons definitely predominate, a little syruppy,cherry and sugar too. Some burnt alcohol and underwhelming citrussy hop in the finish provide some balance. A little too big for my taste but defintely creative.
Bottle shared at beer temple.  Dark brown pour with small dark head.  Oak and light chocolate aroma.  Flavor with vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate and oak.   Great beer

2011 vintage. 375 mL bottle at a tasting at Chris place, served in a snifter. Pours black with a moderate tan head. The head fades to a thin cover and leaves a small amount of lace. On the nose, there are notes of roast malts, oak, bourbon, herbs, molasses, along with nuts and a hint of bread. The flavour is quite sweet, with caramel and molasses, roasty notes and a touch of herbal hops. On the palate it is medium-full in body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an amazing imperial stout. It is complex and roasty with very nice oak notes. A new favourite for sure! 2011-05-22

Big thanks to John for bringing a growler of this goodness to last nights tasting/gathering. Easily the best beer of the night. Poured black with a dark head that never lasted long. The beer itself had enough carbonation so no big deal. Smelled of liquorish, dark malts, dark chocolate, port, sherry, bourbon, dark fruit, and some coffee. Tasting gave similar notes but with great lasting energy and balance. Great freaking beer. Really intense flavors. Would have stood up to anything. I really wanted a cigar with this beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 At small bar on Fullerton.  This is really great stuff. You can really taste and smell the oak and bourbon.  Slightly sour and some dried fruit flavors. Wine like in a way. Serving: Tap

2011 vintage. 375 mL bottle. Lost Abbey tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Black. Tinge of dark caramel brown. 
Head is 1-2 fingers, dark tan  like the foam on an espresso, and has lengthy retention. 

AROMA: Cocoa, milk chocolate, bourbon, vanilla. 
Hints of whiskey dipped figs, oak, coffee, mocha, faint allspice. 

TASTE: Massive bourbon notes. Chocolate malt, vanilla. 
Hints of oak, roasted barley, faint allspice, faint grassy hops. 
Light roasted barley contributes mild bitterness on finish. 

MOUTH FEEL: Lively carbonation  more than expected for the style/viscosity  helps reduce the viscous perception. Plentiful alcohol warmth. Slick mouth feel. 

OVERALL: Milk chocolate and bourbon extremely well balanced on nose  almost like a chocolate milk shake blended with a bit of bourbon. Bourbon is just a touch heavy on taste. Overall, amazing.

Bottle at 4:20. Brown, clearish pour with a slight, tan head. Heavy sweet, malty aroma, soy sauce, cocoa, dark fruits. Flavor isnt as sweet as I had expected, but still sweet, dark malts, some cocoa, caramel, burnt sugar. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Warm, almost hot finish, dark fruits, dry chocolate, some peat and hoisin. Great beer.

Tap @ Falling Rock, Denver. Pours allmost black with a small ring of foam along the glassside. Aroma of caramel, coffee, port, raisins. Taste is very malty, oak, caramel, coffee, dark dried fruit, port, light booze. Thin to medium body, low carbonation. Very good beer. 090411

2009 vintage. Black almost no head. Virtually no carbonation. There are plums and prunes in the aroma, but also peat, roasted malt, chocolate and oxidation, a la Port. Oaky and flat but very rich mouthfeel. Long aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2015 Pours opaque black. Aroma of coconut, motor oil, overripe fruits, bourbon, prunes, raisin and dates. Taste is sweet with borwn sugar, alcohol, overripe fruits, caramel and woody sourness. 

Re rate @ 2014. 

This was a way better experience. More complex and balanced. 
Lots of nice bourbon notes which contributes to the rather sweet nuances that this beer contains.
Bottle. Black with medium brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruit, vinous, bitter, coffee, vanilla and bourbon.

Thanks to Doug for the grand opportunity to try this!! .. black as night, and full as the ocean .. . bourbon, black tar heroin, melted asphalt and sweet coffee roast .. . wow! such an immense beer! ..why dont you put an egg in your shoe and beat it!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2011 Rerate: on tap at Lost Abbey brewpub. Very similar characteristics as the bottle but much smoother, creamier and better balanced; also more chocolate and roasted malts. 
375ml bottle from 2010. Pours a jet black, no head or lacing. Huge smell of delicious balanced bourbon, caramel, malts, and more bourbon. Sweet and bourbon on the palate, bit of alcohol (maybe a bit more age) and some hops on the finish - this is the only part that is lacking - would appreciate more complexity/depth but still a great beer.

Aroma:good bourbon,oak vanilla aroma,coconut...
Appearance:Dark black,light brown head...
Flavor:chocolate fudge,vanilla,coconut...

Pours a nice and black color.  Aroma is of sweeter malts, oak, vanilla, coconut, and some bourbon.  Flavor is of chocolate, oak, vanilla, malts, and some bourbon.  Full bodied with a great palate.   Leaves a sweeter malt and chocolate finish.  Great!  Just great!

Bottled. Pours black with a large, creamy, beige head. Good lacings. Nose of roasted malts and coffee. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, chocklate, coffee and bourbon notes. Flat carbonation. Oily texture. Full bodied. Ends up more dry with alcohol notes and malt bitterness. Very nice.

Bottle thanks to Owen. Pours a very dark brown with only the smallest of dark tan coloured head. Super sweet aromas of drak sugar, stone fruits, vanilla and a little light chocolate. Some oak seems to come through as it warms. Flavours are liewise super sweet. Silky smooth mouthfeel. Probably a little too sweet for my liking and I would struggle to drink the whole bottle but great stuff all the same.

small size bottle dont know the year pour has a really dark color with a little brown head showing some carbonation. aroma has dark damp malt, vanilla, sweet bourbon, old oak, and some dark sugar. thick mouth feel and there is a bit of carbonation still kicking around. flavor is super rich, dark malt, molasses, vanilla, mild bourbon, chocolate, and some raisin. not a ton of heat and the complex flavors make it interesting.

Bottle at Rotary, on April 8, 2011Black color, no head, Vanilla, oak, alcohol scent. Sweet, alcohol, cocoa, chocolate taste. Roasted and chocolate aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Finishes dry.
Pours dark brown/black with almost no. No carbonation. Aroma wood and smoked. Taste is roasted oaky prunes and  vanilla

800th rating.Black beer no head.that costs points... sorry...taste and smell is sweet Bourbon, spices and caramel. Not bad at all, should have some carbonation. Alcohol gets trough hard also, a bit liquorish, coffee and chocolate. I miss carbonation for sure, this one could be like 3.9-4.0...

Bottle pours thick viscous black with thick chocolate head.  Aroma chocolate and bourbon.  Taste dark fruits, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla with some hops/  Finish of alcohol with slight hops.  Very powerful.  Palate thick and almost syrupy with slight carbonation.  Alcohol very evident.

Very nice beer but not sure its worth the cost as theres stuff I like as much or more for much less.

Awesome beer.  From tap.  Black with a tan head.  Great aroma of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, booze and oak.  Similar flavor, but much more bourbon than the other flavors.  Very full bodied with appropriate  carbonation. Impressive beer.

Bottle generously shared at Maxs FF winnings tasting. Standard dark brown pour. Aroma is toffee and marshmallow, toffee and marshmallow, and toffee and marshmallow with a little chocolate syrup. Flavor hits you first with sharp bourbon, followed by a milk chocolate syrup rush. Toffee and pine emerge more later. A bit prickly and syrupy mouthfeel. Solid.

Bottled. Poured pitch black with a dark brown head. Aroma was huge malts, chewy chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and some alcohol. Flavor was medium sweetness and bitterness. This reminded me of a thick chewy bourbon county stout that had been aged for 2 years. The big full chewy body really stood out.
08 bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasty and bourbony aroma, with vanilla and toffee. The flavor has bourbon, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate, and dark fruits. Nice.

Thanks bro.  Pours pitch black with no head.  Aroma of brown sugar, chocolate, bourbon and a hint of coffee (almost a sweet rum-like aroma).  Like drinking a liquid truffle (milk chocolate, cocoa powder) infused with coffee and alcohol.  Completely flat, with a smooth finish and some heat that is slowly felt rather than tasted.  I love the flavors but I do wish there was at least a hint of carbonation.  Recommend sipping and sharing.

Ive had this beer many times in the past but most recently at churchills anniversary and it was awesome per usual. Poured black and thick with a 1 finger head that dissipated quickly. Smells of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, toasted malts. Taste is smooth whiskey and wood, chocolate, malt, vanilla, and some smoke. Very balanced and delicious. I love it!

Poured into a snifter. Thanks to nickd717 for this a long time ago. 2009 vintage (yeah, that one).

We all know the legend of Flat Abbey and now its my turn to participate in its uncarbonated history.

I thought I knew right away that this too would be uncarbonated, even after the two year incubation in the cellar, but...

2.0 A: ...a touch of carbonation had presented itself. But dont worry, your bottle isnt going to be the way it should be. By a touch I mean that even with a semi-aggressive pour, I managed only about 1/16 inch of head that was quickly pulled back into the black colored abyss. Also of note, a chunk of some sort of sludge fell into the glass about 3/4 into the pour. Images of Triple Bock plopped into my head as the sludge cake plopped into the glass.

4.5 S: I must say that Im thoroughly impressed. This smells great and has plenty of power even without the aid of the carbonation to traffic aroma molecules to the surface. Bourbon is by far the strongest aroma. Leather, melon, vanilla, oak are all there in pleasant proportions. Theres just a touch of underlying roastiness and some sweet caramel to enhance. I usually dont appreciate bourbon forward smells, but this is in perfect proportion and is hard not to enjoy.

2.0 T: For the taste, Im not thoroughly impressed and indeed not impressed at all. The lack of carbonation took what would have been an okay beer and turned it into overly sugary and boozy watered down dram of bourbon. The bourbon blocks out everything except for the caramel sweetness and the priming sugar. This is just too damn sweet (but not cloying) and the only thing balancing it is astringent bourbon booziness. Lots of leather and vanilla with just a hint of the beer underneath. I like bourbon barreled beers, but prefer the bourbon to complement rather than dominate.

1.5 M: Heavier medium body. By this point I shouldnt have to tell anyone what the carbonation is like. Its not exactly zero carbonation, but its 98% reduced from what I would want. Not particularly smooth due to the bourbon overload either.

2.0 D: Damn good nose that almost made the bottle a good experience by itself. However, nothing else is up to par. The lack of carbonation made a shitty appearance, a shitty mouthfeel, and a shitty taste. I had hoped that the time in the cellar would have improved this aspect, but alas it did not. I damn near love Old Viscosity, but it was hard to find any of it in the nose or the taste. The bourbon was too powerful to allow that to occur. Tomme should be ashamed of himself for releasing this to the public, especially given the gaudy price. I should also note that I absolutely loved Triple Bock. It was so unthinkably complex and the flavors meshed well together. This doesnt have that same kind of complexity or quality to warrant a good score in spite of being flat.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-23-2011 05:53:16

Bottle thanks to Steptin at ACBF 11.  Black colour no head.  Lots of vanilla burnt toffee oak all on aroma.  No balance at all.  No real beer aroma.  Quite smooth in mouth.  Too oaky burn and vanilla. Just too much. Coulnt finish my glass.  Not enough original beer comes through.  Too much barrel agsd flavour.
On tap at Zenos. Black with thin tan head. Aroma is Whisky. Flavor is Whisky, vanilla, chocolate and a little smoke. Delicious.

Pours dark licorice into a snifter. Mocha head leaves spotted tears as it recedes to coat surface. Vanilla, chocolate and bourbon aromas. Thick with dark licorice and soy upfront turning to dark pit fruit before the warming, smoky port finish.

375 ml bottle @ OHaras, Tampere. 2009 version.
Pours a pitch black colour with a reddish haze and a non-existent head. Aroma of smooth American hops, chocolate malts, coffee and wood. Flavour of chocolate, caramel malts, coffee, strong vanilla and nuts. Full bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a dry, alcohol driven finish with some coffee and chocolate. A very good American Strong Ale.

Black with thin and brown head, oil surface when that dissipated.  Aroma is of earth and rye bread.  Flavor is rye bread, earth, smoke, slight roast and coffee.  Very rich in flavor to an extent I havent had in a very long time.  Bourbon barrel flavor actually melded well with beer flavors so that oak, vanilla, and bourbon were noticeably not part of the description.  Very good, but a slow sipper, even for a big beer.

375ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, American Weeks 2011)
6- A tough battle between the vanilla aroma, and the heavy sticky sugariness that emanates from the top of the surface. I think I know how this is going to taste.
4- Well, you cant fault that nice dark copper hue, but it was as flat as a pancake, and so glassy you can call that a pancake with syrup on.
6 Vanilla/bourbon-dominated flavours make this a uni-directional sipper. If you dont like the vanilla or you dont like raw sugar, youre not going to like this. I can put up with it when its clearly a sipper.
4- With all the sugars, its soft and smooth, but yes, clearly slick and sticky too. Clearly very strong, but the sugar/alcohol combination prevents it from actually burning, its actually not a bad liqueur. Finish does have some coffee notes, so definitely would work well as an after-dinner liqueur.
12 Of course, this is basically instant diabetes in a glass, but in the right context, its quite drinkable. Which probably makes it unique as the only even vaguely drinkable thing from Port/Lost Abbey, who are the most over-rated bunch of slop-merchants on either side of the atlantic.

On tap at City Beer during SF strong beer week 
Appearance: Pours coal black with a small tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Dark roasted malts, dark fruits and bourbon 
Taste: Silky mouthfeel of roasted malts, vanilla, woody and bourbon 
Very good and smooth

Thanks to Eric for your generosity.  Poured  dense and  black, topped with a small tan head.  The aroma was thick of bourbon, vanilla, raisins, and prune.  The flavor was raisins, chocolate, vanilla, and sweet bourbon .  I expected a much sweeter and  more viscus finish. We actually decided to cheers my wifes getting older with a glass of Older Viscosity...heres a cheers to anyone who tries this great beer!

2010 bottle. Pour a dark black with a slight head that dissipates after a few minutes.  The nose is bourbon, vanilla, wet leather and roasted notes. The first sip is is strong with dark chocolate, roasted flavors, vanilla oak and a touch of coffee. The mouth feel at the end when it was colder was strange almost a over carbonated feel but as it warmed up it disappeared.  Nice beer but not earth shattering. I have 3 bottles left. I will age these guys.

Pours blacker than an East Indian with a suntan.  Very little carbonation, pretty much no head.  Smells of chocolate, ripe dark fruits, heavily roasted dark coffee, and bourbon.  Tastes pretty much exactly like it smells.  But the beer is thick and syrupy and coats your mouth, leaving you with complex residual flavors long after you swallow the last drop.  This is one amazing beer.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 12.7 oz bottle from tarheels86, thanks GT. Clear deep dark brown almost black with a very minimal head. Very boozy aroma of bourbon, oak, and alcohol with plenty of dark fruit, burnt sugar and vanilla. The flavor is filled with vanilla, sweet caramel malt, raisins with big bourbon heat and light bitterness. Medium to full body with a mild carbonation and a very long boozy finish. This is a stellar beer, so much flavor and booziness but still goes down easy and keeps you coming back for another sip. Still think this beer could do with a bit more carbonation, and it would be nice to see a head on it.

Bottle. 12.7 oz. Pours deep mahogany brown with an oily, slick surface and a razor thin white lacy head. Aroma is very similar to Angels Share; bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and roasted malts. Body is full and rich, but not as thick as expected. Silky, slightly smoky palate. Finish has a touch of hop bitterness and a nice warming in the throat. Excellent American strong.

Sometimes I scare myself for giving raving reviews all the time but this beer deserves it. I cant find much of anything wrong with it. Pours out as an intimidating asphalt black. Thick. The flavor will blow your mind. So smooth and I would say an easy sipper for sure. Not hot. You definitly get that oak and vanilla quality from the bourbon aging but it isnt the dominate flavor (like in Old Rasputin XII). The finish reminds me of Bitter Cocoa powder....like a dark chocolate cake with a lot of DARK chocolate. Sweet, yet dry and bitter. Love it. Such a well mad Strong Ale. I love roasty malts baby.

(Bottle) Black colour, almost flat with brief bubbly head. Malty, vinous nose with liquorice, tar, molasses, dried fruit, vanilla, oak wood and bourbon. Malty, roasted taste with notes of liquorice, dark chocolate, dried fruit, bourbon, vanilla and oak wood. Warming, vinous finish. Almost full body, slightly oily texture, fairly sweet. High drinkability for its strength. The bourbon barrel gives it an interesting twist, but in my opinion the original version is even better. Lovely beer.

375mL bottle, pours dark brown / black with a medium beige head. Aroma of rich bourbon, oak, vanilla, dark cocoa, peat and alcohol. Flavour reveals the dark cocoa, bourbon and oak upfront, with a smoky/peaty and alcoholic finish. Exceptionally well-crafted.
375 ml.  wow, what a great aroma.  One of the best aromas ive smelled  in a while.  Bourbon, vanilla, licorice.  Pitch black with a light tan head.  very complex.  burns a little.

On tap at Bad Apple. Pour is dark with a dark tan head. Nose is delicious vanilla, rich molasses, chocolate and alcohol. Super rich on the palate deep woody vanilla and apparent yet unagressive bourbon. Layers of sweet chocolate and molasses. Very very tasty.

Bottle shared at Natifest 10.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is big bourbon, dark chocolate, rich malts, dark caramel and vanilla.  The flavor is big oak, dark caramel, vanilla, dark chocolate, molasses and only lighter notes of bourbon.  I thought from the nose that this would be a bourbon bomb, but it was nicely integrated into the flavor. Full bodied and definitely a sipper.  This was nice.

Pours velvety black with thick and foamy tan head. Sweet bourbon and vanilla is apparent right away in the nose. Syrupy texture with smooth and creamy bourbon and roasted malt flavor. Notes of raisin, espresso and chocolate. Beads of vanilla bourbon last for a while.

Bottle: Pours a dark black color with little head. The nose is oaky and bourbony with a sharp alcohol and raisin note along with coffee and roast. The flavor is chewy with soy sauce and licorice, tons of vanilla and marshmallow notes but the tartness from the wood & alcohol overpower a lot of the subtleties. Very big and fun, but you cant watch action movies every night.

Black with brown hues and no head. Heavy fruity and whisky aroma wih raisins, light chocolate and  light roastiness. Nice balance between the base beer and barrell flavours. Big body with almost no carbonation.
UPDATED: SEP 13, 2011 38cl, Vintage 2011, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, too heavy, not balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good brew, yet very expensive!

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2011 Bottled @ home.  Pours a very syrupy deep black appearance with a very dark brown large-ish head.  This beer is incredibly aromatic- you get a huge whiff as soon as you pop the cork.  Deep dark malty aroma with tons of oak and Bourbon in the nose.  Body is not surprisingly very thick and dark malty with a gigantic oak and Bourbon flavor.  Theres notes of wood, vanilla, and chocolate.  Thick, a bit syrupy finish with some alcohol.  The oak flavor just lingers on the tongue afterwords.  I am incredibly impressed.

Pours opaque with limited cocoa head. Smells mostly of molasses and dark fruit malt - the taste matches. Mouthfeel is somewhat sticky but some sopping through your teeth. Kind of a molasses bomb, IMHO. I dont really note many other flavors/complexities shining through.

The pour of this wonderful beer is dark brown with little to no head.  It actually looks like a glass of coca cola.  The aroma is amazing.  Vanilla, caramel, wood and bourbon comes through in the nose which again, is so fragrant.  Flavors of this complex beer range from vanilla, caramel, oak, bourbon, roasted malts, some chocolate......The layers of flavors in this beer are just incredibly delicious and deep.  Even the 12% alcohol is hidden among all those flavors.  Incredible.

Pours deep reddish brown with an almost nonexistent tan head. Huge, complex aroma- caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, roasted grains, molasses, oak. Flavor much like the aroma, hides 12% well, smooth and roasty. Each sip accentuates another aspect of the flavor. Sippin beer, nuances galore, slight coffee as it warms. It started excellent and improves with each drink. WOW!

Bottle courtesy bu11zeye. Dark dark brown color. Tannish head. Vanilla notes on the nose. Very sweet woody nose. Lots of malts. Sweet heavy malts and some tartness fill out the flavor. A touch of coffee is also apparent. this one has more aged qualities to it than the original but is delightful!

Bottle consumed on the surfliner back from the brewery. Super bourbon/alcoholic nose. Like fuselage at first, until you get used to it. Decent carbonation. Thin to medium bodied - which is to be expected with a barrel aged beer.. Cocolate maltesers with bourbon bounce around the mouth at first with a lovely creamy roast finish. Boozy beer. Is it better than old viscosity? They are really two different beasts. Old is a nuanced number where as this is more a whack over the head with a 2 x 4. Very enjoyable.

Bottle from Cavie.  Black pour with a dark brown head.  This one is like when I change the oil in my 1991 Suburban well after 3,000 miles.  Aroma is roasted malts, licorice, cocoa, wood, and alcohol.  Taste is all sorts of woody, vanilla, chocolate, and a little licorice.

Deep black with minimal head.  Very viscous pour with very strong earthy aromas escaping while pouring.  Scotchy, peaty smells with vigerous sugary fruited notes.  Tooth coatingly powerful and at times cloyingly sweetened in its strength.  This brew brings the pain.  While the flavors are dominating they dont seem to transition well together and lacks a consistant flavor narrative.  Still good but I was let down a little bit.

2008 Batch poured 12/10.

A-pours a dark black liquid that has a thick creamy dark tan head.

S-the nose has some wood barrel to it, light bourbon notes, hints of green olive, vanilla, some roasted malts, roasted charred coffee and hints of sweetness.

T-wood up front, notes of bourbon, light olive notes, strong roasted malts, hints of coffee, some light malt sweetness with dark plums and carmelized sugar.

M-full bodied, a little sloppy on the feel, creamy though, with a roasted crisp finish.

D-this has some balance, very roasty flavors with notes of chocolate and some malt sweetness in the back.  nothing special but a decent brew.

Big thanks to Kaiser81 for sending me this bottle. 2010 vintage. 

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a brown head. Glad to see this batch was carbonated after hearing about other batches of Older Viscosity that had carbonation issues. 

The aroma is bourbon, roasted malt and chocolate. The beer smells very inviting. 

The flavor is better than the aroma and is very complex. I get a lot of oak, maple and vanilla, as well as a healthy does of chocolate and roasted malt. With all of these secondary flavors, I get a large amount of bourbon and some hot, warming alcohol. 

Full, creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

I love Old Viscosity and this beer was everything I hoped it would be. Excellent.

Port Brewing
Older Viscosity
I have and older bottle of this sitting in the basement, so we tried the newer bottle first. This does not evoke memories of Old Viscosity, for starters. Pours black with a thin to medium tan head and ok retention. Oily appearance. Aroma is bourbon and sour red wine with roasty oak. Odd , but rather pleasing. Flavor is oily bourbon and vanilla. Boozy as hell with nice oak notes and a sweet finish. Good shit and I cant wait for the older bottle!

Pours completely black and no head formation to speak of.  The aroma is superb!  Aromas of sweet milk chocolate and rich vanilla are domineering.  This is just a fantastic smelling beer!  Smoke and wood are also noticeable as are brown sugars, dark fruits, molasses, coffee, and deep roasted malts.  I love this smell!  Very smooth and very rich with bourbon.  The bourbon is just wonderful giving flavors of sweet vanilla, milk chocolate, coffee, molasses, charred oak, and dates.  The finish is a little bitter from the roasted malts and is long.  Overall, this is just magnificent!

375ml bottle from Brewdog Bar in Aberdeen. Pours very dark brown with a thin mid tan head. Nose; bourbon, figs, brown sugar, soy sauce and some coffee. Taste; syrupy, chocolate, coffee, liquorice, wood, bourbon, sticky dark fruits. Complex and rich, but certainly not the easiest beer to drink!

Poured from a 375 ml bottle at Lost Abbey.  Pours a dark as night black with a nice tan head.  Smell is bourbon, chocolate and toasted malts.  Tastes of chocolate and bourbon.  Smooth.  The alcohol is hidden well on this one.
Basically the embodiment of amazingness.  Soy sauce, molasses, brown sugar, nutty roastiness.  Creamy, but medium thin at the same time.  Absolutely fantastic

2008 375 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown nearly black body and topped by a minimal thin tan colored film that settles quickly and leaving dripply legging across the glass. The aroma shows the bourbon right off the bat to go with notes of dark chocolate, molasses, and woody, oaky vanilla. The flavor follows suit with the oaky bourbon, wood, chocolate roast, and vanilla. The bourbon and chocolate malt blend perfectly for a great taste. Nearly full bodied and coats the mouth well with minimal carbonation as expected that leads to a warm, smooth bourbon finish. This a really nice bourbon barrel aged beer, and makes a good base beer even better.

375 ml bottle from South Bay Drugs.  2009 vintage.  Pours a near-opaque dark brown with a faint red tint and a tiny tan head that settles into just a small ring.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, and vanilla up front, with the chocolate malts of the Old Viscosity settling into a secondary role, along with notes of caramel, cream, earth, and a little smoke to the oak.  The flavor follows along the same lines, though the bourbon doesnt bring the same heat.  Nice sweetness and roastiness from the caramel, chocolate malts, and lightly toasted brown sugar.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a rich, sweet mouthfeel.  I thought the bourbon barrel added a different element to it, but I didnt necessarily like it any more or less- just different.  Still a great beer.

Black.  Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, and booze.  Flavor is bread, molasses, slightly of dark fruit, and more booze.  Although more complex, I actually preferred the Old Viscosity.  The Older Viscosity was clearly lighter in the body, and that was somehow distracting.  But this was still a really good beer.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Deep brown, near-black body with no head. Aroma is full and complex: licorice, soy, intense yet well-tuned boozy notes, hints of fungal aromas and chocolate. Such an unconventional mix, and yet working extremely well. Incredible. Taste is a tarty fungal soy mix with undertones of port and some wooden flavors. Fascinating. Palate is slick and oily, but perhaps (surprisingly) a tad bit thin. Never mind though, this is truly a full-fledged, original American craft beer creation which few can match in composition and complexity. Simply put: awesome.

A: Pours a deep, dark black into my snifter. As expected given the vintage this is, there is absolutely no head at all with the hardest of all pours, and only a tiny bit of lacing is all I can muster with a long swirl of the glass.

S: Loads of coffee and espresso with heap after heap of bourbon as well. Some mild, dry sweetness coming alongside some bittersweet chocolate.

T: Some alcohol comes alongside the espresso, which ends up really bringing out the bourbon characteristics. Any chocolate and/or sweetness is quite subdued.

M: Again, almost zero carbonation. If it werent for the style--i.e. if this were an IPA--the lack of carbonation would be a major buzzkill, but its only a minor setback how it currently is. Loads of alcohol as well.

D: Fairly drinkable given some fairly obvious flaws. Fairly disappointing as the taste shows some promise, and I was expecting more knowing how good Old Viscosity is.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

Bottle brought to a tasting, thanks wavers1!  Black pour with a nice mocha colored head.  Lots of bourbon up front in the aroma, then a big roasty malt presence and some wood.  Bourbon flavors werent as big as I thought they would be, which was nice.  They were there but didnt overpower.  Huge roastiness throughout this one.  Not a bourbon bomb but it left its presence known, very nice.  Finish was bitter and roasty, huge.  This was a monster.  Viscous mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation, maybe too much.  Quite excellent, carbonation could have been more lax.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of molasses, burnt, and dark chocolate, moderate resin and earth for the hops and yeast, with background notes of raisin, port wine, wood, tar bourbon, cherry and alcohol. Head is very small, bubbly and wispy brown, with sparse lacing and good legs and is almost fully diminishing. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then the long finish is moderately bittersweet and lightly acidic. Palate is full, creamy with a soft carbonation and a heavily alcoholic finish. Definitely a mouth-filling American Strong Ale, it should be sipped slowly and enjoyed with at least one friend per bottle...or drink it alone and get pleasantly smashed.

on tap at the Iron abbey.  Black as night and thick as molasses.   Rich, deep, oily, like drinking a glass of velvet mud.  Chocolate and oak are predominant, but the complexity is overwhelming.  A real treat.

12.7oz corked and caged bottle from 2009, courtesy of SuzyGreenberg on my first trade, enjoyed for my 500th rating.  The cork pops out to release a tiny whisper of carbonation, and bourbon floods the room.  The beer pours thick, dark brown, and with absolutely no head.  It looks black in the glass, with a tinge of reddish light peeking through around the edges.  In addition to bourbon, Im getting aromas of oak, sweet raisin, milk chocolate, buttered toast, and red fruit.  The flavor is sweet oak, bourbon, dark chocolate, cherry, and toast.  Alcohol and slight bitter pine are present in the finish, with a lingering bitter aftertaste of butter, toffee, and berry jam.  This feels thick, oily, and creamy, with low carbonation and a warming mouthfeel.  This is a fantastic beer.  Complex, rich, and velvety, it is great to sip on a cool night sitting by a fire.  Im so glad to have had the chance to try this.  Thanks Ben!

F me...WOW! Aroma of bourbon, wood, dark fruit, molasses, fig & cocoa. Pours Snipes Black with rich chocolatey head. Mouthfeel is warm, oily, and sticky. Taste is deep bourbon, molasses, wood, malts, and strong alcohol finish. Sweet up front, and bit dry and slight bitterness on the end. Tasted from the bottle @ 60F. This beer rocks!Dont be stupid about it. If you find it, buy it.

Picked up bottle in colorado a few months ago. Pours dark with a light brown head.  smells of bourbon and coffee. Bourbon flavor is not over powering. Over all a very good beer. Aging another bottle and will be interested to see how one tastes after being aged for a few years.

12.7 fl.oz. corked bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 12.0%. Pitch black colour, moderate tan head. Intense aroma of sweet malts, bourbon whiskey, vanilla and oak, also moderate roasty notes, hints of chocolate and liquorice. Very sweet (too sweet?) and intense flavour, sweet malts galore, notes of bourbon, oak and vanilla again, also notes of mild coffee, dark chocolate and liquorice. Moderate hops.

#200
Bottle pours a dark, muddy brown with small, fizzy brown head.  Aroma of baked goods with whiskey.  Predominant flavors of cookies, molasses, wood, smoke, black licorice, and whiskey.  Smooth and syrupy with a dry finish.  Outstanding.

Pour from the guys next to us at Darkness Day 2010, thanks for the awesome hook up! Dark brown almost black pour, thin white head.  Aroma is complex with bourbon, chocolate, dark fruit notes.  Taste is nice chocolate intermingling with dark fruit, some roasted coffee and a bitter oaky finish with some bourbon.  Excellent flavors, and a well made brew.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2011 Dark mahogany with good, creamy, brown head / Winey, big, nose of coffee and bourbon / Full body, some acidity, winey and creamy with good balance, good alcohol mask, and long finish / Young flavors of dark roast coffee, caramel, coconut, vanilla, oak, and bourbon / Excellent, but coconut flavor a bit too potent.  Presumably will improve with age.

WOW! Like the bottle says this is Old Viscosity turned up to 11. Shared half the bottle with a friend. Pour with lots of carbonation and a thick tan head. Very heavy body. Thick and creamy had to drink it slowly. While I enjoyed this beer the half a bottle was plenty. A very unique beer experience for me. Received in a trade from Matt.

Oh my! Heaven Hill Bourbon Barrels. Maybe there is a god. Stout like in appearance, this has a wonderful fruity aroma that leads to an amazing array of flavors that begins with vanilla, chocolate, caramel along with fruit and candy. There is quite a bit of booze but it is remarkably smooth and easy to drink.

350ml bottle. Pours black with very small brown head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, oak, and some booze. Flavors again of bourbon, vanilla, booze, and some roasted malts. Has a real nice bourbon flavor. Reminds me of GI BCS but thinner.

Bottle from Capones (finally).  Pours dark blackish brown with minimal brown head.  Nose is big plum/prune, dark patent malt, cacao, dark choc, hops, fuselly bourbon.  Tastes rich, vcery drk  malty, on the sweet side, with cacao, dark choc, German choc cake, raisins, very complex flavor.  Not as rich or complex as I crave for this style, but Ii want to send a stinging rebuttal to those who say this is either overrated or undercarbonated.  It is perhaps a bit of both, but it hs a presence about it that reminds me of Lando Calrissian.  It took me 5 yearts to find this beer, and yes, it is at a level that approximates the higher tier beers at its level, not the best Ive ever had, but one I am glad I got a chance to quaff, and beer geeks NEED to be able to fins these beers.  Beer resellers are the scum if the earth. As a summary, it is a very hot and very dense (and as a brewer I dare you to impart density to a 12% beer...good luck with that) beer thsat has tons of complexity and flavor.

Bottle pours dark black with a brown head. Aroma is quite overwhelming, bourbon is very present, oak, vanilla, molasses, caramel and chocolate. Taste is amazing and similar to aroma tastes like someone pour a very fine bourbon over a very rich chocolate dessert, there is amazing balance here, with a nice medium bitter aftertaste.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep black with no head at all. Aroma is bourbon, oak, vanilla and lots of alcohol. Taste is pretty similar, with a strong presence of alcohol again. Full body with very little carbonation.
Well, its a great beer in my opinion, but there are two weaknesses: too much alcoholic to me and too much low carbonation.

Bottle. Dark brown almost black body with almost no head. Aroma is oak, alcohol, chocolate, coffee, sweet ripe dark fruit. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, oak, alcohol, dark fruit and soy. Medium carbonation.

Bottle from a trade with DeadGirl. Pours black with a few bubbles.  Strong aromas of bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolate and alcohol. Very boubon foward flavor. Lots of vanlla, chocolate and oak. The alcohol is still a bit hot. Full body with a slick, oily mouthfeel. A little csrbonartion would have made it that much more enjoyable. Still a nice beer. Thanks Amelia.

On tap at Hop Leaf Chicago. Near-black, thick finger-width brown cap. Mouthwatering aroma of chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and wood. Sweet chewy palate, with beautiful dark malt flavours of chocolate, figs, vanilla, bourbon, wood, leather. Lots of barrel character here, but lots of beer behind it, creating a terrific balance and a delicious beer.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Black pour light tan head .... roasted and chocolately aroma with a bourbon kick ..... taste of bourbon and chocolate roasted malts, oak and very balanced with a bitter chocolatey and bourbon finish .... an awesome brew very smooth and of course the bourbon dominates as it warms ... loved it

Wow. Im sending out another thanks to bhensonb. Im starting to look forward to the times when I forget to stop at the store and am forced to do a cellar raid. Bhensonb sent me this one a year ago in a trade, and, damn, its great.

This one pours all but flat. There is only the smallest hint of carbonation here. Dark black opaque as promised by the name. The nose is all about the bourbon and oak from the barrels. First trip past the lips there is a slight alcohol warmth. -- Doh! 12% - lets go slow - and then the bourbon and sweet, caramel, oak flavors. I absolutely love this beer. Maybe its the autumn in the air, but this is hitting the spot dead on tonight. Oak and bourbon dominate with cherry, chocolate, caramel following closely and threatening to take over. Ive never been a great fan of bourbon barrel aged beers - except for Rosies - but this one is a masterpiece. Im afraid of how much of this I might drink if I could get it regularly.
UPDATED: OCT 15, 2010 2010 bottle.  Oh boy this is hot.  The bourbon nose and taste is overwhelming.  A year or two of aging might improve this ale.  Or just let it warm up!!!

2010 cork and caged. Strong alcohol and soy bouquet. Black as night pouring into snifter with thin ring of bubbles. Tastes like teriyaki and whiskey. Full bodied, thick and lingering. Ive really enjoyed past vintages and the Year round releases but Im thinking of using it with my sushi instead

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Bottle at isaac newtons. Black pour with no head. Delicious thick aroma with caramel, malt and vanilla. Taste is creamy and thick with little hoppiness but a complex malt taste. Vanilla and toffee are forefront with slight Bourbon sweet booze flavor. Mouthfeel if full and inviting. I suspect this is a very similar recipe to the angels share. Superb.
Had a sip from James. Aroma is an amazing toasty malt with undertones of a dark hop. Flavor is is so nicely balanced with the Bourbon and deep malts. Really an intense brew.

12.7oz corked and caged bottle poured into a Snifter at 42°.  Color is a solid black with nice carbonation and a small tight brown head.  Aroma is rich sweet and roasted with a oak and vanilla.  Full body with a rich mouth feel.  Flavor is bold with rich sweet caramel, coffee and chocolate then the oak and vanilla come in with just a hint of bitterness.  In the after taste the bitterness rolls into a licorice taste and a warming hint of alcohol.  Wow this is just an amazing brew, just as good as the Old Viscosity with some extra flavors added to the complex.  If it wasnt for the cost ($16 for a 12.7 oz bottle) and that its so hard to find (it took me almost 2 years to find this bottle) I would keep it around all the time.

Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival on September 16, 2010.  Solid black color.  Aroma is wicked, almost like a cardboard box... dusty, but very good.  Woah-hoo... very strong, a little bit of hop-roast character.

On tap @ Falling Rock Tap House, Denver. Dark as sin with almost no light able to shine through even with only 2 oz. left in the glass. Minimal light chocolate head. Aromas could be smelled 6 inches from the glass; very powerful. A very boozy bourbon aroma dominates, with a healthy dose of brown sugar, chocolate, maybe some motor oil (but maybe my mind just tricked me into that last one, via the bottle label).  Th taste is much the same as the smell, with a powerful bourbon punch followed by an overwhelming cocoa impact. Too sugary sweet, like cola syrup. Finishes kinda stanky and over-the-top sweet. Mouthfeel is too oily and low carbonated. An overrated dissappintment.

Aroma:malt lidt kaffe lidt chokolade vanilje tømmer  Ud.:kaffesort klar Skum:ingen Efter smag:sød lidt bitter moderat slut efter smag:sød moderat bitter meget i langtid  Krop:fuld For.:sirupsagtig Brus:flad 
cask @gbbf 10

new 2010 vintage, $16, not bad. nice pour, excellent carbonation. as always, a complete bourbon bomb here, which i love. its super smooth, nice slight heat, excellent malty flavor, both roasty and distilled. a tasty ale. the nose is a tad hot right now, the body o dont mind, but both should age really, really nicely this year. im definitely picking up a few of these for the cellar.

Bottled vintage 2009
Opaque black, no head. Aroma has raisins and portwine, like in the aged BW, but this is only one year old. Also some licorice and Bourbon. Full-bodied. Lots of vanilla, whiskey, licorice and raisins in the flavor. Of course also some alcohol. Smooth palate. Interesting, sweetish-salty beer.

Bottled. Deep quite much black colour, not much, but slight brown head. Aroma is alcohol, raisins, some vanilla, wood, dark fruits, Quite port/madeira wine like notes as well. Flavour is raisins, toffee, brutal plum, thick coffee, mild chocolate and vanilla. Totally brutal in flavour. Probably beats many things Ive had for the flavour... This is heading for the top...

375 ml bottle of 2009 vintage purchased at the brewery on release day in summer of last year ($15).  Pours a dark black with a hint of brown around the edges.  Despite a vigorous pour, this produces almost no head...uh oh, looks like this brewerys well-known carbonation problems are coming into play.  Aroma is lovely with a big bourbon presence and other notes of wood, booze, dark chocolate, vanilla liqueur.  Flavor is also nicely complex with (again) big bourbon flavors, molasses, wood, chewy caramel, chocolate.  Its boozy -- the hotness distracts a little bit.  The barrel character and higher ABV makes this quite different from the normal Old Vis, and somewhat similar to the Angels Share series (though not quite as good).  And as with last years Angels Share, the lack of carbonation is disappointing but does not necessarily distract from the overall experience with this beer.  Another dark beer winner from Port / Lost Abbey.  (537, 375)

Rating #2000. 2009 bottle purchased at City Beer in SF on 8/4/10 and shared at the Day Before Labor Day party on 9/5/10. Pours pitch black with a medium tan head. Nose is boozy, but more like a brandy or port than a bourbon with notes of chocolate and licorice. Flavor starts with chocolate and moves to brandy with some caramel before a roasty finish. Very nice, but I think I like Old Viscosity a tad bit better. Wouldnt mind tasting one of these with some age on it.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 Sample from a bottle courtesy of JaBier at the Day Before Labor Day party. The beer pours opaque black with a medium thick light brown head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of bourbon and dark chocolate along with malt. Full body with a nice oaky bourbon character accented by caramel malt,  vanilla, coffee and chocolate. The finish is somewhat boozy with a cocoa and oak aftertaste. Good beer that I am glad I got to finally try.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2011 (Amateur Review) On Tap : Pours a Dark Black with thin tan head - I was not prepared for the aroma ; havent been a huge fan of american strongs so far, but this one was stunning. The Bourbon is huge on this one - You nearly have to tell yourself youre not drinking whiskey here - Its just a huge brew, and not just because its 12%. Super smooth , you notice flavors of bourbon, caramel, chocolate, stunning. Wow.. really. 

- We all had our first beers that blew the mind, and this was it for me.

Bottle. Really excited to try this one after I found it on shef at Binnys. Pours a deep black color with a slight tan head that collars around the snifter. Huge bourbon notes in the nose along with dark chocolate and some booze. The taste is awesome. Very smooth with a nice bourbon flavor. Some dark chocolate, coffee, and leather after taste flavors. The bourbon really does meld well into this one. Medium/heavy mouthfeel. I could drink this all the time but it would get a little pricey at $12/bottle.

Vintage 2010. Bottle pours black with a thick beige head that sticks around for a while.  Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, coconut, and dark fruit.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of molasses, oak, and vanilla.  I can also definately notice a red wine aspect to this beer that quite a few people have mentioned.  Overall body is full and viscous, with plenty of depth.  Bravo.

Whoa! This is a bourbon aged monster. It looks like an imperial stout--thick black, small tan head, little patches of lace. The nose is interesting, very pungent though, in all honestly, not necessarily completely good. It smells of chocolate, Cabernet, coconut and bread dough. There is also another facet I can only describe as meaty, just sort of a savory richness, which really is as strange as it sounds. I like it overall but it is a strange mix that doesnt completely work. The velvety texture compliments the overall chocolate taste quite well but when you get right down to it, this is just a bit much. Complexity is often overrated and that, I think is the case here. Still, despite its shortcomings, it is an intense experience and one that is sure to interest lovers of barrel aged beers, which is why I feel it merits a north of average score despite all my negative comments. How on earth it is averaging above 4.0 as of September 2010 on RateBeer is beyond me though. You guys baffle me sometimes.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Consumed with Travlr in Tucson. Nice pour - good head with a motor-oil look. Smells rich. Initial sip, massive caramel and chocolate flavors without any hint of bitterness. The after-taste lingers long enough to make you want another drink. Amazing. Start with an AleSmith Wee Heavy, finish the night with this caramel thick oil.

12.7 ounce bottle shared with steptin.  Very black, large thick brown head with good retention.  Aroma of whiskey, oak, burnt caramel.  Taste is bourbon, port wine, grapes, dates, earth.  Body is chewy.  Dry finish.  Very nice.

Draught at Stone 14th Anniversary Celebration. First, I love how this beer looks. Black opaque with a small dark beige head. Aroma is sweet and dominated by bourbon, a bit malty with chocolate and coffee notes. This beer is medium-full bodied - sweet, roasted with some vanilla. Bourbon all the way through. Remains smooth with the low carbonation. Medium-long duration alcoholic finish. A must-have San Diego beer.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2010 10 bottle.  Black with light carbonation (thin brown head quickly fades).  Bourbon, raisin, and sweet dates smell.  Strong but not too strong bourbon in the flavor.  More dark raisin and some heavy sweet malt.  Bottom drops out of this one about 50% into the taste and rough alcohol takes over.  Im struggling with the quality of the taste in the finish.

Black pour.    Smells like cocoa, oak and lots of bourbon.  Rich, chewy and sweet with a lot of oak and booziness.  Tannic and a little bit astringent.  Its plenty intense, but it doesnt really come together for me.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 Bottle split with pat, labeled 2008. Pours a pitch black with nice thin brown head and lacing that lasts throughout.  The aroma is really incredible here - instantly reminding me of angel share with notes of vanilla, caramel, chocolate and sweet toffee. The Mouthfeel is perfect - smooth and well carbonated. Notes of vanilla, sweet toffee, roasted chocolate malts, caramel, vanilla extract, Bourbon, and oak.

375ml special cork bottle very nicely served with a chocolate bite at a place called 19. Glas in Gamla Stan. Vintage 2009 at a perfect drinking temperature. Pitch back body with a deep rusty shade. Bright shiny surface with dimples. Very, very aromatic with a confectionery smell added by raisin. Vinous taste containing cocoa and mocha balanced by mid-bitter dark fruits. Lingering and warming ending. Sorry, but I can not mentioned what I paid for this superb drink (Stockholm, 29.07.2010).
Bottle. black colour with a small tan head. Aroma is licorice,coffee, oak, alcohol. Flavour is dry, licorice, coffee, oak, oily, roasted malt, caramel. full body. world class beer.
Great balance of bold flavors. Great sweet choc mol. flavor. Bourbon is bold but not over powering. Nice alch. burn.

375 ml bottle given to me by my boy padrefan98 awhile back. Poured a rather dull and lifeless deep dark mahogany body with only the slightest hint of bubbly beige head. Aroma is lots of bourbon barrel, vanilla, oak, tobacco, slight earth, dark malts, and slight chocolate pudding. The body is rather nice with a medium to fuller body and light carbonation. Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, wood, oak, alcohol and bourbon. Even though this one sat for quite sometime and I even smoked a cigar beforehand this was HOOTTTT!!!!

pours like used motor oil.  Minimal head.  Very  strong nose of molasses, oak, some vanilla.  Port-like.  Very good taste, oak much stronger than old viscosity.  Thicker mouthfeel.  Overall a great brew 
(I personally prefer the old viscosity) and I wouldnt hesitate to grab another.

12.7-oz bottle Lost Abbey (2010) - Aroma: bourbon, vanilla, oak, maple syrup; Appearance: opaque, jet black color, brown head, some laces; Flavor: salty, sweet, bourbon, molasses, brown sugar, cherries, chocolate, fudge ; Mouthfeel: full bodied, silky, soft carbonation; Overall: awesome, wonderful strong alcoholic (no harshness) beer with extreme of oak, vanilla, and bourbon aromas and flavors, which leads the imagination towards cherries, dark chocolate, fudge, and dark fruits.  The only reason this beer is hard to drink is because youll want to keep smelling it.  Definitely worth the money.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Maple, walnut, wood and vanilla aroma.  Looks appropriately like dirty motor oil; no head.  Super chocolatey with those maple, walnut, wood and vanilla tones.  A nice warmth going down as well.

Notes: 2010 Release on cask at the GBBF 10

(Also GABF 09: Bourbony whisky aroma.  Jet black with a tan head.  Deep flavor; woody strength with a vanilla, alcohol finish.  Overall smooth with a bit of walnut and maple syrup notes in the finish)

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark black with dark brown hues on the edges. Thick, oily appearance. Tiny, almost non-existent, foamy, tan head that disappears fast. Thin ring of lace around the edge of the glass.

S - A lot of dark molasses and burnt brown sugar. This is paired with a lot of bourbon and vanilla along with an oaky/woody aroma. Also has a fair amount of dark chocolate and fudge aroma, and just a faint hint of coffee. Really pretty complex, with molasses, bourbon, and chocolate aromas intermingling.

T  Similar to the aroma. Strong chocolaty fudge and roasted dark malt to start with hints of coffee. Then a good kick of bourbon, vanilla, and oak comes out. This works well with the chocolate, fudge taste. Some burnt sugar, brown sugar type of sweetness comes out toward the middle of the sip. This is quickly cut by the bourbon, boozy taste that lingers after the sip.

M - Medium to full body. Thick, although not quite as viscous as I expected, and chewy. On the lower side of carbonation, but it works alright with the beer.

D - Definitely has a boozy aspect and alcohol is present, but it is still pretty drinkable as those flavors dont go unchecked. Body isnt quite what I expected but still full and filling.

Notes: Vintage 2009. Really enjoyable beer. Has a lot of the bourbon flavor, so if you like bourbon you have a good possibility of liking this. Well done barrel aged stout.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, chocolate, roasted grain), trace hops (resin), with notes of cardboard, alcohol, corn, vanilla, wood.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Full body, watery/syrupy/velvety texture, lively/soft carbonation, heavily alcoholic.

I love Old Viscosity (maybe the only Port/Lost Abbey beer I still like to this day, though), but wow, was this disappointing!  Wet cardboardy oxidation plus planks of wood plus corn syrup plus a strong alcohol note = no fun to sniff.  Its rich in the mouth, but overly sweet and alcoholic.  A $16 drain pour...so very, very sad.

Uber dark brown pour with a dark tan head. Aroma holds lots of bourbon, vanilla, lactic sugars, plenty of booze, and sweet chocolate. Flavor is absolutely packed with bourbon and vanilla, wood, heavy cream, caramel, and molasses. Palate is rich but still glides down so nicely. Low carbonation, but fits for the flavors. Awesome stuff.

Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Aroma is oak, vanilla, and sweet malts.  Notes of dark chocolate and some coffee come out.  Palate is a little strong.  Flavor really brings out alcohol, numbing the tounge.  Damn good.

Bottle.Pours jet black with a small tan head.Aroma of oak ,roasted malts ,alchohol and roasted sweet malt.Flavor is sweet caramel malt,roasted malt ,toasted malt ,oak,coffee,warming alcohol and coco.Full body,soft carbonation.World class!

Bottle from tasting organized by drowland @ Proof - 7/23/10.  Had this at the same time as Firestone 12 and 13.  Black pour with thin light tan head.  Aroma of licorice, leather, soy and oak.  Tastes were sweet sweet dark fruit, soy, bourbon and vanilla.  Had a minty vibe.  Warm alcohol burn.  Lots going on, but sweet for my tastes.  I had and liked the regular old viscosity a fair bit more.

Bottle.  Aroma has heavy notes of bourbon, molasses, dark dried fruits, vanilla, wood, chocolate and roasted malts.  Black in the glass with a tan head that leaves little lace.  Flavor is heavy sweetness, light sour saltiness and a medium/light bitterness.  palate is very full bodied and oily soft with a long finish.  Overall a very complex bourbon bomb that warms very well.  Cannot quaff this one, must sip.  Delicious.

This one pours nicer than the younger sibling with a coal black body and a full, tan, fluffy head which settles to dense, thick froth and leaves tight lacing.  The nose is awesome, sweet and fruitier than the original; candied black currants, burnt caramels, toasted oak with a nice straight bourbon tinge, lots of molasses and maple syrup, fudge, burnt oats, and minimal mocha coffee.  The flavor is much like the nose but just so intense and rich; scorched maple and molasses, Colombian coffee, leather, candied currants, rich fudge, some burnt caramels, hints of toasted oak, and burned oats.  The palate is thick, very full, velvety, chewy, and still nearly lively.  The finish takes an eternity with rich fudge taking over with light notes of leather, coffee, and candied currants.  Not a bad thing to say about this one; similar to the "Old" but richer, fruitier, thicker, and more refined.  Truly unique experience, especially for someone who believes the thicker the better or the richer the better.  One of my favs ever, enough said.

2010 release.  Bottle from South Bay.  Bourbon, smoke, oak, coffee beans in a very fine aroma.  A little molasses join in as well.  Very dark brown pour that practically looks black once poured with a nice thin tan head. Silky smooth, creamy, good carbonation, warming going down.  Rich cocoa flavor with lots of smooth bourbon.  Charcoal, wood, pepper, prunes and coffee adds depth and plenty of complexity.  Soothing.  Awesome beer!  Lost Abbey appears to have corrected their carbonation issues.
