Cask,   GBBF 10.  Dark brown with a thin head.  Aromas are marzipan with soy and toffee.  Spicy with almonds and peppery alcohol.  Flavours are earthy, sweet, coffee with marzipan and a thin oily character.  Warming alcohol bit surprisingly a little bit underwhelming.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2010.  Pitch black beer with a light head.  The aroma is fruity and port like, and the flavour is rich and port like.  Overall a good well conceived beer.
Bottle thanks to DaSilky. Pours tar black with tan head. Little lacing. Nose and taste of oak, bourbon, chocolate, smoke, deeply roasted malts, dark nuts and some coffee.
7/23/10.  Shared by Tim - thanks, man!  Huge smokey bourbon leather aroma but also with coconut and vanilla.  Similar in flavor but with a dash of sour and maybe a hint of mint and soy.

(Bottled, sampled 2010-01-30) Almost black with a very weak and fading head. Very strong vanilla aroma with oak, soy sauce-like malt, and alcohol. Flavor is clearly better with rounded, rich vanilla, strong and thick maltiness, but not cloying. Alcohol is warming smoothly. Full body, slicky, warming, low in CO2. An excellent example of a successful oak ageing: the original burnedness has disappeared and alcohol feels more rounded, even though the ABV has actually gone up.

Pours a deep black color with brown highlights and a thin beige head. Appealing, complex aroma of molasses, chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt and wood. The flavor is very good and quite complex, theres roasted malt, wood, molasses, chocolate, vanilla and bitterness. The body is medium with a liquorous texture and gentle carbonation. Im not a huge fan of barrel-aged beers, but this one is amazing.

Pour is black with a thin tan head. Aroma is of some oak, vanilla, alcohol and some sweet earthy notes. Taste is very smooth and complex. Alcohol, light roast, chocolate, earthy wood notes, dried fruit. The alcohol of the bourbon is there the whole way through, but never gets in the way of the rest of the flavors in the beer. Well done.
Alcoholic raisins weep vanilla tears into an oaken chalice. The chalice burns and the resulting syrup is cut with caramel and a bit of port. Itll put hair on your chest.

Ive been looking forward to popping the cork on this beer with such expectation.  That its £15.99 a bottle and such a highly rated beer on Ratebeer are only two reasons; the other is the much talked about carbonation issue which affected most of the special Port Brewing/ Lost Abbey 2009 editions.  The questions is, fizzy or flat.  Well, thats simply answered: undeniable flat.  It pours jet-black with no head, a dead beer.  And I will not accept that this is the brewers intention, as that has to rate along with "The dog ate my homework" in terms of excuses.  Its flat and thats a blunder of the beermakers - no excuses.  But with that said,  the nose is quite something; intense vanilla and overpowering wood.  Then big smoky notes.  Theres a nuttiness and a woozy alcohol presence, which only means that the 12% ABV is all too apparent.  The nose is of dust and ash and a heady alcohol... which is a bit of a let down for a beer rated this highly.  As it is, Old Viscosity scores higher for me and even that was a let down.  This is over priced and under-carbonated.  I once drank a bottle of Old Chimneys Good King Henry Special Reserve (with a group of dear friends), and that was incredible - it was everything this beer isnt.
Draft: pours dark black with a tan head, aroma of coffee, bourbon, oak, taste of bourbon, coffee, vanilla, nice and thick, just an excellent beer, hope to get a chance to have this again sometime.
2009 bottle flat like a 9 year old girl.  Nose is beautiful.  Toffee, caramel, and sharp.  Taste is huge mellowness.  Sweet and molasses to sharp with lots of alcohol.  Warming and nice.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. Deep and boozy, stone fruits, chocolate, burnt sugar, licorice, really an amazing beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: After several months of praying to the gods of all things carbonated, the 2009 Older Viz was finally cracked open. Much to my delight there was an audibly recognizable release of gas when the cork was popped. Dark brown/black body with a faint, timid khaki cap. Forms a tight ring with some skim in the middle. Very, very, very spotty lacing.

S: Rich bourbon, oak and vanilla highlight a rich, slightly bitter chocolate and roasty malt base. Inviting and strong, yet not "i might as well bang my head against the wall because I sense a hangover coming" strong.

T: More bourbon, oak and vanilla atop a thick, creamy semi-sweet chocolate. Good amounts of caramel, and burnt brown sugar. Slightly boozy. I was expecting some coffee/espresso notes, but they werent there, but that isnt necessarily a bad thing.

M: Slightly still. But honestly, it wasnt a bad thing. If i could "improve" the beer, sure I would add a bit more bubbles to my brew, but it works the way it is. Its got a nice weight to it, but it doesnt sit like a rock.

O: Quite enjoyable. Not the pinnacle of the style, but a damn good one that contributes nicely to the available brews. The 12.10abv is nicely managed here and the small bottle size is a treat. No need to slug through a massive bomber or 750 when I can get a nice single serving and move along.

$15.99/375 ml. 2010 bottle. Woo I cannot believe the money I spend on beer, but yet I keep spending. Cork comes out without much sound. Pours black with a small head. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is very sweet, lots of bourbon, tons of vanilla, but is dominated by the bourbon and vanilla notes with maybe some roast in the back, but is hard to tell with its hotness and bourbon. The taste is practically the same as the aroma with vanilla and bourbon being the most noticeable then some chocolate shows up. This is very smooth for the high ABV and simply put this is another bourbon barrel aged beer. This is not any different then other BBA Imp. Stouts and Im sure this question has been asked before but what makes this not an Imp. Stout? Seriously I want to know.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2010 I purchased this for $16 for a single bottle from a liquor store in the San Diego area, consumed with a friend in Portland, OR.  When I purchased this, it was something my future wife just threw in the basket because the RateBeer small advertisement next to it said 100 rating.  When I was in line, I saw the price and almost put it back.  Im very happy I didnt!  Aroma consisted of brandy, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, very sweet and it felt like there was 1000 aromas going on at the same time.  Appearance is  black with a thin brown head.  Taste consisted of chocolate, very sweet,  alcohol is definitely in the mix with a bourbon base, coconut, etc.  As with the aroma, theres about 1000 things going on with this beer and its very smooth...the ingredients arent fighting each other.  Very happy that I was able to have this.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2010 Shared bottle.  Very nice.  I wish I had more of this.  The aroma is bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, sweet.  The flavor is the same, with more oak.  The body is nice and thick, oily mouthfeel.   The finish is boozy, light pine.  Very good.
Pours a dark black. Big boozy bourbon aroma coming off this one. Sampled at a blind tasting. A slow sipper to share on a cold night.

Pours a black color with no head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, bourbon, and vanilla.  The dark fruit and vanilla on the nose mix awkwardly, to give it a somewhat off aroma.  Sweet syrup like taste up front.  Some bitters on the backend with notes of chocolate.  Too thin of a mouthfeel as well.  Needs more body.  Tasty, but a bit dissapointed with my first brew from Port Brewing.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10


Aroma: Nose was tons of bourbon (read: booze, booze, and more booze), vanilla, and some wood

Appearance: It pours an oily black color with a brown head and a bit of lace

Flavor: The taste is sweet and malty with a lots of bourbon flavor

Palate: This one is on the oily side, thick, heavy, and even a little chewy

Overall Impression: 
This beer was alright, but I just found it to be too boozy for my personal taste.  I have no qualms with many liking it more then I, and perhaps with more age it would have been more to my liking, but at this point in time it was just too much bourbon for me, if I want to drink bourbon, I wouldnt have opened a beer.  Anyway, I can see the appeal, and I still believe it deserves a solid score, just not one as spectacular as many have given it.

375 ml corkes bottle. A black beer with a very small, fully diminishing brown head. The aroma is moderately malty with a strong note of bourbon, other notes of roated grains, chocolate, alcohol, oak, vanilla, maybe some fruits and smoke. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly sour, lightly bitter. Again the bourbon is heavily present. Full body, flat carbonation, quite long finish with light to medium bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. Well, nice appearence (even without much head) and after all pleasant aroma, but too flat, boozy and the bourbon is too strong. I like bourbon barrel aged beers, but this is too much, I like my beer to be "more beer" than this. Drinkable in any case

Bottle. 

Pitch black, absolutely no head. 

The aroma is big and bold with lots of nutty bourbon, roasted malts, cookie dough, caramel and some alcohol. 

The flavor is sweet and warming. I love the integration of the dark caramel and cookie dough malty backbone and the bourbon in this one. Notes of chocolate, almonds and vanilla. Ends warming and bitter with lingering notes of bourbon.

Full-bodied and chewy. No carbonation whatsoever, which is really a shame since it is obvious that the flavors are hindered by this.

This is a real treat, but it would be so much better with a little Co2.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2010 2009 Vintage bottle. Pours almost pitch black, with just the slightest amount of brownish notes comming thorugh in the bottom of the glass. The head is barely there, just a dark brown bubbely lace. Aroma is mostly of whiskey, wood and alcohol. But also some darkfruit. The flavor is of whiskey, wood, oak, alcohol, roasted malts, vanilla and darkfruits especially prunes. The body is full, with a fairly thick mouthfeel, but carbonation wise, it is dead flat. Overall a good, but really big beer, that you might want to rate as a spirit instead.

Bottle. Big, thick, black/deep brown colour with no head. Aroma of strong oak, bourbon, dark fruits and berries, vanilla, rum, figs, red wine and cherries. Thick taste of heavy oak, cherry, wine, figs, alcohol, vanilla and liquorice. Very oily texture, huge body, no carbonation, medium-long duration. Complex and interesting, but overly sweet and too flat for my taste, while also being a little chaotic and discordant.

Bottle. Black color with thin head. Aroma is strong and complex: chocolate, bourbon, oak with pungent alcohol. Taste is deep and polyhedric: liquorice, dark chocolate, prune, vanilla, bourbon. Full body with oily texture. Excellent beer. Long lasting dry and warm aftertaste.

Boy, was I looking farward to trying this beer, and oh boy, was I disappointed BIG time. Bottle, 37,5 cl. Opaque deep brown with no head. Nose has a lot of oak, bourbon, alcohol, very overdone on the aging. Soy sauce, small vanilla. Notes of the rich fruitiness of an amarone, with figs, prunes. Aroma is rather nice, but overdone on the aging. The taste is huge. Oak, bourbon, vanilla, soy sauce, small hints of coffee in the after, dried dark fruits. The mouthfeel is poor. It is flat, but it doesnt manage to compliment that with the mouthfeel, and the taste notes dont manage either. A big let down for me.

Back -N- Black  Brouwers Café  Seattle Beer Week 2010
Aroma  Thick bourbon barrel and large amounts of alcohol.   
Appearance  Black in color, Clear with a thin brown sugar head.   
Flavor   Rich dark malts with smoke, bourbon and coffee flavors.   
Palate    Dry finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  One big tasty bourbon barrel aged brew.  Loved it.

Beermerchants order (again!). Poured from bottle into goblet glass. Very thinning head. Opaque surface. Black colour with a colour resembling brown sugar on the edge. Black tan colour. Texture is silky and smooth. Lacing is fantastic. A little rough and nutty around the palate. I get dark guey chocolate like Galaxy chocolate, vanilla, oak, wood, roasted malts and oil. A nice soft carbanation. Really enjoying this one. I am so glad Phil stocked this again. Damn back log of beers to re-buy just to rate. This is one excellent beer. Thoroughly good lacing. . Edit. Definitely getting bourbon through the body as I drink this. Buffalow Trace style.  MMMMM. Thanks a ton Phil for stocking this still. Its superb.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Jet black pour with no head. Low carbonation. Rich aromas of dark chocolate, raisins, bourbon, very vinous. Dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, smooth bourbon feel, really warms the throat. Pleasing alcohol burn sweetness. Very smooth caresses the throat as it slides down. Vinous, sweet throat warming finish. Definately one to take your time over. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2010 Draft at Brouwers.  Very black, dark brown bubbles.  Sweet bourbon, dark fruit, and chocolate nose on it.  Oily, slightly creamy feel to this.  Very smooth stuff, loads of bourbon and dark chocolate.  Lots of dark fruit, sticky dates and dried black cherry.  The finish is primarily wood and dry chocolate.  Excellent brew... I dont think Id shell out for a bottle, but sampling it on draft is more than worthwhile.

375 ml bottle; 2008 vintage via Sinners Club; thin jet black with fluffy dark brown head fading slowly; intense nose of chocolate cake, oak, bourbon and candy apples; texture is thin and a little oily on the teeth and glass; decadent roast with creamy bourbon, chocolate; level of bourbon is just about perfect to me as it complements rather than dominates; Old Viscosity itself is a rich, decedent brew and this just ups the ante; chocolate and dark fruits with honey, oatmeal and vanilla; very nice

(Bottle, 2009 vintage, from Systembolaget) Poured black and oily. Formed no head. Aroma contained malts, vanilla, oak and roastedness. Palate was full bodied, oily and bit dry with low carbonation. Flavours were roastedness, vanilla, sweetness, liquorice, alcohol, chocolate and mild bitterness. Aftertaste contained sweetness and vanilla.

Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting.  Pours a still deep dark black, no head.  Huge vanilla and wood and bourbon.  Chocolate and cocoa, vanilla.  Big chocolate malted milkshake.  Thinner than expected, though given the stillness maybe it shouldnt be a surprise.  Nice smooth malt and roast, toffee and caramel, big vanilla tones.  Really yummy, but the stillness is a bit of a problem.  Finishes with more soft vanilla and chocolate pudding.
Black of color with a very small head. Am aroma of liqurice, dark fruits and prunes. A flavor of liqurice, port and alcohol.

Pours dark brown in color. Smell is absolutely heavenly and among the best Ive smelt in a stout. Reminds me of the nose on the Bells BA Expo/Double Cream blend! The taste is pretty damn close as well. This is truly a very incredible beer. Could use just a smidgen more thickness in the mouthfeel. The barrel aging is done to perfection. A very good vanilla and oak smell. This was easiily the best beer of the night.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2011 16oz goblet draft from "The Tap Room" in San Diego. Poured a jet black color with very little head. Aromas are alcohol, plums, oak, bourbon, and dark chocolate. The taste is immediately alcohol, it burns your throat on the way down. Ive had plenty of 10%+ alcohol beers and this one hid it much less well than others at 20%. Its like drinking a fine port wine. This is definitely a sipper and should be enjoyed one at a time. There is some oak in the taste along with whiskey!, black cherries, roasted malts, and vanilla. Its really good but potent. It grew on my the more I drank. Im really happy I found this and would recommend it to anyone thats looking for a dessert beer or something to have on a cold night.

2009 bottling enjoyed April 2010.  

Poured opaque black with no head, and only a faint rim layer of small bubbles.  As observed on the palate as well - another carbonation problem, and it has suitably impacted the appearance and mouthfeel scores.

Nose has an appetizing bourbon-boozy vanilla/caramel note.  Once on the palate a rich dark sugary caramel comes through and also reminds me of coconut.  Virtually no carbonation on the palate.  Flavors continue to the finish with plenty of bourbon booziness.

aquired via trade with boltz7555. Thanks JASON for this unbelievable brew!  black pour with no head. nutty, chocolate aroma with hints of marshmallow, cream, oak, and booze. large bourbon-bathed raison finish..amazing bourbon flavor with huge raison, licorice, and milk...very much like an imperial porter, aged nicely.  creamy, enveloping mouthfeel. wonderful brew

First batch that was sitting in my cellar courtesy of Zug4abby. I think this is 2006. Pours a dark brown black with no head and almost no carbonation.. Nice aroma of dark fruits and sherry. Full bodied with a slick texture and extremely soft carbonation. Flavor of sherry, dark carmelized sugars, dark fruits, and vanilla. Hops have faded out, and just a hint of roast is left. Warming and tame oaky finish.  Not bad, but I wish I had consumed this fresh. I did have a fresher sample at Lost Abbey Ratebeer summer gathering and it was much better- more hops and less sherry. This just goes to show, DONT age barrel aged beers, especially ones that rely on hops to contribute to the overall impression.

March Madness tasting -

Aroma:  Just amazingly intense, yet smooth and alluring at the same time.  This is how a beer can cross all kinds of barriers, and still be stellar.  Huge notes of maple, oak, bourbon, chocolate malt balls, and roasted coffe.  I could smell this for days.

Appearance:  Ink black, thick consistency...looks like the gravity still clocks in at a hefty 1.150!  Head was small but creamy, light brown in color, spotty bubbles, drippy lacing.

Taste:  Oh man, I "hated" having to share this 5 ways but you know...its worth it.  Bourbon-y goodness, molasses, dark chocolate, black licorice, oak, brown sugar, figs, Almond-Joy...all super-smooth and extremely supple.  Nothing clonks you over the head but everything is assertive as all get-out.  Might be the best thing to come out of Port Brewing that Ive had.

Thanks to Tweety for sharing this bottle with me...  [Vintage 2008] Poured black with no head.  Aroma had port or sherry-like qualities.  Flavors were very raisiny, plum, and/or prune-like.  Thinner body than expected.  Other flavors of chocolate, soy sauce and a little bit of alcohol in the finish.

Sampled at Feb 2010 Indy tasting - Aroma is deep dark malts, vanilla and dark chocolate.  The flavor is crazy full of of chocolate malts and vanilla.  Palate is smooth and creamy.  Wow a fantastically tasty beer.  I have to admit, by this point in the tasting, I was feeling it.  But this beer still blew me away.  I want more!

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Murky chocolate-brown body, thin buff head. Heavy, rich nose, with tannic oak and strong bourbon, concentrated raisins and prunes, heavy, burnt caramel, molasses, and alcohol. The alcohol packs serious heat in the body, which is dominated by oak and bourbon, backed by chocolate, prune, and raisin. Rich but not overly viscous. The long medicinal, licorice/tobacco finish becomes tiresome after a few sips. That flaw aside, this is a very nice beer.

2008 bottle thanks to Pepsican. Pours a deep black with tons of great head and lace, lots and lots of beautiful lace. The aroma is plenty of bourbon and chocolate with some nice floral notes, but the alcohol is really overbearing in the aroma. The flavor is nice bitter dark chocolate with the bourbon kept well in the background with a great burnt toast finish remarkably roasty and rich. The whiskey opens up a lot as this gets swirled around but it never at any time tastes like a bourbon bomb. Creamy full palate, very rich, amazingly easy to drink.

Beautiful head. 2008. Very smooth roasted flavors. Velvety chocolate that goes on forever. Awesome black patent comes through in the back of the finish. Aroma has a bit too much fruit. Bourbon barreling is subtle but nice. Flavor starts with de-bittered black malt-ness.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 On tap at Bavarian Lodge. Pours a thick dark brown with a small head. The aroma is heavy, nuanced bourbon. No subtlety here. Thick palate with a sophisticated, woody bourbon flavor. How much one enjoys bourbon is directly proportional as to how much one enjoys this beer. Think fine sippin KY whisky with all the oak, vanilla, and cigar flavors with a hearty backbone of malty flavors of chocolate and bread. Truly enjoyable slow drinking beer.

Pours dark brown with only a smattering of large bubbles. Not a good sign. The aroma is hugely boozy with bourbon whiskey, nuts, chocolate, figs, dates , and raisins. The flavor is very thick and rich with malts and booze. The massive bourbon presence overpowers this beer. Theres a little bit of chocolate, nuts, and dark fruit in there. Very thick and rich, but completely flat. I admit it, Im one that really needs the prickliness of the carbonation to enjoy most beers (except Angels Share) so this was a bit disappointing for me. Love Old Viscosity though.

2009 Bottle from Kris Wines, London. Shared with Slothez on the Amsterdam ferry. Nice looking bottle and an aptly named beer. Like pouring out a glass of Texas tea. Nose had vanilla, dark chocolate, liquorice and bourbon. Slid down luxuriously full, smooth and warming. Flavour was quite sweet, with all the elements from the aroma and more. Woody notes jostled with booze, roasted malt, fruit and spices. Terrific lingering bitter finish.  Top class stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2010 Draft at Teresas. Pours deep mahogany brown with an oily, slick surface and a razor thin white lacy head. Aroma is very similar to Angels Share; bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and roasty malts. Body is full and rich, but not as thick as expected. Silky, slightly smokey palate. Finish has a touch of hop bitterness and a nice warming in the throat. Excellent American strong.

Well, this damn thing is about two years old now....Pours jet black and smells lightly like cardboard, raisins and caramel malt. Past its prime to me.  Watery and malty and lacking body. But the basic flavor is there. caramel, light hops, some faint vanilla nad chocolate. Good, but not what it should be.

Bottle with special thanks to coyotehunter for sharing.  Weve put this off the last few meetings, so here it is.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head and aromas that are a bit on the weak side as far as Im concerned.  Im in the minority on this, but all Im picking up are some faint cardboard, brown sugar and booze.  Flavors are pretty sweet and boozy... kind of a brown sugar and booze with a little bit of a sour edge to the finish.  Didnt see that coming and it makes things interesting.  Kind of a not-quite-ripe plum flavor.  Mouthfeel is thin, yet sticky.  Finish is boozy and slightly sour.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle, courtesy footbalm. Aroma one of the more bourbon-powerful of the ilk but more notably one of the most vinous and complex with notes from fresh berries to intensely dark chocolate to molasses to graham cracker and toffee and finally just-right notes of vanilla and wood. Flavor again has a ton of bourbon, even to the point of a slight burn, but is also like chewing on a once again very dark bar of chocolate. The oak remains, very earthy and mature-seeming, as well as rich malty notes, almost bready even at times. As the beer warmed the alcohol took over a bit and made me wish I hadnt savored it as much, but either way, an excellent barrel-aged brew.

Bottle from TheCheeseMan. Cheers! Cork comes off with just a slight fizz. Pours almost still, lightdevouring black, some dark brown bubbles but they fade fast. Swirling the glass leaves brown tinged legs on the glass walls. Aroma is big, I caught a lot of aromas from the glass while it was still on the table. Surprisingly big on wood, loads of spice, quite a bit of alcohol, liquorice, oxidized notes, dark fruity notes, vanilla, almost perfumy in the vanillaness. Some caramel as well, or perhaps suryp. Surprisingly mellow on the bourbon. Initially very sweet on the tongue, it dries up quite a bit in the finish because of the alcohol which almost abrasive, a bit like drinking a pure spirit. Thick and viscous, with just a slight hint of prickling on the tongue, so not entirely flat. Most definitely a sipper, Im an hour in and still got quarter of a bottle left. I got to say, the aroma is amazing, but on the tongue its a bit too rough.

2009 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with just a smidge of head.  Aroma of bourbon, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, oak, nougat, maple syrup, coffee.  Flavor seems a little less complex and more muddy in my mouth -- still plenty of bourbon with sweet malt, lots of syrupy molasses and vanilla.  So overall, I guess I wasnt so impressed with it, although it is a lot better than lots of other bourbon barrel-aged beers.
7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

Black with absolutely no head. Strong aromas of bourbon, alcohol, wood, dust, oil and vanilla. Flat and watery palate. Sweet malty flavours with notes of vanilla and wood. If you are into the bourbon-beer scene, then this is probably a great beer.

Bianca and Thierry, mayn thx. For tasting day 20.02.2010. 
We tasted also this special bottle. 
Dark brown to black color, with a brown head. 
Aroma strong roasted malts, complex, coffee, alcoholic.
 Medium to full body. Taste sweet, roasted malts, alc.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010 On draft at Sheffields. Pours a deep, dark brown with the only remnants of a light brown head clinging to the sides of the glass. Smells like coconut and cinnamon, signifying oak, and also smells of bourbon. The malts smell very dark and toasted. Coffee and chocolate dominate the palate with the roasted flavors coming through on the back. The alcohol is present, but it is a little better integrated than other beers of this style I have had young on draft. The palate is very big, but not oily. The finish goes on for a long time. This is a very high quality beer, and I love this style with some more age. I hope to pick up a bottle for cellaring.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2011 Draught at Back country. UPdate. THis beer is awesome, awe-inspiring, and totally shocking. Worthy of all the great praise and attention. A hugely boozy, demanding, bourbon bomb with enough chocolate, dark fruits, syrupy sweetness and general shock factor to wreck a train, this bad boy is fierce and just maybe UNSTOPPABLE.

  Draught from Mountain Sun. Black/brown with thin tan head. Aroma of coco powder, booze, syrup and an almost medicine-like smell. Flavor is big coco and booze with thicker beer (almost chunky) texture. Also a little medicine-like in taste but otherwise big chocolate and booze in a big bad beer.

Pours a thick dark brown, looks like chocolate syrup or motor oil,(go figure). No head, just a couple bubbles. Caramel malt whiskey sweet aroma. Flavor of caramel, bitter chocolate, wood, whiskey, toast, molasses, soy sauce. Full bodied. Dry, oily, touch of bitter chocolate finish. Not well rounded, and not overly  smooth. This brew has tons of character, in fact it is a league all its own, but not that great.

Sampled from the bottle at the 2010 February Circle City Tasting. Poured black with no head. Aroma had notes of wood, bourbon, dark grains and chocolate. Flavor was similar with a strong bourbon note, dark chocolate and coffee. The beer was near flat.
2009 bottle:Pours dark brown. No head, no carbonation. Aroma is all oak and boubron. Flavour is oak and bourbon with notes of soy sauce and liquorice. Boozy finish.

Had two bottles. First was amazing, with the fullest yet drinkable body Ive ever had, luscious, a sort of sensual vanilla scented panther ready to fiercely savage you if you dont show her the respect her velvety body deserve. A dessert. A dream. A night of chocolate passion. A vanilla sniff of beatitude. A "bourbony" chunk of heaven. 
The second shows more deeply her barrel aged character, being less bodied and more aggressive and difficult to tame. 
Both Amazing.

A: The bottle opened with a slight pop and the pour was lowly carbonated, but did feature some bubbles. The beer itself is viscous and black with a minimal tan colored head.

S: The nose is very nice with notes of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee. Perhaps a little bit of alcohol heat, but nothing overwhelming.

T: The great nose did not quite translate to the flavor. The flavor is very heavy on the bourbon, with the chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt flavors coming through more as the beer warms up. Unfortunately, so does the alcohol.

M: The body is full, and the carbonation is sufficient for the style, but could use some more bubbles.

D: This beer can be one of my absolute favorites, but this iteration of it is a bit disappointing. The alcohol comes through just a bit too much, unfortunately, but I would still recommend this beer and drink it any time.

Bottle from After4ever. Pours a oily slick dark brown color with no head. Nose is dark fruit, chocolate and bourbon and alcohol. Palate is slick with a light fizz and a burning throat. More nose notes of wood and vanilla. Flavor is bourbon, chocolate malt, vanilla, woody oak notes, and a very dry alcohol finish.
Consumed at EBF. Aroma consists of molasses, caramel, chocolate, coffee and toffee. There is also a huge candied sugar flavor (candy apple coating).

Appearance: 3/5
Pitch black liquid. It was completely flat with just a few bubbles floating on the surface and it left no lacing.

Smell: 8/10
Red wine, port wine, dried fruit, whisky, booze and yeast.

Taste: 8/10
Wine, nuts, wood, chocolate, whisky and coconut.

Mouthfeel: 3/5
Smooth with no carbonation. Had a noticeable alcoholic feeling that dried my mouth up.

Comment:
As I poured this I was quite surprised as it didnt look like Old Viscosity. It was completely flat and when I smelled it the first thing that came to mind was port wine. I had a glass of red wine available compared the two and there where several similarities. After tasting it I realised it had allot of red wine flavours. But also whisky and a mix of other alcoholic beverages.

Not sure what would fit with this beer but I imagine the same thing that works with strong red wines, or port wines, with lots of flavour.

This was an unexpected and interesting experience. I expected the same beer only with some wood and whisky flavour. But this version was a completely different beer.I quite enjoyed it though.

Black color, flat, no head. Phenolic aroma, chemicals, roasted malts, chocolate, light apples. Strong body, oily mouthfeel, very salty; there is liquorice flavor in the front, then sweet caramel, and some chocolate; alcoholic. Drinkable, but too salty and flat.

Sampled from a 12.7 oz brown corked bottle this beer poured a black color with only the faintest trace of a brown head that dissipated quickly. The aroma was very strong and sharp port wine, wood and anise and had undertones of chocolate and tannins. Complex but a bit off. The flavor was bitter and very woody with strong anise and moderate port wine, raisin, tobacco and chocolate. The finish was long with bitter woodiness. The body was flat and a touch thin. Fairly boozy. Interesting but a disappointment compared to the regular Old Viscosity.

15-FEB-2010, bottle @home, from "Barley Wine".
Very exited to see what this is:) Not easy to find, and quite expensive, so I really hope for something special.
And it is...
...it pours almost black with an yellow edge, and oh - no head at all. Is this really strong ale? It looks like stout. You can tell the viscosity and density just from swirling the beer in the glass.
Beautifull color, and the yellow reflections are special, but a beer should have some sort of head (!) so only a 4 for appearance.
Wonderfull vanilla and chocolate nose, some roasted coffee, but mostly the barrels come through. Thats an 8 for aroma.
Taste is very complex with leather, tobacco and liqourice. Best tasting beer ever? 10 for taste.
Palate is difficult to rate. No carbonation at all, and a beer should have that(! - again), but at the same time the most dense beer I can imagine. And the alcohol is doing things to my mouth that I enjoy. It can really be felt, but is still quite well integrated.. How do you rate that? I end with up with 3 for palate.
Overall, maybe the best beer ever? With some carbonation in this beer it could easily be my number one, but now I end up giving it 4.4 all in all.
What is it with the carbonation, anyway? Has it gone due to the long travel time? Or was it never there?
Well, next time I see something from Port Brewing, I will be buying without hesitation.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Its younger brother - Old Viscosity is a high class beer - its yummie. To be saved in bourbon barrels and thus knocked up with vanilla like sweetness normally doesn´t do  much good for either stouts or strong ales. But lets give it a shot. The cork vitness of very low on carbonation when popped - or these one didn´t pop..it had to be squeezed off. The pour is brown differs to a brownie blackness. No head. The nose is so packed with the bourbonbarrels. The vanilla i smassive but there is also spices, tobacco and some roastyness with some plums or raisins in liquor. The taste is better than most borbon aged I have had. The sweetness and vanilla / marzipan-like taste is not that overwhelming and it leaves room for other notes. . There is some mild smokyness, leather and tobacco notes. The palate is oily like the containes of the engine from the truck on the label. The alcohol is picking your tounge and leaves a long bitter and roasted finish. Certainly a good beer - and a aged one where there still is some balance - thats nice. Still I guess I prefer the normal version though. Cheers
bottle, pours black, no head, and very oily.  Strong oak and bourbon aroma.  Flavor is huge vanilla and sweet bourbon with some of the roasty base beer in the background.  Hot to death and I love it.

Bottle - Pour is deep black with a small tan head and little carbonation. The nose is mainly bourbon whiskey with some oak, vanilla, and fudge. The taste is big,  boozey, chocolate, and a hint of vanilla. ive had this on tap at the brewery and enjoyed even better with a little carbonation

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 Draft, Toronado.  I really love this beer.  Ive had it three times now and have enjoyed it more with every taste.  This time, I got a glass to settle my stomach from a night of sours at Toronados RR -tion night (a 16 oz pour for $6 - bless that bar).  This beer pulls off thick and rich better than any other beer that Ive tried.  The bourbon note is big and strong, but it doesnt get in the way of the underlying stout.  In fact, I find the oaky bourbon flavor balances the beer quite nicely.  The beer is rich with coffee, cocoa, prunes and brown sugar, yet its not sticky or cloying.  Its definitely a slow sipper.  The mouthfeel is velvety smooth. Fantastic.

Bottle shared at puzzls place: Near black pour with a wispy dark khaki film of head. Huge rummy aroma with a bourbon sweetness and huge oak. A hint of tobacco is in there as well after it breathes a bit. Slick body, but not cloying. Very oaky flavor with a big bourbon presence. Less boozy in the flavor than anticipated from the aroma. Some raisiny richness and residual oak. A hint of tobacco with residual oak on the back. A giant with drinkability.

shared at Andys tasting -  pours black wtih round edges (whatever that means- damn you handwritten notes). Arouma is prunes and licorice, strong flavor. Body is light cream, thick molasses, finishes bitter.

Pour is deep black with a small tan head and no carbonation. The nose is mainly bourbon whiskey with some oak, vanilla, and fudge. The taste is BIG on boozey whiskey, chocolate, and a hint of vanilla. A really great ASA with a great whiskey flavor, kind of like a less intense Lost Abbey Angels Share.

#1,800.  Bottle - big thanks to a previous secret Santa.  Pours pitch black with a huge fluffy tan head.  Nose is predominantly bourbon - cherry, wood, vanilla.  There is some cocoa in there too but it is mostly that overdone barrel aged character that so many ba beers fall victim to.  Flavor is bourbon, a bit of cocoa, some tootsie roll, a good amount of vanilla and a bunch of booze.  The finish has that milky quality that I often find in BA impy stouts.  This is nice, but nowhere near as good as the regular Old Viscosity.

Bottle, kindly shared by GrOve.  A thin layer of tan bubbles upon an opaque, near black body. Aroma is roasted dark malts, quite rounded, with a pleasant chocolate scent and notes of wood, dried dark fruits and soy sauce. Taste is full malty and chocolatey with hint of beef stock. Quite vinous, or maybe just a boozy and wooden touch from the bourbon barrels. Some roasted notes, some licorice, and a fair amount of earthy bittering hops and dried dark fruits underneath. Thick in the mouth, quite smooth, too. Big alcohol warmth in the finish.

courtesy of fiulijn - pours a dark black colour with no head retention; roasted chocolatey aroma, notes of alcohol and nut; very sticky and oily (what a surprise!), full-bodied, very low carbonation; solid bitterness, long chocolatey roasted and nutty aftertaste with warming alcohol notes - powerful
Bottle thanks ryan for sharing. Black pour with a white ring of head. No real pop when the bottle opened. Vanilla, oak, bourbon, chocolate and dark fruit, some warming.

For some reason Ive owned about 10 of these and have never drank or rated one.  Woops.  Rating 900.  Black pour with a nice sized tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, vanilla,  and oak.  Flavor is heavy oak, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, and just a touch of molasses.  Finishes dry with a good bit of carbonation.  Id almost like a touch less carbonation for the style,  but still very good.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2012 Dark brown pour, no head.
Extreme port aroma, with liquorice, smoke and spices.
Deep smokey liquorice, whiskey and burned wood flavour. Intense.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Pitch black with no head.
Frutiy oaked aroma; loads of bourbon.
Thick and oily palate. Almost flat. Smooth.
Chocolate, coffe, licorice, tar. Extremely full-bodied. Complex with vanilla and oak.

No head. Opaque black body. Fruity plummy wooden aroma with notes of dates and soy sauce. Dry-sweetish earthy vinuous alcoholic chocolatey taste with vanilla notes. Full body. Hottish mouthfeel. Dry earthy chocolatey plums aftertaste with alcohol and vanilla notes. Nice and unusual. (0.376l bottle, shared by Ole_R.)

Bottle at Retorps LA tasting.  Poured black with a creamy brown head.  Nose is vinous, with notes off bourbon, vanilla, wood, anise, and tobacco.  Full body with a creamy mouth feel and medium carbonation.  This really is a stunning beer, very complex and decadent.  At first sip I was assaulted by huge notes of fudge, bourbon, and dark roasted malt, as I progressed I got vanilla, fig, currant, coconut, anise, tobacco, and booze.  Very smooth and balanced for such a massive beer.  Slight bitter finish.
@ Beertemple. Black colored brew. Alcoholic nose, licorice. Flavor is bourbon, port, licorice, some whiskey/peat. Smooth and silky, one to sip.

Bottle shared by Ben aka ShareANeveda. Poured dark brown with a moderate frothy brown head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt, woody with a small alcohol aroma. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Heavy bourbon woody and malt sweet flavor with a heavy bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

I drank this from 2009 version 375ml bottle into my Rochefort chalice. 

The beer pours a very dark black with hardly any light showing through on the edges. It looks very oily, and pours with no head what-so-ever which is disappointing. 

The aroma is strong and awesome. Tons of malts attacking my senses. There is tons of vanilla, with a little oak, snd bourbon that burns your nose. 

The taste is very nice, medium bodied and complex. It starts out sweet with vanilla and finishes with tons of vanilla/bourbon.

The feel is light, totally not as viscous as it protrays itself.

Very drinkable.

Overall, this is very good. One of the best oak aged RIS with tons of bourbon flavor. If you like that vanilla/bourbon this is where you go. For me to be world class needs a head, and better feel overall. Its very similar to GIBCS, but not quite there yet.

Bottle at The Beertemple, Amsterdam. Pours pitch black with almost no head. Very intense aroma of bourbon, leather, salt and port. Flavor is salt, with port and peat. Quite salty finish. Very strong and intense brew but almost without carbonation.

Pours black, and completely flat. Aroma is strong of bourbon, with some nice roasted malt. Its viscous and thick on the palate, and rather delicious. My only wish is that there had been even a little carbonation. Still a really tasty brew.

Bottle 2009 from my secret santa must have been good this year.  Pours a good black with no head at all.  So naturally no lacing.  Has an intense aroma of alcohol, bourbon, vanilla, smokey, malts, and sweet licorice.  Has a very light carbonation.  The flavor is good.  A good burn but not too much.  REally dances on the tongue.  Changes evrytime on the tongue.  Some bitter , then sweet, it is a taste experiance.  Has a full body.  The texture is thick like motor oil.  Has a great finish with a good aftertaste.  This is a real good beer.

Bottle, 375ml - Opaque black beer with no head. Aroma is malty with notes of cocoa powder, espresso, licorice, spices and some alcohol. Flavor is malty with notes of cocoa, coffee, spices, alcohol, vanilla and salty oak. Great, great beer. Almost a 4.4.

Bottle shared by OleR.
Stock cubes, lovely smoke. Vanilla, burboun, salt. Warming alcohol.

Crushed on tap at Homemade Liquids and Solids.  Surprised the hell out of me that it was there, but what a fucking surprise!  Huge in all ways.  Inky, thick, bourbony, awesome.  One hell of a beer experience.

Una bestia! questa birra è un esempio eccellente di barrel aged... al naso si sente subito il legno intriso della botte e le complesse note tostate.. in bocca è molto elegante e prevalgono le sensazioni del legno, del bourbon, del tabacco e un calore alcolico considerevole... eccezzionale!

Bottle. Black,no head. Milk chocolaty aroma. Dark malts. Taste is also milk choclaty (due to the oak aging?). Also dark malts, soy, liqour filled bonbons etc. Thick and oily texture. Relative easy to drink for a beer of this style.

2009 bottle.
Pours black- brown with a blank surface.

Taste of chocolate and liqour filled bonbons.
bottle thanks to mar.  poured black with ruby edges.  aroma was bourbon, vanilla, and alcohol.  flavor was dark roast, bourbon, and vanilla with a rather light body.

(bottle from Sparky27, thanks Eric!) Pours an inky jet black with a light tan head that retains well.  Aromas of roasted barley, bittersweet chocolate, smoke, bourbon, vanilla, wood, and plums soaked in booze.  Plenty of alcohol on the nose too, but theres enough here to provide a counterbalance to the heat.  The tastes follow the aromas with roasted barley, chocolate, bourbon, and plenty of smoke and charred wood on the finish.  I think these flavors on the finish overpower some of the other flavors.  Mouthfeel is smooth with a medium to full body.  Light, but not still carbonation.  A good beer indeed, but much like the regular Old Vis., it was still underwhelming.

Bottle (37 cl) from Systembolaget. Dark brown to black, no head. Salty roasted aroma with overwhelming vanilla oak notes, and some whisky. Flat and lifeless. Sweet and salty with a dry finish. Extremely overrated.

2008 bottle thanks to captain Cougar.  Pours a thick, oily black with a light-brown head.  Nose is wonderful chocolate and fruit.  Taste is incredible!  Chocolate, fruit and subtle bourbon.  Mouthfeel is medium-thick and dry, with some alcohol warmth.  This one has carbonation!  Yay!  Very complex and very, very nice!

2009 bottle. This beer pours a deep black with a very slight amount of bubbles, nearly flat but not completely as most people are reporting (perhaps I got lucky) tiny bubbles continued to rise along the edge of my glass through the entire drink but not enough to form any sort of head or ring of carbonation.  The aroma was a massive shot of chocolate and vanilla notes with a deep earthy and oak smell. Bourbon is an obvious factor in this beer as well and its character shows here. Taste was complex full of dark chocolate with vanilla and a powerful oak and bourbon flavor towards the finish. As the beer warmed the flavors melded and became more mellow and blended, a very nice plus for this beer as it seems only the best of beers mellow and flesh out nicely as the warm and sit. My last 10 or so sips were amazing! Amazing flavors I can only imagine what this would be like if it were fully and properly carbonated.

Tasted 2009-12-26. 2009 bottle. Pours pitch black with no head. Smokey port wine aroma. Tastes like a mix of a 30 year old tawny port and a smoked porter. It works big time. Drink it not like a beer but like a dessert wine. Treat it properly, and its a great drink.
scura no schiuma gastura quasi assente naso intenso alcolico liquore brandy affumicati whisky luppolo in bocca prepotente tostata ma anche inizialmente dolce poi complessa finale quasi balsamico

Courtesy Secret Santa- thanks man! What a complex and delicious beer...where to begin? The aroma was a huge chocolate/vanilla mix with a heavy oak presence. Pour was a deep dark black with no head or bubbles. Taste was incredibly complex. Dark chocolate with vanilla are strong with the oak and bourbon heavy in the aftertaste. Each sip throughout the whole beer was different. Only downfall to this beer was the fact that it was completely flat. A little carbonation wouldve gone a long way, but the great complex flavor more than made up for it. Delicious!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle, great inky brown with no head, aroma of ripe plum, chestnuts, raisin and 
butterscotch, flavors of bbq, prunes, fig, malty chocolate, nice sipper

On tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad. Black with a thin light brown head.  Aroma is mostly bourbon barrel with underlying malts, prune, raisin, chocolate. Taste is fantastic; cacao, oak, alcohol, roasted malt, bourbon, earth. Overall a very well done bourbon barrel aged beer. Hell yes.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2010 *re-rate* 10/17/10. 375ml bottel, 2010 edition as a sweet bonus from sage at the lost abbey tasting room. my goodness the 2010 is an absolutely wonderful beer, such an improvement from 2009, which i actually thought was quite good. tons more caramel, toffee, and chocolate with a better integrated bourbon presence and beautiful carbonation. awesome beer.

375ml bottle, 2009 release, from the lost abbey tasting room. pours an oily black with almost no head but a thin ring of brown bubbles leaving a bit of lacing. aroma is great with big notes of caramel malts, toffee, chocolate, and fine bourbon with notes of raisin bread, Myers rum, prune, date, and cinnamon cookies. flavor is delicious with big, oaked bourbon notes up front with chocolate malt, buttery toffee, vanilla, raisin, and more rum notes coming through late. palate is full bodied and contrary to popular belief i did find this to be CARBONATED, albeit very lightly, with a long, woody bourbon finish. overall, a damn nice brew.

Sampled at the ORF tasting thanks to whoever brought it!  Looks great.  Dark and syrupy.  Aroma of bourbon, soy, roasted malt.  Taste was basically the same... soy, bourbon, lots of booze.  Nice brew but something was off for me

Near black pour with no head.  Massive bourbon aroma with soy, black strap molasses, huge smoke note and lots of volatile alcohol.  The flavor is overwhelming charred oak, vanilla, soy sauce, and bitter dark chocolate.  The body is syrupy with low carbonation.  Man, this beer is just HUGE.

I am glad I have finally tasted this beer. On tap at Kellehers, Peoria. Black pour, like motor oil with a thin head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, coffee. Taste was smooth. Vanilla, bourbon, coffee. Nicely balanced. It lefta great taste in my mouth. A beer to enjoy. I didnt really taste the alcohol which suprised me due to the content. The aroma hung in the glass after the drink was done. I wished I had a dd so I could of had more.

Sampled on draft at Capones on 11/28/2009.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque. Looks like thick motor oil but is completely still without any bubbles or carbonation which is strange since this was on draft.

Dark roasted malt aroma with hints of bitter sweet dark chocolate, subtle coffee and a dominant bourbon presence. Hints of dark fruit and sweet alcohol. Slightly vinous.

Soft carbonation up front followed by slightly chewy medium roasted malt body. Lots of sweet bitter dark chocolate, toffee, subtle coffee and hints of dark fruit, especially grape, prune, raisin, plum and fig. Slightly vinous with sweet alcohol notes and a strong bourbon presence that lasts throughout. Subtle earthy oak tannis with a good bit of vanilla that helps cut down the bourbon heat but the flavor is pretty much dominated by the prominent bourbon character. Sweet and surprisingly not too hot at 12%. ABV decently masked but the bourbon presence gives it a lot of liquor taste. Overall pretty drinkable.

On tap at Capones. Black with a lasting beige head. This "beer" just screams bourbon. The nose is dominated by it with just glimpses of oak, vanilla, and chocolate peeking through. Bourbon is the major player in the flavor department as well, just a bit of vanilla and cocoa come through and they may have come from the bourbon. Body is medium-thin. Not at all impressed with the flavor but have to hand it to them for making this as smooth as it is. Would never have guessed that it is 12% abv.

On draft at Capones. Pours a clear dark brown colour with a slight beige head. Interesting aroma of maple syrup, dark fruits, oak and vanilla. Flavour is the same as the aroma. Has the flavour of maple cough syrup. I understand this is highly rated but I did not enjoy it.

2009 bottle.
no pop when uncorked, this pours completely flat. its brown-black and fairly thick.
aroma is of charcoal, bourbon, malt, chocolate milk, coffee, figs, roasted nuts, and smoke. 
flavor is sweeter, more chocolate milk, with a harsh alcohol front, biting middle and long bittersweet chocolate liquor finish.
the harsh coal elements persist throughout (should have aged it?), and this isnt really beer, but its interesting.
not sure how to rate something that looks, smells, and tastes like liquid charcoal.
also, body was disappointingly thin given the description of "sludge", but had a rich velvety smoothness.

Bottle 375ml. @ DØE Tasting, Fox & Hounds, Holstebro.Clear dark brown color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, light light brown head. Aroma is roasted, chocolate, coffee, light burnt, cocus, red wine - bourbon, wood - vanilla, driied fruit. Flavor is heavy sweet, light light red wine acidic and heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light moderate alcoholic - bourbon. [20090929]

At Brouwers Cafe in Seattle as a special treat from @trevor211 at my US homecoming. The pour is beautiful with a nicely subtle head. Nose is very boozy, and bourbon, wood and smoky chocolate. Tastes exactly like bourbon was poured on top! Leathery and full taste, but the body is remarkably light. flavor is there but the whole package is a bit under wrought. Not my fave but impressive, up there with the big bourbony stouts buts not complete.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 My Bottom Line:
Vanilla-like bourbon notes add depth to this strong ales molasses-bearing malts, as surreptitious miso notes brush roasted and chocolatey flavors. This is one serious creation.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam surrounds the darkness.
-The body is marvelously rich yet never tiresome. Gum-lickin good!
-Alcohol heat is emboldened by the barrel flavors.
-Carbonation is rather low, which works with the wealthy but calculated dextrins.

Bottles.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/06/2009
Vanilla and bourbon aroma. Dark coloured strong in alcohol and malty with a little dryness in a warming bitter finish.

20091120  Thanks to Dickinsonbeer for this big black brute.  What a punch in the face this beer is.  Hugely delicious, potent, goes great with Rachel Ray and 30 Minute Meals.  I dont know if thats true, but Paul insists.  Great use of the bourbon and wood.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brownish black with a wine-like ruby highlight and no nead- very low carbonation.  Aroma is fresh bourbon, caramel, chocolate, toast, roasty, nuts, leather, earthy, alcohol, licorice, woody, vanilla,.  Flavor is mineral, chocolate, bourbon, vanillla, oak, toast, sweet brown sugar, molasses, and alcohol.  A bit messy and nothing working together very well- alcohol is high, still hot, and not mellow- unsure of the year, but I thought it was older, but seems pretty fresh- and typically undercarbonated compared to some other bottles I have had in the past.  OK

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Chocolate, licorice, whisky and vanilla aroma. Black colour, light brown tiny head, fair lace. Very sweet, salty, chocolate, licorice, vanilla, whisky,  nice bitterness, hint of banana, complex. Sticky, cloying, warming. Impressive and powerful.

375ml bottle at Monks Cafe.  Black, inky liquid with a spitty tan head that was very faint around the outside of the glass.  Aroma was big wood, brown sugar, molasses, some toast, vanilla, bourbon.  Flavor is heavy on the vanilla, bourbon, wood, molasses, toasted malts.  The finish is slick, a little boozy.  Nice.

bottle @ 4:20 Birra straordinaria, fuori dagli schemi, ,scura, impenetrabile e con pochissima schiuma; complessità olfattiva estremamente interessante e molto ampia. Oltre al cioccolato al cacao, si avvertono caramello, vanignlia, liquirizia, confetture di  frutta estremamente concentrate e zuccherine. Al  palato VISCOSA non carbonata, straordinaria, morbida,singolare  e unica..Davvero una grandissima birra!!

pours a black with a blood red tint, no head, and a little lacing.

smell is of alcohol, cocoa, and brandy.

taste is strong, thick, dark fruits, and cocoa, ends dry and a little bitter.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Pours black with just a few bubbles on top. The aroma is godly whisky, caramel, vanilla, chocolate and coconut. The flavours intensify the aromas with slightly more emphasis on coconut and vanilla. Oily and smooth, soft as velvet. Deep, complex and oily- a wonderful balsam.

Once at GABF 2009 then again at the Lost Abbey Barrel Tasting.  Pours dark brown from the carafe, slightly translucent if you hold it up to the light, with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is bourbon, roast, caramel, and vanilla.  Flavor is complex and excellent with roast, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, toffee, fig, raisin, and of course bourbon.  A little boozy, but damn it, I like it.  Viscous on the palate (who would have guessed?) with low carbonation and a slick, syrupy mouthfeel.  Amazing beer.

FoBAB tasting.  Pours a translucent dark brown with a lacy, light tan head. Plenty of bourbon barrel plus some caramel in the nose. Medium body and light carbonation. Oaky vanilla in the taste, along with roasted nuts and cookie dough. Dry, oaky finish.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 Bottled at home. Opaque black, no head whatsoever. Super complex nose, malts, caramel, dark fruit, liquorice, liquor and much more. Complex flavor as well, pretty sweet but the flavor is developing during every sip, bitter and alcoholic, but also malts, coffee, liquorice and some wood-notes. This stuff is extremely good. Thanks you caesar for suggesting to buy this, i just cant get enough of this.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 Bottle, 2009 Vintage. Nice beer, but more like a mild whisky. Pours black with zero head and almost no carbonation. Had it head to head with Yule Smith, and I preferred the Yule Smith. Very complex and interesting beer. Aroma very boozy, whisky notes, smokey. Mouthfeel is boozy, syrupy. Taste is bourbon, oaky, vanilla, coffee and nice licorice finish.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2011 this beer smells like delicious whiskey then explodes with deliciousness into my mouth

Pours a black liquid with no head. Smell is extremly rich and very complex with lots of vanilla-like notes of oak, some caramel and a bit of alcohol. The taste has a lot of alcohol, oak barrels and vanilla along with some heavily roasted malt. Somewhere, the flavour fails to keep up with the aroma, but this is still an amazing beer.

bottle, thank you very much Allen! Deep brown colour with no head. Very complex aroma of caramel, songle malt whisky with a touch of smoke and dark berries. Very full-bodied, intensively malty, rather sweet with flavours of licorice, dates, whisky and plums, and just a shy hint of smoke.Very interesting, thanks for sharing this one and Angels Share with me, Allen!

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2009 Bottle from 2009 batch pours a smokey dark red/brown that has no head or lacing, but leaves "legs" on the glass the way a brandy would. The bourbon-licorice-caramel-chocolate aroma is top notch. The taste buds find raisin, buffalo jerky, oak, dried cherries, smoke, leather, and a pretty strong alcohol base. The dry finish leaves your mouth a-tingle from the front of your lips to the bottom of your throat. Like a boozier, more concentrated version of Angles Share.  While the complexities of aroma and taste are impressive, at $16/bottle, its a one time taste experiment. There are at least twenty other beers I would buy before another of these.

2008 12.7 oz bottle thanks to Giarcsr ( thanks Ryan)poured black and thick in body and yes this one has a nice big whippy tan head aromas are of dark fruits,roasted malts,bourbon,vanilla and oak taste is of all the fore mentionedalso has great lacing , alcohol is very well hiddenvery smooth and creamy mouthfell one great beer

12.7 oz bottle in Buret: Pours dark dark dark black with a hint of blood around the edges. Absolutely no head, just a small Single-file line of bubbles along part of the glass. Massive chocolate aroma with red-wine poached apple. Wonderful strong but not stringent coffee beans circle around the chocolate. Chocolate coated raisins build up as the alcohol and fruit blow off.  Nice vinous notes underneath everything  as well as a touch of musty basement. Wow! I am already satisfied and I havent even tasted it yet! Flavors of coffee sweetened with chocolate syrup and perhaps a touch of condensed milk this sweet chocolate slides back and makes way for coffee with a whiskey kick. Irish coffee?! This is where the hop bitterness and some hop flavor roll on in breaking up the coffee. The hot alcohols stay but dont become as distracting as they often can. Long coffee, hop and whiskey finish to this slick and thick treat. This really should be a bottle to share... Too bad I opened alone.  Ill have to get another bottle and age it too. All I can say is wowee wow wow!

Thanks to Adrian for opening one of these interesting, champagne-corked bottles.  This poured out black and thick, with a fair amount of coffee in the aroma.  Rich, hoppy, full, and strong.  An espresso malt flavor is the big thing here.  I didnt really taste much bourbon or barrel - I believe it was the last beer of the night, so maybe my taste buds were starting to lose power.  A very good brew, but given how high it is rated, I was hoping for something a little better.  I would like to give it another try someday.

375 ml bottle courtesy of TheEpeeist and a trade long ago, probably our first. Thanks, Chris! 2008 bottle, I believe. Pours an inky thick black, opaque and murky, no light even on the edges, straight black with a dark brown big bubbly head that dies to a moderate layer, laces pretty well. Aromas are a nice layer of bourbon, wet oak, vanilla, not overly boozy, but a nice sufficient layer, letting some nice roasted malts shine through, a touch of chocolate and cream, good dark fruits of plum and raisins. Nice. Initial is full, a good feel for bourbon without getting annoying or overly boozy, as vanilla, oak, and a good bitterness grab the back end. Chocolate and creaminess, caramel, smoothed out, mixing with lighter coffee, roasted malts, and a full feel. This beer coats the palate, but doesnt take a too heavy or syrupy of a body on. Reminds me vaguely of Capricho Oscuro Batch #2. Dark fruits slip in behind the scenes, raisins more now, a touch of cakiness, nut, caramel. Leaves a solid bitterness on the palate from roast and coffee. Carbonation is not a deterrent in this beer, as there is a good amount that gives a a nice body, light tickle on the palate that accentuates the roast and bitterness and dryness. Very nice.. as the bourbon isnt dominant, but has a very synergistic quality to it. Touch of maple syrup. I guess I should have tried the base first though. Cheers!

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2009 Rate from The Map Room, draft.  Pours a dark brown near black shinny  thicker cola color with thin frothy cream color fizzy head.  Aroma is wonderful, rich raisins, great oxidation which I have missed in beers of late, sweet but not cloying, nutty, lovely bourban, hot finish but in a great way, rum-raisin, some dark fruit, really lovely, touch of licorice towards the finish. Long rich nutty rum raisin aftertaste that is just slightly ashy.  Full bodied, lighter side though, smooth and creamy, avoids being heavy, and also avoids the sticky syrupness of regular viscousity, fine sizzling carbonation that improoves the beer without detracting.  Maybe my favorite from Tomme. Fan-freaking-tastic.  [This beer actually got more boozy and harder to drink as I drank, opposed to the other way around... I dont imagine any of the bottles are as good as this is on draft]  This beer honestly tastes like Haagen-Daz Rum Raisin ice cream!

Pours out a flat black.  Smellsi sweet and boozey. Taste is vanilla sweet oak coffee goodness. Very good flavors here chocolate, molasses, cocoa, vanilla, coffee, dark fruit, bourbon,oak and earthy flavors. Very good brew nice and smooth. Great stuff.

I couldnt let this one sit around for too long it was calling my name. Worthy of a nice rating as this is a well made, well aged beer. Smooth, woody, oaky, vanilla laden, roasted malt, a touch of sweetness, and some great fruit flavors show off this beers complexity. Got some nice tan head that didnt last for too long but confirmed a nice carbonation. Prune, molasses and vanilla aromas. Flavor of roasted malt and oak. Some vanilla again and a little tinge of whiskey peat. Finish is fruity and bittersweet like cocoa and coffee. Good stuff.

Bottled 375ml. Vintage 2009. It pours a very dark beer with no head. Almonds, alcohol, pralines, a lot of plums, raisins, faint acetone, Shōchū, walnut and vanilla in the nose. A lot of Shōchū and walnut showing up in the taste. Sweet. Full bodied. Almonds and acetone sneaking in. No carbonation. Licorice, mint, heather and walnut in the finish which is very alcoholic. Rather dissapointing. I didnt enjoy this beer that much.
2008 bottle.  Pours a black color with a medium sized brown head.  Aroma of bourbon, malts, and chocolate cherry.  Taste of chocolate malt, cherry, bourbon, and alcohol.  Very nice and rich.

Bottle @ HJ Hansen, Odense. Pours black with small bubbles on top. Nose is sweet of bourbon and roast. Lots of vanilla and oak. Low carbonation. A bit warm and slick. Taste is bourbon, coffee, vanilla and caramel. A barrel version that really works. Enjoying every sip of this complex masterpiece. Thank you God!

Black Pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is dark bourbon, vanilla, woody and sugary.  Strong dark burnt caramel Malt character with some sweetness, loads of bourbon overtones and booziness.  Powerful, Decadent, Thick creamy mouthfeel.  a dry vanilla sweetness at the finish.  Grandiose

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 Black massive pour with a very small brown head. Aroma hige amounts of bourbon and vanilla with every dark sugar facet covered. Imperial porter with huge amounts of sweetness- reminds me of LA Angels Share but more heavily malt-oriented and a bit less sweet. Flavor is quite similar to the nose with dark fruit, caramel, molasses, and brown sugar coming though powerfully. Palate is rich, thick and amazing. Velvety and smooth.

Tap, at The Publican.  Pour is total blackness with a very thin/ non-existent brown head.  Aroma is simply wonderful: roasted malt, dark fruits, plum, light spiciness, coconut, vanilla, wood, bourbon, and very light alcohol.  it smells way too good! Flavor is vanilla, fruit, wood, light bourbon, very creamy chocolate, smooth coffee, and a lightly peppery/ alcohol finish.  Just amazing.

Source:2008 bottle for my 1400th rating. 
Glass:Bells tulip. 
Appearance:Dark brown pour with a half finger of beige head.
Aroma:Chocolate and vanilla with some roast on the nose. 
Flavor:Chocolate and vanilla dominate, with bourbon, and maple syrup. 
Palate:Full body with soft carbonation.
Overall:Wasnt disappointed.  Great sipping beer.

Bottled. Almost black coloured. Fluffy light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, ripe fruits and some dryness. Flavour is full of chocolate and spice. Bourbon barrel definately notable. Coffee, caramel and a somewhat syrupy touch as well. Medium to full bodied. Dry sweet and spiced finish. Has a light bitter touch and a light alcholbite on palate and lips. ABV almost not notable.

Poured thick and viscous out of the bottle.  The color was almost black with brown highlights sneaking out.  A short ring of brown foam appeared.  No lacing to speak of.  The aroma was boozy, chocolate, malts and some vanilla.  The flavor was chocolate, bourbon and vanilla with a bit of a hop bite towards the end.  Full bodied mouthfeel.  A sipper.  Great beer, but Im glad I shared the bottle as I think drinking this on my own would have been a tad laborious.

06 vintage on draft at Resurrection Alehouse.  Pours jet black, very little mocha head.  Aroma is dominated by bourbon, with only hints of caramel and chocolate coming though.  Taste is very boozy, with a rich chocolate and coffee finish.  While you could still taste the alcohol, this was strangely incredibly smooth.  I had to spread this out over the whole meal as it wasnt all that drinkable.  As much as I love Old Viscosity, this didnt quite do it for me, and I may be in the minority in saying that Old Vis is better.

Dark brown with no head. Aroma is heavy woody bourbon, vanilla, molasses, alcohol, cheap chocolate and light caramell. Body is "viscous" and slimey with extremely low carbonation (which I belive works ok for this kind of brew.) Flavour is similar to aroma but more concentrated and hot with a rather lovely strong bourbon finish with perfectly intergrated warming alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2011 2010 375ml bottle thanks to aplusbreaks.  pours a light black, dark brown with a 1 finger tan head.  wonderful bourbon / oak / dark fruit nose.  thick body with layers of bourbon, wood, vanilla, raisins, plums, dates, coffee and chocolate.  nice carbonation - mellow but not flat.  hot finish with more bourbon and oak.  the sweet dark fruits come forward really well throughout the finish.

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09...  pours a light black with a little tan head... big strong bourbon nose... very smooth medium body with notes of coffee, vanilla and more bourbon... excellent strong and smooth finish... I really want a bottle of this stuff.

On tap (Sept 26th).  Pours dark brown with a medium tan head, some lacing.  Strong sweet bourbon aroma and molasses.  Full body, rich, hot and velvety.  Bourbon, chocolate, and coffee flavors, almost cloyingly sweet, with a mild earthy dry finish.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Bottle from 08. Pours black with a nice tan head to it. Has a smell of bourbon and brown sugar. Has a bourbon, vanilla, and some coffee in the taste.

GABF 2009, day 1: Big whiskey nose. Darkly roasted. Wafty espresso. And a rather large alcohol bite. Nice level of hop bitterness, but the sweetness won in the end. Hints of coconut and vanilla could be found in the background.
Bottle thanks to Bman1113vr. Black pour with almost no head. Aroma is cinnamon, vanilla, bourbon, oak, brown sugar. Flavor is meaty, maple, light coffee, slightly boozy. Great syrupy mouthfeel!

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2011 375 mL bottle purchased 1 year ago from South Bay Drugs (replaces an earlier review from GABF 2009).  Pours black with a short khaki head.  Swirling the glass leaves a slick residue on the side.  The aroma is of bourbon, alcohol, and dark fruit.  Incredible flavor of vanilla, oak, espresso, booze, dark chocolate cake, and coconut.  Very strong alcohol presence.  This is an exceptional beer.

Draft at 2009GABF. Pours a thin short lived head over a dark, brown/black (SR 38) clear body.....nose is loaded with, coffee, chocolate, coconut....taste is similar, with loads of coffee, chocolate, coconut, finishing with a medium hop bitterness....mouth feel is thick and rich, carbonation adds to the creaminess. An excellent example of what can be done with balanced big forces.

2007 pours black. aroma is roasted malt, cocoa, vanilla, and a hint of alcohol. mouthful is enjoyably full with the roasted malt followed by some bourbon, vanilla, bitter chocolate. finish lingers enjoyably :D

Bottled. Tnx Menno! Aroma has coffee, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, dark and dried fruits. Black coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is sweet, vinous, bitter, has fruits, chocolate, oak. Very strong and powerfull. Great brew.

Bottled, shared by Menno. Pitch black color, short head. Aroma is heavy of roasted malt, coffee, chocolat, alcohol, liquor, some cask notes, bit vinous. Strong taste, big malted, bourbon, oak, hint of vanilla, slight alcoholic. Lovely brew, but its 2 much to drink for a starter :-)

On tap
this beer has too much to talk about.  this beer needs your time and your undivided attention.
coffee, dark chocolate, smoke, OAK, fig, whiskey, toasted grain, OAK
changes and grows and changes some more.  We laughed and cried.
Only thing keeping it from a 5 was the slightly out of balance oak.

Pours black, little to no carbonation and it didnt need it. Nose is HUGE bourbon, big roasted malt, dark fruits, raisin, leather, vanilla, wood and cocoa. Flavor is sweet bourbon, roasted grain, slight smoke, vanilla, fig, big oak. Bad ass beer.

Smells and looks like a SA triple bock bit is much better in terms of flavor and the smoothness. Lots of soy and chocolate and bourbon. 08 bottle so it actually had some carbonation instead of being flat.

08 bottle via trade w/bman1113vr. Pours thick and black with a thick dark tan head. Huge aroma, lots of bourbon, vanilla and chocolate malt bursting all over the place. Thick silky smooth body with more of the chocolate malt vanilla bourbon in the flavor. Just a good thick chewy good beer.

Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Nose is soy, vanilla, dark toast barrel, roasted nuts, dark chocolate, bourbon, syrup. Taste is the soy sauce, vanilla, bitter dark chocolate, burnt oak. Nice sticky mouthfeel and medium long finish. Very good for Asa. Pours a dark mahoganey color that is almost opaque body and minute beige head.

12.7 oz bottle.  09 version.Pours dark brown/black ( like motor oil) With No head. Dark Brown ring tried to form,but was to flat.No carbonation
Aroma was  a nice and smokey with dark fruit, oak, vanilla .Flavor is dark chocolate, bourbon, roasted malts, with a slight sour. Has a nice and smooth alcohol burn. seems very thick, but taste a bit watery.  Not worth the 16.99.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2011 Rating #700!  2008 bottle from Zathrus13- Thanks!  Pours black with an inch high tan milkshake head.  initial aroma is dark fruits, dates, figs, bourbon, dark chocolate, vanilla, and peat.  Inviting, to say the least. Flavor is roasted malts, dark chocolate, throat warming alc (in a good way), bourbon, cream.  Less viscous than i expected.  Booze is a great compliment, never hot or overpowering.  Im really enjoying this.  a nice silky smooth balance of dark chocolate, dark fruit, and bourbon. Curious to see how this 2009 bottle from wavers1 turns out... But this was Awesome.  Great job Port Brewing.  



2010 bottle from Phaleslu.  consumed Oct 2011.    Rich molasses, anise, chocolately dark fruits, back by a warming silky vanilla and bourbon.   good carbonation.  nice body.  awesome, heartwarming, tasty beer.

The lack of carbonation really hurts this beer. Pours completely and utterly flat. No carbonation AT ALL. I think I am now done with Lost Abbery till they get this shit fixed. The only thing Ill get from them till I find out otherwise is sour ales. Nose is a little smoke, wood and leather with a bit of cherry pit. Pretty nice nose. Looks a dead black with no head. Flavor is very muted, some light smoke and leather and some bourbon but nothing seems to really hang together, I know from experience that carbonation really helps bring some of this stuff together. The body is super heavy without any carbonation to help it along. Viscous and coating. Really disappointing.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2010 375mL 2010 ed corked and caged into Lost Abbey raster glasses. This is a total re-rate after having a bad batch from 2009. Poured a near black, clear deep brown, with a medium, dense, brown head that leaves swathes of sticky lace everywhere. Aroma also has lots of vanilla, coconut, roasted macadamia nut, vanilla, spicy oak. Not as intense as the normal Old Visc in the nose- more refined. Flavor is rich in cinnamon, burnt wood, roasted malt, charred earth, lots of drying oak. Dry, velvety, soft carbonation on the palate.

[Bottle] Pours black and absolutely dead ass fuckin flat. Aroma is really quite nice and full despite no bubbles to help volatilize it, huge sweet bourbon barrel nose, vanilla, and coconut, hints of bittersweet chocolate,  and booze. Flavor is strong and rich, but again, without any carbonation, it just dangles flaccid and uninteresting on the tongue. There is lots of booze and bourbon, barrel tannin, dry chocolate, and a real chalkiness. If this was carbonated it would be fantastic, but as it sits in my glass, its just another mediocre offering from Tomme Arthur. This whole Abbey thing really gives me the vibe of him being like one of those scary evangelical preachers that promises to deliver you to whatever respective mecca theyre selling you, but it just all ends up being one big scam. Well luckily my investment to this point has been fairly limited.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2010 Draft at bottleworks. Pours inky black wirh just a small ring of head. Aroma starts with chocolate and deep, well balanced alcohol. Taste is touchingly bitter in the cocoa/coffee mold without being overpowering. Feels like an alcoholic dessert sauce.

2008 vintage

Dark liquid with reddish highlights around the top when held to light. Nice mocha colored head and lace.

Smells of booze and dark fruits, dark dark malt: Chocolate and roasted variety.

Really incredible taste, Bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, cream, hint of roasted malt. Bourbon level is high but not burninating.

Mouth is thick and low in carbonation. Warming feeling doesnt start until the end of the drink.

Just an amazing, amazing brew.

Bottle. Im rating two years side by side but they managed to be very similar so it counts like one. Pours pretty much black with huge chocolate head. Aroma is kind of lighter than youd expect but has bourbon present along with some chocolate and toffee. Flavor is potent with bourbon, oak, vanilla and rich roasty malts. Smooth beyond belief. Not overpowering in the least and the alcohol is hard to find, this one really does not fall under the category of challenging huge beers but instead along the lines of well crafted and well balanced drinkable barrel aged goodness. Among the BB releases I find the 08 to be the most subtle at this time. Good lord I wish I had bigger bottles of this stuff.

On tap at Brouwers. Cool thing is this sucker was tapped when Liquid Sunshine VIII met there. This was an awesome surprise. Dark black with nice chocolate head. Head sticks around for some time; nice looking beer. Nice pungent wood/whiskey aroma. Not a stout? As with Old Viscosity, I dont understand this, but oh well. Slight sweet chocolate aroma as well. Nice complex aroma. Very strong whiskey/alcohol at first, then a nice chocolate/wood taste after that. Very nice complex flavor. Very bold. Whiskey is strong, but I like that type of thing. Very rich and smooth palate. So glad to have tried this one. Overall, complex and strong. Get ready to try that whiskey. Great brew.

Draft at Brouwers Cafe, after someone else at the table (I forget who) talked them into tapping this, thanks to them. Poured black, with a thin dark-tan head. Really bourbony, almost too much. Toffee, mocha/chocolate, nuts, gorgeous molasses character. Starts very expressive, and moves right on into dominating from there. A huge beer, just over-dominated by the bourbon.
From a bottle poured thin and black with no head.  Sweet malty flavor with a bourbon aroma and lingering finish.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde!] Pours dark brown with a good brown head. The aroma is probably the weakest point of the beer, and is primarily coconut from the bourbon, alcohol, and a little chocolate. The taste is big on coconut again, but also brownies, alcohol, malt, and a little oak. Quite thick mouthfeel, smooth, and has a long finish. Overall this is a nice beer that is enjoyable, but quite simple--especially in the aroma. Thanks again, Andy!
